From ian at znark.com  Thu Jan  1 00:25:03 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Thu Jan  1 00:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Dual Booting Linux, Windows XP
In-Reply-To: <1072811259.3020.81.camel@farm-libranet>
References: <20031230172517.17106.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>	<1072806727.3022.63.camel@farm-libranet> 	<20031230105459.290cddd9.russell-evans@qwest.net> <1072811259.3020.81.camel@farm-libranet>
Message-ID: <3FF3D90A.2010800@znark.com>

Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:
> On Tue, 2003-12-30 at 10:54, Russell Evans wrote:
>>
>>Don't do it. /dev/hda1 is not your MBR.
> 
> 
> Ok.. I have been wrong before..
> 
> What is it????
> 

/dev/hda1 is the first partition on /dev/hda hard drive.  The MBR is the 
first sector of the hard drive, /dev/hda.  It is possible to have a boot 
sector in the first sector of a partition for use with chaining.

In my experience, it is easiest to have GRUB installed in the MBR.  With 
Windows 2000 and XP, chain loading works great.  This is the config from 
my /etc/grub.conf.  Windows 2000 is installed in /dev/hda1; hd0,0 for GRUB.

title Windows 2000
         rootnoverify (hd0,0)
         chainloader +1

  - Ian

ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Jan  1 14:20:03 2004
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Jan  1 14:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] remote user notifications 
In-Reply-To: <200401011317.58868.carla@bratgrrl.com> 
    on Thu, 01 Jan 2004 13:17:58 PST
    from Carla Schroder <carla@bratgrrl.com> 
References: <200401011317.58868.carla@bratgrrl.com> 
Message-ID: <20040101221954.0592F158056@kanga.canids>

Carla Schroder <carla at bratgrrl.com>:
> Today's 'stump the gurus' question: what can you do for remote users who are 
> running X, like Gnome or KDE or some such, and who won't see console 
> messages? Especially shutdown or reboot messages?

a. notify people at least a day in advance.  a week in advance is
   better.  regular weekly maintenance time is good.

b. ask everyone to run a message program like zephyr or AIM or
   whatever, send alerts that way.  or set up a 'system alert'
   mailing list, which allows people to subscribe their
   email->pager gateway, etc.

c. the hard part is emergencies that involve failure in the
   messaging mechanism.  writing a message to a person's tty is a
   very simple and robust mechanism.  if that doesn't work then
   the whole system is likely to be unusable, and it won't be a
   big deal to reboot without advance notice.  offhand, I can't
   think of any other message mechanism with that characteristic.

   if it's important, set up a list of phone numbers to call for
   alerts.
--

I second Mr Lee's suggestions. The other suggestions thusfar involve
either revealing too much information or depending on the system
having tty's available (such as xterm), which can't be depended
upon. If it's a tunnel, even snarfing xauth permissions is dubious,
though that would be second attempt besides the above (using some
GNOME/KDE tool for scripting dialog boxes). Since the user may not
even be present and have work open, there's just no way to guarantee
no data loss in the cases of "emergencies". Patience in rebooting is
more likely effective.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Brian Derr wrote:
> 
> With this new evidence I have a new question then: What do these
> terminal emulators do that rxvt doesn't?  It doesn't pick up wall or
> shutdown messages.  Is it a compile time option for rxvt?
> 

rxvt picks up wall and write messages on my machine, Fedora Core 1.  The 
one difference could be that rxvt is not writing to /var/run/utmp.  wall 
looks there to find the logged in terminals.  There is a flag (-ut), and 
  resource that controls this.  I guess it could be a compile-time 
option.  It could also be installed non-suid root and not have permissions.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Jan  1 16:45:02 2004
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Jan  1 16:45:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] remote user notifications 
In-Reply-To: <20040101234917.GA6876@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> 
    on Thu, 01 Jan 2004 18:49:17 EST
    from Brian Derr <bderr@myrealbox.com> 
References: <200401011317.58868.carla@bratgrrl.com> <200401011524.48446.carla@bratgrrl.com>  <20040101234917.GA6876@brian.brianandkellyderr.com> 
Message-ID: <20040102004452.0DD35158056@kanga.canids>

Brian Derr <bderr at myrealbox.com>:
> With this new evidence I have a new question then: What do these
> terminal emulators do that rxvt doesn't?  It doesn't pick up wall or
> shutdown messages.  Is it a compile time option for rxvt?

it's about whether you're "logged in" or not,
which is about writing to /var/run/utmp (used to be /etc/utmp),
which is what 'wall' uses to decide where to write to,
and also what 'who' uses to report who's logged in.

any program that wants to be "logged in"
needs to be able to write to utmp,
which means it needs to be set-gid utmp or set-uid root,
or it needs to call a program that can write to utmp,
such as "login".

note, "wall" won't notify remote X users who aren't running an
xterm or similar tty program.
--

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Jan  1 21:00:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Jan  1 21:00:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Loadable Kernel Modules
Message-ID: <20040102045926.31649.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>

My fascination with this subject arose in a rather
unusual way.  I installed SuSE recently, but something
is wrong with the configuration of the boot loader. I
expect to solve this problem in due course, but in the
meantime I can boot only with the floppy disk created
during the installation. Moreover, my attempts to copy
this disk have been unsuccessful (because I can't
mount it). So if this disk were brought near a
magnetic field, I would again be at the mercy of Bill
Gates.

I downloaded boot.iso from SuSE's FTP site. CD's are
rugged, so I would not expect to have such problems
with them. Unfortunately, when I booted into Linux
from this disk, certain functions were missing, such
as the Ethernet connection and sound. I suspected that
such functions were present in kernel modules, and
tested this hypothesis by attempting to enable the
Ethernet card before rebooting. I selected
?RTL8139too? from the drop-down menu, though I did not
provide any parameters. (These apparently should be
io=d0000 irq=9.) In any case, the Ethernet card
functioned when the system came up, though of course
there was still no sound.

In any case, the subject of kernel modules is an
interesting one. The book most frequently cited on the
subject is the one by Rubini and Corbett. What seems
to be more difficult to find is a rather comprehensive
list of all device drivers in use with the parameters
for each, often none. It would be interesting to know
where such a list is maintained, if indeed one exists.

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"Convictions are more dangerous foes of truth than lies."--Frederick Nietzsche

> information about it. 2.0.16 is much much better than any previous
> version and I would recommend upgrading just for the happiness factor. 
> pre .14, I think, doesn't have large file support also. 

I did a search on the net to see what security vulnerabilities gFTP has
had in the past and I could only find two such cases, one major, one
minor, both in 2001.

Vulnerability #1: (Remote Format String Vulnerability)
(quote) "A format string bug exists in the facility used by the gftp
client program to log FTP and HTTP responses. As a result, it may be
possible for a malicious remote server to execute arbitrary code on a
user's system."  This was fixed back in version 2.0.8
http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2657/info/

Vulnerability #2: (On-Screen Plaintext Password Vulnerability)
(quote) "When a user logs on to an FTP server using gFTP the login
password is displayed in plaintext on the screen."  This was fixed in
2.0.7(?).
http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/3446/info/

The exploit you're thinking about was probably due to the general
insecurities/problems with the SS1 protocol, which is what support they
removed in .15.

Cheers,

Daniel

daniel at digitree.org
DigiTree Studios Pty Ltd.

You are probably correct on this matter.  I can read the partition
information, but the kernel won't let the system update the cached/older
partition information, because it could result in possible corruption. 
Running fdisk on a mounted hard disk results in the following:
...
WARNING: Re-reading the partition table failed with error 16: Device or
resource busy.
The kernel still uses the old table.
The new table will be used at the next reboot.
...

The scenarios I described before should still be mostly true as to when
you need to reboot the system when repartitioning.

Message-ID: <20040102172540.70529158056@kanga.canids>

Brian Derr <bderr at myrealbox.com>:
> Try as I might I cannot get rxvt to work with /var/run/utmp.  I looked
> at the compiled in options with rxvt --help and utmp support is there.
> I ran rxvt +ut and rxvt -ut with to no avail.  I also set rxvt to
> set-gid utmp with no success.  So what is wrong here?  I have the +ls
> option set for rxvt which, I am under the impression, is supposed to use
> login.  Any ideas what to try next?

when you have source code, black box debugging is generally a
waste of time for something as simple as this.

a. google for something like "rxvt doesn't write to utmp".  if
   you don't find an answer quickly,

b. compile rxvt with -g if it isn't already, and run it under gdb
   and see if it's actually calling the function that writes to
   utmp.  sometimes 'strace' is useful if you don't want to
   recompile gdb.

   debugging set-id programs is a little messy, in general you
   have to be root to do it.

On Thu, 2004-01-01 at 20:59, Robert Kopp wrote:

> tested this hypothesis by attempting to enable the
> Ethernet card before rebooting. I selected
> ?RTL8139too? from the drop-down menu, though I did not

> In any case, the subject of kernel modules is an
> interesting one. The book most frequently cited on the
> subject is the one by Rubini and Corbett. What seems
> to be more difficult to find is a rather comprehensive
> list of all device drivers in use with the parameters
> for each, often none. It would be interesting to know
> where such a list is maintained, if indeed one exists.
> 
> =====
> Robert "Tim" Kopp
> http://analytic.tripod.com/

If you have some unusual configuration which requires some modules to be
loaded at boot so that some file systems may be read, you may need to
run mkinitrd.  This command loads the necessary modules for booting. 
Man mkinitrd for a synopsis of the command.  But short and sweet:
mkinitrd /boot/initrd-2.2.5-15.img 2.2.5-15

This will make the necessary modules available the next booting.

Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM






From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jan  2 10:25:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jan  2 10:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] gentoo-sparc impressions
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401020851460.8849@pecos.madboa.com>

I installed Gentoo on my Sun Blade 100 (500MHz UltraSPARC-IIe) a
couple weeks ago. This is about the fifth different OS/distro I've put
on this machine; it's had Solaris 8, Solaris 9, Debian, OpenBSD, and
now Gentoo.

Solaris is too proprietary for my taste. Debian was OK, but it just
didn't feel good on the sparc (though I'm satisfied with my Debian
installations on an Alpha and Celeron at home). OpenBSD is very
conservative -- it still runs gcc 2.x and older libs -- and some
crucial ports like ntp never worked well. Plus, the curve for
mastering the OpenBSD security-level stuff is fairly steep, and I
needed a production box sooner rather than later.

Gentoo is the first Free, well behaved, and up-to-date distro that's
really felt good on this machine, which serves as my network gateway,
mail server, and web-development server. In the latter capacity, it's
running MySQL. I think it will soon be my LDAP server as well, but
there are some sticky replication issues that need to be ironed out.

Here are some impressions:

*   The installation documention wasn't included in the CD ISO. How
    wierd is that? The installation instructions are split over a
    dozen or so HTML pages, so I had to pre-download them before
    proceeding.

*   I did the compile-the-whole-thing installation rather than go with
    the pre-compiled stage3 packages. It took about a day to get the
    basic system up and running; most of that time was spent compiling
    glibc and gcc.

*   I've encountered two package hiccups:

    1. A recent silo (sparc bootloader) upgrade left my system
       unbootable. I had to boot from CD and downgrade the package. I
       haven't had time yet to follow up on this.

    2. The sendmail and ssmtp packages don't work and play well. The
       vixie-cron ebuild requires a virtual-mta package, which is
       supposedly supplied by sendmail, but portage insists on
       building ssmtp, which stomps all over sendmail.

*   I've been able to lock the box up completely on two occasions by
    reloading some iptables rules. This is almost certainly not a
    Gentoo issue, but I mention it just for completeness.

*   I communicate with this box over a serial console and ethernet.
    There's no keyboard or monitor -- and I haven't (and probably
    won't) install X -- so I can't report on using its graphics
    subsystem. Ditto for USB and FireWire.

    The great thing is that everything, from boot to full system, work
    flawlessly over the serial console. The only concession I had to
    make was to remove the consolefont and keymaps init scripts from
    the default boot runlevel.

*   The kernel that ships with the boot ISO and the kernel I ended up
    building both had no trouble at all using the built-in GEM
    Ethernet controller and an add-in Intel EEPro card.

    Also, Gentoo ships with dhcpcd instead of ISC's dhclient. That's a
    great choice. I like dhcpcd soooo much better.

*   Most of the core ebuilds are kept fairly up to do for the sparc
    platform -- but many that aren't as central to the system aren't.
    The default SpamAssassin for sparc is 2.4x, which is way, way out
    of date (so I just grabbed the latest from CPAN :-). Inexplicably,
    the DocBook stuff is also quite old.

*   Other than SpamAssassin, I also had to build MIMEDefang and
    Dovecot by hand, but the builds went without a hitch.

*   The init scripts are wierd.

*   /etc/conf.d == /etc/sysconfig

*   rc-update == chkconfig

*   It was very helpful to me, a long-time rpm user, to install the
    'epm' package, which makes querying packages/files much more
    familiar.

*   I dropped this script into /etc/cron.daily to give me a nightly
    report concerning newly updated ebuilds.

    #!/bin/sh
    EMERGE="/usr/bin/emerge"
    GREP="/bin/grep"

    if test -f $EMERGE
    then
      $EMERGE --quiet --nospinner sync 2>&1 | $GREP '^>>>'
      sleep 10
      sync
      $EMERGE --pretend --nospinner --update --deep world
    fi

*   The Sun Blade 100 has a known problem with its system clock
    running too quickly. Sun released a Solaris patch to address the
    issue, but afaict there's no Linux patch for it. Still, ntp is
    able to keep the clock in fairly good shape.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Sat Jan  3 02:37:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Sat Jan  3 02:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix aliases...
In-Reply-To: <1072906815.28880.159.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1072906815.28880.159.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1073126173.19300.43.camel@kat.zotnet.com>

On Wed, 2003-12-31 at 13:40, none wrote:
> Can individual users have an aliases file in their home directory?  
> I want to allow individual users to create their own aliases to 
> their mail accounts. 

This is a security risk.  What if the user creating "root" or
"postmastrer" or "michael."

There are a number of mechanisms to due this correctly.  Most involved a
database (postgres or mysql) or use dbm files.

>  
> 
> I want to block sending mail offsite with a source address 
> "local user name"@"localdomainname."

Blocking is easy.  Block everything you do not specifically allow.


> Another option is to put an admin controlled alias file in
> each user's home directory that contains the aliases for 
> that user and then have users IM admin with their new alias 
> requests.

Very admin intensive.

> 
> After aliases files are changed, does Postfix have to be restarted 
> for the changes to be applied?

If using the db options now, if using an alias file, you need to run
postmap on the file (which created the .db files.

Note:  alias files are for all domains.  Virtual files are per domain.

> 
> If I implement imap, I should probably have a local website where
> a user can request to see all of his/her aliases.

If you are going to do this, then jump to web-cyradm
(http://www.web-cyradm.org/).  This allows users (domain admins) to
control users for the the imap account (nothing to do with users on the
system), domain aliases, and other things.

http://www.web-cyradm.org/#doc

http://www.delouw.ch/linux/
Postfix-Cyrus-MySQL-Web-Cyradm-HOWTO


http://www.web-cyradm.org/documentation/Postfix-cyrus-postgreSQL-web-cyradm.pdf.gz
Postfix-cyrus-postgreSQL-web-cyradm.pdf.gz

I use the Postgres version.

One thing this does is it forces you to maintain a database to receive
mail.


The trick in postfix from from:  
/etc/postfix/main.cf:
        proxy_read_maps= proxy:unix:passwd.byname
        proxy:pgsql:/etc/postfix/pgsql-virtual.cf,
        proxy:pgsql:/etc/postfix/pgsql-canonical.cf,
        proxy:pgsql:/etc/postfix/pgsql-mydestination.cf

        #..... etc
        local_recipient_maps = proxy:unix:passwd.byname $alias_maps
        
        # .... etc
        virtual_maps=proxy:pgsql:/etc/postfix/pgsql-virtual.cf
        
        # alias domains ....
        virtual_alias_domains =
        proxy:pgsql:/etc/postfix/pgsql-mydestination.cf
        
        # Outgoing addresses should be rewritten from e.g test0002 at
        domain to user.name at
        # virtualhost.com. This is important if you like to use a
        webmail interface.
        sender_canonical_maps =
        proxy:pgsql:/etc/postfix/pgsql-canonical.cf
        #
        mailbox_transport = lmtp:unix:public/lmtp
        fallback_transport = lmtp:unix:public/lmtp

These changes are forcing postfix to use the lmtp protocol.  Cyrus is
likewise changed.  You can use this as a template for your changes.

I also added amavis-new and SpammAssassin.

For all of this to work you need to check the versions numbers.  RH9 was
not new enough for several of the packages.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat Jan  3 09:25:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Jan  3 09:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Playing with imap server and fetchmail...
In-Reply-To: <1073113896.18855.30.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1073113896.18855.30.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1073150677.5206.46.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2004-01-02 at 23:11, none wrote:
> I have run into a few curiosities with fetchmail and imap.
> Does IMAP draw the mail out of the local postfix mail
> queue before any local mail user agent such as pine, etc.
> , can?  If not, can messages go missing from the imap
> server if they are picked up by a local mail user agent
> on the server?

Judging from this paragraph and the rest of the email (snipped) I think
you don't have a very good understanding of how email works on the
server side of things.  I would suggest reading up on it a bit, but I'll
give you a brief explanation of what you're asking about...

Mail is stored in spools on the server, be it an mbox file or maildir. 
When it comes in, it's put in to the user's spool, usually in
/var/spool/mail/$user if you're using mbox... if you're using maildir
the spool will generally be in your home directory.

Fetchmail takes the mail and puts it into a mail spool somewhere.

IMAP reads mail from the mail spool allowing a client system access to a
user's email almost as if the spool were local.

POP3 reads mail from the mail spool, generally sending it to a client
then deleting it from the spool.

AFAICT, imap2000 doesn't seem to really be the most popular nor the best
IMAP server to be running.  It seems difficult to find decent IMAP
servers these days.  I've pretty much settled on BincIMAP.  It's young,
but seems to be doing good for me... it's quick.  You'd have to convert
from mbox to maildir to use it, though.

<snip>
>      --  Michael C. Robinson

That's kinda funny.

Rob

I prefer things... servers, especially... to do one thing and do it
well.  I don't like the idea of one server handling pop3 and imap
together very much... but maybe that's just me...

FWIW, BincIMAP handles Maildir, not mbox (currently, although I think
they may add mbox support down the road), handles SSL/TLS just fine
(unless you build statically on a different system and move the binaries
over, it seems) and is very flexible in its authentication.  By default,
it uses 'checkpasswd' but it can be set to use almost anything else, I
guess.

never heard of it before.  :-)

about it.  It didn't seem to fully understand separation of mail spools
and regular files in your home directory and as a result would often
scan the entire directory for email.  I didn't realize this was the
cuase of the uw slowdown until I was speaking with SquirrelMail devs one
day who started ranting a bit when they learned I was using uw-imap. 
:-)

That and procmail can't seem to write to an mbox file once it hits 49MB
in size any more.  So I needed to move over to Maildir.  Maildir is so
much more responsive than mbox with large spools after the initial cache
is built.

> Read what?  There are a lot of HOWTO's that aren't good enough.

Alone each one may not be good enough, but together they start to paint
a picture you can use to get a better idea of how email is working on
your mail server.

> There are a lot of books like the one Sendmail that wouldn't
> be particularly helpful.  When using IMAP, where are the lists
> of what is read and not read kept?  Does IMAP ever remove 
> messages from the spool?  

Maildir provides a mechanism for indicating to whatever software happens
to be reading the specific spool what has and what has not been read. 
Since many things could be reading from the spool (mutt, pine, pop3,
imap, others?)... the mechanism for identifying what has and has not
been read must be very standardized.  If you read documents on how
Maildir works, you'll probably start to understand this a little bit. 
Hint:  It has to do with the naming of the files.

mbox surely has a similar function, although I never really got in to
the how's and why's of mbox so really can't speak to how exactly it
works.

Sure the imap server can remove messages from the spool.  Why wouldn't
it, when you hit delete on the message?  Just like mutt can remove
messages from the spool.  Have you ever actually used imap before?

> Who teaches a course on Postfix 
> and other mail issues within the Portland area or online?

Google might know.  I think taking a class on Postfix is probably a
little bit overboard unless you want to become a professional sysadmin.

You need to understand we don't care if you're using Postfix or some
hand-rolled MTA, though.  As soon as it puts the mail in the spool, it
is done with it, it does not care what, if anything, happens to the
mail.

> Where I'm at, there isn't exactly a public library to go
> that has anything useful on technical topics.  I didn't
> know of any such resource when I was at Portland State 
> either, the unrealistic expectations of some instructors
> such as Karla Fant compounding this problem.  It isn't
> talked about enough in Computer Science programs at PSU.

Computer Science != SysAdmin

Computer Science is about creating programs to do things for you, not
about setting up mail servers.  Why the hell would you expect to be
taught about IMAP, Postfix, Maildir, or mbox in a CS program?

> > Mail is stored in spools on the server, be it an mbox file or maildir. 
> > When it comes in, it's put in to the user's spool, usually in
> > /var/spool/mail/$user if you're using mbox... if you're using maildir
> > the spool will generally be in your home directory.
> 
> Can a Maildir be elsewhere than the home directory so that mixing with
> other files isn't a problem?  What files need to be changed to relocate
> Maildirs or is the location of the Maildir assumed by many programs?
> Is evolution Maildir compatible?

You could put a Maildir anywhere you want to.  However, getting an IMAP
server to read from a Maildir outside of your home directory can be
tricky.  Getting Postfix to deliver to a Maildir outside of your home
directory can be tricky.  Such things are not recommended.  What *I* did
was set the default to ~/.Maildir/INBOX so it isn't seen unless I want
to see it.

I'm sure evolution is Maildir compatible ... but are you running
evolution on the mail server, reading right off the spool?  From the
other email you sent, I'm assuming you want Evolution reading from an
IMAP server, right?  Evolution speaks IMAP... we don't care what IMAP
speaks as long as it speaks whatever your mail is stored as.  IMAP does
the translation from Maildir.

Please, if you haven't already... PLAY WITH THIS.  If you don't wish to
read a bunch of documents on the subject, just play with it yourself,
see what it can do, see what it can't do.

At the risk of offending everybody by stating your questions are
somewhat stupid... your questions are somewhat stupid.  They show you
have not tried to do your homework.  You are asking questions without
understanding what it is you are even asking.  Do you even understand
what IMAP is?  What an IMAP server does?  What Postfix does?  What a
mail spool is?  If you don't fully understand these items, read up on
each individual one, get a good grasp of each one, *then* ask questions
about them.

Please, GAFC.  STFW.  RTFM.

Rob




From heinlein at madboa.com  Sat Jan  3 12:59:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Jan  3 12:59:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Playing with imap server and fetchmail...
In-Reply-To: <1073159007.5209.84.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <1073113896.18855.30.camel@goose.robinson-west.com> 
 <1073150677.5206.46.camel@dell.linux.box>  <1073157469.28601.11.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
 <1073159007.5209.84.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401031243260.8849@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 3 Jan 2004, AthlonRob wrote:

> Maildir provides a mechanism for indicating to whatever software
> happens to be reading the specific spool what has and what has not
> been read. [...]
>
> mbox surely has a similar function, although I never really got in
> to the how's and why's of mbox so really can't speak to how exactly
> it works.

mbox clients (mail readers or things like pop/imap servers) add
a Status: and X-Status: header into each message:

Status: O    <-- new message
Status: RO   <-- message that's been read

X-Status: A  <-- message that's been answered
X-Status: D  <-- message that's marked as deleted
X-Status: AD <-- combo of above two

There are other permutation of those headers, but that's the gist of
it. The absence of the Status: or X-Status: headers means that a
message has not been read by an mbox-compliant mail client or pop/imap
server.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

To be able to write mail software and operating system 
code.  Understanding and using software is about more 
than just reading code, otherwise none of us would ever 
be able to use the sizable systems we have today stuck
in the verification process.  If there is a great chasm
between the sysadmin and the programmer, this does
not bode well for future software projects.
  
Computer science is an umbrella, it's sad that many 
limit it to the reading and writing of code.  In 
reality, a good programmer has to come up with algorithms, 
etc. before writing a new program or even interpreting an 
old one.  The source code, especially when it is poorly 
documented, is never enough.  There are network 
administrators and network programmers, the latter 
has a far better chance of contributing source 
code changes to the open source community.  For lack
of a Network Programmers degree at Portland State,
CS is the closest second.  I think Linus has a 
specialty in Unix system architecture.

I have used IMAP, the explanation that it makes
a spool merely look local is oversimplified.  There is
marking with an mbox or Maildir spool to determine
what is read and not read ( ? on deleted ).  There is 
understanding when fetchmail is invoked with fetch-all 
why the same messages sometimes get retrieved ten 
to twelve times.  What is up with incremental 
message downloads in evolution if the remote 
spool has 200 messages?  Is this a problem with mbox, 
evolution crashing during message retrieval, or is 
it a problem with the remote source?  If a download 
crashes during an imap session, does this result in 
multiple copies of the last message sought?  If you 
fetchmail from imap to imap, do you need to set the 
address of the source server to allow deleting  
messages?

For now I'm just going to try and work with fetchmail.
I have decidedly backed off of having a local 
IMAP server.

When will there be a nationally recognized bachelor's 
degree for system administration?  I guess it would
be called bachelors of infrastructure technology,
or whatever IT stands for.  ITT has some degrees,
but they're anti Linux, horribly expensive, and
their degrees are not nationally recognized under
the same accreditation system that traditional
degrees are.  When I talked with them, it seemed
I'd be training to become a slave to some
single job description or small menu thereof
in an atmosphere of potentially zero technology
sector job offerings.  ITT looks to be a path to 
earning less than a person with a traditional 
degrees and ultimately working with anything 
(mostly Windows), but not Linux.

On Sat, 2004-01-03 at 13:48, Carla Schroder wrote:
> Anyone know of a nice script for adding users in bulk on a Linux system? 
> Assume you already have a database of user information of some kind- a 
> /passwd file from another system, a directory or database of some kind.
> I think I would want the login names and other personal data, and then 
> generate a new password. I've been googling without much success.

It shouldn't be very difficult to write a script like that at all.

Use 'useradd' ....

In a for loop, something like:

useradd -p $PASSWORD $USERNAME
mkdir /home/$USERNAME
chown $USERNAME /home/$USERNAME

...should do the trick for you.  You can, of course, modify the useradd
line with more options if you want to do things differently than the
system default options.

Rob

On Sat, 3 Jan 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:

> cp /etc/skel/\.* /home/$USERNAME
> chown -R $USERNAME /home/$USERNAME

Using tar will pick up symlinks, directories, etc...

  tar -cC /etc/skel . | tar -xC /home/$USERNAME

though the -C switch is specific to GNU tar.

> FYI in case you decide to install more Debian systems if you type bf24
> at the boot prompt in the installer you will get 2.4.18 as your default
> kernel.  It is still wise to update to at least 2.4.23 due to the recent
> kernel exploit.

Actually, you don't need to upgrade to 2.4.23, as long as you have the
security updates in your sources.list -- debian backports security
updates into its stable kernel (2.4.18 at the moment) so as to provide
the minimum of hassle to production environments.

I put my linux box running SuSE 8.1 behind a D-Link DI-604 router/firewall, which is connected to ADSL. Before putting the machine behind the router, all my network connection (i.e., web, email, etc.) were quite quite quick. After setting up the DI-604, I can successfully connect to outside addresses, but resolving host names is terribly slow. However, when I use nslookup I get a very fast response. If I run Win NT though vmware, the response is also very quick! The problem does not seem to be browser or software related--the slow down occurs with different browsers (mozilla, galeon, konqueror) as well as with my email retrieval (sylpheed).

Any help to resolving this problem would be greatly appreciated! I've included my host.conf, hosts, and resolv.conf for reference.

Thanks.





host.conf:

#
# /etc/host.conf - resolver configuration file
#
# Please read the manual page host.conf(5) for more information.
#
#
# The following option is only used by binaries linked against
# libc4 or libc5. This line should be in sync with the "hosts"
# option in /etc/nsswitch.conf.
#
order hosts, bind
#
# The following options are used by the resolver library:
#
multi on



hosts:

#
# hosts This file describes a number of hostname-to-address
# mappings for the TCP/IP subsystem. It is mostly
# used at boot time, when no name servers are running.
# On small systems, this file can be used instead of a
# "named" name server.
# Syntax:
#
# IP-Address Full-Qualified-Hostname Short-Hostname
#

127.0.0.1 localhost

# special IPv6 addresses
::1 localhost ipv6-localhost ipv6-loopback

fe00::0 ipv6-localnet

ff00::0 ipv6-mcastprefix
ff02::1 ipv6-allnodes
ff02::2 ipv6-allrouters
ff02::3 ipv6-allhosts

192.168.0.100 mycomp.pacifier.com mycomp


resolv.conf:

domain pacifier.com
nameserver 64.255.237.242
nameserver 64.255.237.243

www.spiretech.com is inexpensive. You use your own
computer.

One potential problem with any colo facility is e-mail and
spam. If your "neighbors" in the IP address space are spammers,
your address can be black listed. With a colo facility that
allows customers to use their own computers, the spammer could
be a hacked Windows box.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Mon Jan  5 11:05:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Mon Jan  5 11:05:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Dual-booting Linux, Windows XP
Message-ID: <20040105190407.17789.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

I have discussed this before, but this is probably the
easiest way to do it:

Put GRUB in the first sector of /boot, if not already
there.

Copy to a DOS-formatted floppy disk:
dd if=/dev/hdb2 of=/bootsect.lnx bs=512 count=1

Any 8.3 filename not already used will do, and your
device name is probably different, too.

Copy this small file to c:\ on Windows XP.

At the command line:

attrib -r -s -h c:\boot.ini

Add this at the end:

c:\bootsect.lnx="Linux"

Change the attributes back:

attrib +r +s +h c:\boot.ini and reboot.

NTLDR's welcome screen is pretty ugly, so if you want
a splash screen of Michelangelo painting the Sistine
Chapel, you may have to use a different method.


=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Mon Jan  5 15:17:02 2004
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon Jan  5 15:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] adding user accounts in bulk
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401031641150.8849@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <200401031348.43119.carla@bratgrrl.com> <20040104001404.GC27603@patch.com> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401031641150.8849@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <200401051517.27436.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 03 January 2004 4:43 pm, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Sat, 3 Jan 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> 
> > cp /etc/skel/\.* /home/$USERNAME
> > chown -R $USERNAME /home/$USERNAME
> 
> Using tar will pick up symlinks, directories, etc...
> 
> ? tar -cC /etc/skel . | tar -xC /home/$USERNAME
> 
> though the -C switch is specific to GNU tar.

usermod moves a user's home directory, and handles all the grunt work of 
permissions etc:

# usermod -d /server1/home/username/ -m  username

And good ole awk is find n dandy for finding all the files that belong to a 
user, such as crontabs, mail spools, random stuff:

# find / -uid 1050
# find / -user username

Find orphaned files with -nouser and -nogroup.

Oh here's another cool find command that comes in handy when making mass 
changes because a user has moved or been deleted:

# find / -uid 1050 -exec chown  1200 {} \;

Or use the usernames instead of uid. However if the user has been deleted, the 
only way to find any remaining files are by the uid.

From griffint at pobox.com  Mon Jan  5 17:34:02 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Mon Jan  5 17:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux or Unix Classes(warning: VENTING)
In-Reply-To: <3ffe0747.7653835@mail.aracnet.com>
References: <3ffe0747.7653835@mail.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200401051733.51083.griffint@pobox.com>

On Monday 05 January 2004 4:55 pm, Prutzer wrote:
> HI All,
> I'm here to bitch, so if you don't want to hear it(readit) then kill
> file the thread please.
>
> I'm bloody damned tired of signing up for a class to find it's been
> canceled. Then being offered a MS class instead.
> <snip>

99% of cancellations happen because not enough people sign
up for the class to make a profit, or at least break even. Keep
in mind the the trainers are trying to make a living too. And trust
me when I say there's not much margin in the training business.
The last thing trainers need is to be dishing out expenses to teach
a class and not get it back in tuition.

As for offering an MS class as a substitute, I have no explanation
for that and won't bother trying to defend it. I guess they just offer
what they've got.

The best thing you can do is pool your demand for training. If you
can find other like-minded individuals and you all sign up for the
same class, you'll reduce the chances of it getting cancelled. Most
classes will go ahead if they reach break-even enrollment.

Terry

cater to smaller installations.  Most co-lo places will offer fractions

On Mon, 2004-01-05 at 15:21, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Sunday 04 January 2004 9:11 am, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> > 
> > On Sat, Jan 03, 2004 at 04:30:22PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > > Rather,
> > > useradd -m -k /etc/skel -p $PASSWORD $USERNAME

man useradd

 -m     The  user?s home directory will be created if it does not exist.
        The files contained in skeleton_dir will be copied to the  home
        directory  if  the  -k  option is used, otherwise the files
        contained in /etc/skel will be used instead.  Any directories 
        contained  in  skeleton_dir  or  /etc/skel  will  be created in
        the user's home directory as well.  The -k option is only 
        valid  in conjunction  with  the  -m option.  The default is to
        not create the directory and to not copy any files.

so the -k seems redundant 
-p passwd
              The encrypted password, as returned by crypt(3).  The
default is to disable the account

So you need to loop $password and $username 

Off course you can leave off -m if according to -M

-M     The user home directory will not be created, even if the  system
              wide settings from /etc/login.defs is to create home dirs.

of course group adding was a redhat thing:

     -n     A group having the same name as the user being added to the
system will be created by default. This option will turn  off  thisRed
Hat Linux specific behavior.

course, the economy was better then, so you might have to try something
a little different. 

I've been running small networks of Suns and Linux and Windows since
about 1992 (not so much Linux in 92, since it wasn't production quality
then), and I think the Cisco certifications are a great place to start.
If you understand networking and troubleshooting, you have a strong
foundation. Then maybe Linux+ or server+ certification (MS-heavy, but
lots of generic stuff too) and some low-wage work to get experience and
you'll have a nice resume.

I'm not saying that a degree is a bad idea, just that Linux admins don't
usually have one that directly relates to their work. A degree in any
hard science will be very useful, though. 

Good luck!

--Kurt

that doesn't mind you shoulder surfing (pay attention and take notes, 
the lesson will be a valuable one). If you feel like you need to get a 
jump on the issue and want to try your hand you can look to 
tcpdump/ethereal and your favorite TCP/IP reference material (any layer 
2 reference would be good too but not likely to be helpful given the 
circumstances of your current problem).

On Tue, 6 Jan 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:

> Well, as a holder of a Bachelor of Fine Arts who started working
> with computers less than a year after graduation and then spent the
> bulk of my career with the beasts, I'd suggest that's not a bad
> idea. :)

We've had this discussion before. Many disciplines have a three-way
distinction between design, creation and maintenance:

  Architect           - Contractor      - Handy man
  Automotive designer - Plant Engineers - Mechanic
  Computer Scientist  - Programmer      - Sysadmin

Admittedly, the line is often blurry, but I'll stand by the
distinctions nonetheless.

The maintenance folks typically receive limited formal training; it's
mostly on-the-job stuff. That's why it's not uncommon to find
sysadmins with non-CS backgrounds (like me :-).

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

On Tue, 2004-01-06 at 09:47, Robert Kopp wrote:
> Having installed a more current version of Linux, I
> get the impression that I have trouble compiling some
> software that formerly did not present difficulties
> (gcc-3.3.1-24). Is this possible? If so, how can I
> address the problem?

I think you're being a bit vague...  :-)

I installed this thing, and it doesn't do the thing I wanted it to.  Any
suggestions?

What version of 'Linux' did you install?  As in, what distribution and
version, although they really shouldn't matter too much.  "Current
version of Linux" doesn't narrow it down very much.  :-)

Yes, new GCC versions *can* present compilation difficulties.  They do
things just a little bit different, which can lead to problems.  IMHO,
GCC 3.2.3 is the one to stick with for now; it's what both Slackware and
Gentoo utilize which speaks volumes to me.

How to resolve it?  Install a different GCC version, perhaps?

Rob

>EasyStreet is the only co-lo facility I've seen that seems to really
>cater to smaller installations.  Most co-lo places will offer fractions
>of a rack, but you'll share a single full-size cabinet with other
>customers, which is kinda sucky.  EasyStreet actually has fractional

I'll definately second this nomination.  Last place I worked used to 
rent a partial
rack cabinet at EasyStreet.  The facility is clean and comfortable.  The 
network
connectivity and support staff are excellent.  Admittedly, the final 
clincher was
EasyStreet's location.  The former company was located out at Cornelius 
Pass Rd
and Sunset Hwy, and I live only a couple of miles (max.) from 
EasyStreet.  For
planned work, it was quicker than going all the way downtown.  And, if there
had been any midnight calls (there wasn't), I wouldn't even have to get 
on a freeway.

If you use EasyStreet for any other services, and need a co-lo, you 
certainly
want to consider their place.

- Don

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Jan  6 12:09:01 2004
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor Pikus)
Date: Tue Jan  6 12:09:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] apt vs rpm cheat sheet?
In-Reply-To: <20040106192629.GC1469@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0401061148030.8487-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Tue, 6 Jan 2004, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> list all packages	rpm -qa		apt-cache pkgnames
> package information	rpm -qi		apt-cache showpkg
> install a package	rpm -ivh	apt-get install **
> update package list
> update packages
There is no cheat-sheet because the tools do slightly different things:
rpm is a back-end to apt. rpm operates on installed packages, and package
files which you have downloaded (it can also take a URL, but that only
automates the download). apt operates on the list of package records which
it caches.

So, if you want to know what packages are installed, there is nothing
better than rpm -qa. If you want to know about an installed package,
apt can't do any more than rpm -qi can do (it spits out more information
by default, but you can get all of that with rpm options like --provides
and --requires). However, apt-cache showpkg will do an effective "rpm -qi"
on a package you don't have yet. So if you want to know what would package
X do if you actually installed it, this will tell you.

Similarly, apt-get install will install package and its dependencies from
the repositories it knows about, while rpm -i will install a package from
a file or URL.

So there is no "mapping", you use apt and rpm for different purposes.


>
> ** performs dependency resolution
>
> If not, if people email back with ideas I'd be happy to coallate,
> format(probably as HTML) and re-release them.  We could even include
> yum or other package managers.

So thinking this was a good cause I outputted rpm --help into a file and
added what I thought was the apt commands.  I've cut and pasted it here,
and I've attached to preserve formatting.

some things to remember, as Fedor pointed out, apt is more of a way of
getting files packages, not an installer, or maintainer of packages.  In
redhat it is a transport mechanism for rpm.  I believe in debian its
dpkg/dselect.  So lots of rpm specific issues do not apply to apt.  The
same is true the other way.


Usage: rpm [OPTION...]

Query options (with -q or --query):
  -c, --configfiles                list all configuration files
  -d, --docfiles                   list all documentation files
*seems none*

  --dump                           dump basic file information
apt-cache dump

      dump   dump shows a short listing of every package in the cache. It  is
              primarily for debugging.

  -l, --list                       list files in package

apt-cache showpkg
       showpkg
              showpkg displays information about the packages  listed  on  the
              command  line. Remaining arguments are package names. The avail-
              able versions and reverse dependencies of  each  package  listed
              are  listed,  as  well as forward dependencies for each version.
              Forward (normal) dependencies are those packages upon which  the
              package  in  question  depends;  reverse  dependencies are those
              packages that depend upon the package in question. Thus, forward
              dependencies must be satisfied for a package, but reverse depen-
              dencies need not be.  For instance, apt-cache  showpkg  libread-
              line2 would produce output similar to the following:


  --queryformat=QUERYFORMAT        use the following query format
  -s, --state                      display the states of the listed files
*seems none*

  -a, --all                        query/verify all packages
       pkgnames
              This  command prints the name of each package in the system. The
              optional argument is a prefix match to filter the name list. The
              output  is suitable for use in a shell tab complete function and
              the output is generated extremly quickly. This command  is  best
              used with the --generate option.

  -f, --file                       query/verify package(s) owning file
  -g, --group                      query/verify package(s) in group
*seems none*

*sorta* apt-cache search
      search search  performs  a  full  text  search on all available package
              files for the regex pattern given. It searchs the package  names
              and  the  descriptions for an occurance of the string and prints
              out the package name and the short  description.  If  --full  is
              given then output identical to show is produced for each matched
              package and if --names-only is given then the  long  description
              is not searched, only the package name is.

  --specfile                       query a spec file
*seems none*

  --whatprovides                   query/verify the package(s) which provide a

apt-get install
       install
...
       If no package matches the given expression and the expression  contains
       one of ?.?, ??? or ?*? then it is assumed to be a POSIX regex and it is
       applied to all package names in the  database.  Any  matches  are  then
       installed  (or  removed).  Note  that  matching is done by substring so
       ?lo.*? matches ?how-lo? and ?lowest?. If this is undesired prefix  with
       a ?^? character.


  --badreloc                       relocate files in non-relocateable package
  -e, --erase=<package>+           erase (uninstall) package

apt-get remove
      there are ways of installing during a remove with adding a +

  --excludepath=<path>             skip files with leading component <path>

       --force-yes
              Force yes; This is a dangerous option that  will  cause  apt  to
              continue  without prompting if it is doing something potentially
              harmful. It should not be used except  in  very  special  situa-
              tions.  Using  force-yes  can  potentially  destroy your system!
              Configuration Item: APT::Get::force-yes.

  -F, --freshen=<packagefile>+     upgrade package(s) if already installed

*sorta, this is for all packages* apt-get upgrade

      upgrade
              upgrade  is  used to install the newest versions of all packages
              currently installed on the system from the sources enumerated in
              /etc/apt/sources.list.  Packages  currently  installed  with new
              versions available are retrieved and upgraded; under no  circum-
              stances  are  currently  installed packages removed, or packages
              not already installed retrieved and installed. New  versions  of
              currently  installed  packages  that  cannot be upgraded without
              changing the install status of another package will be  left  at
              their current version. An update must be performed first so that
              apt-get knows that new versions of packages are available.

  -h, --hash                       print hash marks as package installs (good
                                   with -v)

  --ignoreos                       don't verify package operating system
  --ignoresize                     don't check disk space before installing
*seems none*

  -i, --install                    install package(s)
apt-get install

*apt has its own cache issues*

  --nomd5                          don't verify MD5 digest of files

                                   satisfy dependencies

  --noscripts                      do not execute package scriptlet(s)
  --notriggers                     do not execute any scriptlet(s) triggered
                                   by this package

       -q
 
       --quiet
              Quiet; produces output suitable for logging,  omitting  progress
              indicators.  More q?s will produce more quiet up to a maximum of
              2. You can also use -q=# to set the quiet level, overriding  the
              configuration  file.   Note  that  quiet level 2 implies -y, you
              should never use -qq without a no-action modifier  such  as  -d,
              --print-uris  or  -s  as APT may decided to do something you did
              not expect.  Configuration Item: quiet.

  -v, --verbose                    provide more detailed output
*apt is pretty verbose by default*

  --fileclass                      list file names with classes
  --filecolor                      list file names with colors

  --filerequire                    list file names with requires

                                   installed)
  --redhatrequires                 find package name that contains a required
                                   capability (needs rpmdb-redhat package
                                   installed)
  --buildpolicy=<policy>           set buildroot <policy> (e.g. compress man

  --without=<option>               disable configure <option> for build

apt-cache dump

      dump   dump shows a short listing of every package in the cache. It  is
              primarily for debugging.

  -l, --list                       list files in package

apt-cache showpkg
       showpkg
              showpkg displays information about the packages  listed  on  the
              command  line. Remaining arguments are package names. The avail-
              able versions and reverse dependencies of  each  package  listed
              are  listed,  as  well as forward dependencies for each version.
              Forward (normal) dependencies are those packages upon which  the
              package  in  question  depends;  reverse  dependencies are those
              packages that depend upon the package in question. Thus, forward
              dependencies must be satisfied for a package, but reverse depen-
              dencies need not be.  For instance, apt-cache  showpkg  libread-
              line2 would produce output similar to the following:

Second Tues of the month.

Speakers:  Toby Kohlenberg, Intel

Title: How (and why) to build a Security Operations Center.

Topic: Over the course of 2002 and 2003, Mr. Kohlenberg was responsible
for the development and training of a Security Operations Center. This
talk provides a summary of the lessons learned over the course of that
work. Mr. Kohlenberg is a Senior Information Security Technologist for
Intel Corporation. He has experience in penetration testing, incident
response, architecture design and review, IDS, and various other things
that paranoid geeks are likely to spend time dealing with. In the last
couple years he has been responsible for developing security
architectures for world-wide deployments of secure WLANs, Windows
2000/Active Directory, and IDS technologies. He currently holds the
CISSP, GCFW, GCIH and GCIA certifications.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Jan  6 13:37:02 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue Jan  6 13:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] apt vs rpm cheat sheet?
In-Reply-To: <1073423929.23573.5.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
References: <20040106192629.GC1469@dalsemi.com> <1073423929.23573.5.camel@kat.zotnet.com>
Message-ID: <20040106213607.GG1469@dalsemi.com>

On Tue, Jan 06, 2004 at 01:18:49PM -0800, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> 
> So thinking this was a good cause I outputted rpm --help into a file and
> added what I thought was the apt commands.  I've cut and pasted it here,
> and I've attached to preserve formatting.
> 
> some things to remember, as Fedor pointed out, apt is more of a way of
> getting files packages, not an installer, or maintainer of packages.  In
> redhat it is a transport mechanism for rpm.  I believe in debian its
> dpkg/dselect.  So lots of rpm specific issues do not apply to apt.  The
> same is true the other way.
> 

Thanks a lot, Zot.  As I'm wading through various manpages I was
understanding more of what Fedor (and now you) are saying.  apt/up2date
mainly handle transport (getting it here) and installation issues
(dependency resolution, ordering, etc.)  dpkg and rpm are for handling
a package (install it, remove it, verify it, query it) and handling the
set of installed packages.

I think what I'm going to do from here is this:

Figure out the set of commands that I most used and document them.

Publish that.

Add more information from your manpage mangling and other feedback
and repeat.

Thanks again!
Colin

Second Tues, Dec 2nd.

Speakers:  Toby Kohlenberg, Intel

Title: How (and why) to build a Security Operations Center.

Topic: Over the course of 2002 and 2003, Mr. Kohlenberg was responsible
for the development and training of a Security Operations Center. This
talk provides a summary of the lessons learned over the course of that
work. Mr. Kohlenberg is a Senior Information Security Technologist for
Intel Corporation. He has experience in penetration testing, incident
response, architecture design and review, IDS, and various other things
that paranoid geeks are likely to spend time dealing with. In the last
couple years he has been responsible for developing security
architectures for world-wide deployments of secure WLANs, Windows
2000/Active Directory, and IDS technologies. He currently holds the
CISSP, GCFW, GCIH and GCIA certifications.

Syntax help: PCA filename #rows #cols option

Unless you want to study Linux.  Dennis and I met before I started 
at PCC back in 98 and he gave me quite s bit of crticism for wanting 
to specialize in Linux then.  He apologized, but it was a very
traumatizing experience.  As far as the accusations of poorly done math,
I'm getting my math at Rock Creek with grades I only dreamed of three
years ago.  Maybe he was talk, maybe he teaches programming well.
I was interested in risking a course with someone I could clearly
anger so easily for doing nothing more than stating vague interest
in a Linux focused computer science career.> 
> -- 
> "The LORD is good, a strong hold in the day of trouble; and he knoweth
> them that trust in him." -- Nahum 1:7 KJV
> 
> We are solar powered; we are powered by the Son.  -- Doug Rowse, 2003
> 
> If God were small enough to fit into my head He wouldn't be big enough 
> to worship.  -- Brett Meador, 2002 


Karla knows her stuff, but she is angry and it shows through
the number of students failing.  Making programming torture in my
opinion doesn't help anyone.  I'm speaking as someone who passed 
the 202 midterms with flying colors, but couldn't get through 
a single programming assignment.  Karla needs to give clearer
assignments and perhaps even some hints.  Maybe if she does this, 
she won't lose as many students.  I recommend going through the
161,2,3 series with her, but I don't recommend 202.

Nobody wants to be risk being just a tech.  Linux is portrayed as
something you can only work with as a tech though.  Another problem
I see is that even some of the brightest engineers are ending up
under employed.  IBM has cut a lot of research programs at the top.  
If Ed wants to offer ALC press as a realistic avenue to get the
best education in the area with which to start a career as a
professional Linux administrator with, great.  

The local CS programs at PCC and PSU need to be overhauled anyways
though. The politics of Microsoft, or even O'Reilly dependency for 
that matter, ought to be questioned.  The less flexible a degree
is for specializing in various career fields, the less it can 
offer in the way of job security.  A degree is like a business 
contract, if you complete certain requirements the degree is 
awarded.  There needs to be an educational path for computer 
scientists who want to focus on Linux/Unix.  If it has to happen 
in the private sector first, so be it.  I see an AS as a good 
starting point before attempting a risky venture to bill oneself 
as a Linux specialist, that way you're halfway done with a 
traditional bachelors degree just in case all your efforts go 
South.

I don't know what Ed's or Mike's capacity is, what anyone interested
in Linux seems to need yesterday is politics 101 and basic understanding
of where things really are.  The notion of pursuing a professional
career without the focusing influence of a strong University or college
is not an appealing one, at least not to me.  Especially if your
credentials turn out to be solely your word, your work, and nothing 
more, the though of no degree is terrifying.  How are you going to get
your start?  What about advancement?  If there is a way to go from
an AS to a professional society through a strong apprenticeship program,
this is a less terrifying notion.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From dhedlund at digitree.org  Tue Jan  6 17:08:01 2004
From: dhedlund at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)
Date: Tue Jan  6 17:08:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora or not?
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F41Eq80zU0KjRG0001711d@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F41Eq80zU0KjRG0001711d@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <1073435293.9636.16.camel@bluegum.digitree.org>

On Wed, 2004-01-07 at 09:44, Vincent Yau wrote:

> Perhaps it will just be a matter of time before Fedora is more stable.
> Should I bank on that?  Or should I go search for another distribution like
> Debian or Slackware?   Or is it perhaps that I configure something wrong
> on my  Fedora installation?

I have found Fedora to be very stable overall.  Some applications that
people might use might be a bit buggy, but it could just be that
application or the version thereof.

I've been very happy using Mozilla Firebird over Mozilla itself.  Some
people have problems with Firebird, but I have set up java and flash
plugins with it and using it heavily I haven't had it crash on me in the
two months or so I've been using it.
http://dag.wieers.com/packages/mozilla-firebird/mozilla-firebird-0.7-1.rhfc1.dag.i386.rpm

The addition of Yum, and using various yum repositories has made adding
optional packages to Fedora a breeze (mplayer, wine, etc).  It's as
simple as going 'yum install <packagename>' and 'yum update'.  Here are
some places you can get yum to work with:
http://dag.wieers.com/apt/
http://www.fedora.us/
http://rpm.livna.org/
http://freshrpms.net/

The Israeli government has become the latest national government to seek
open-source alternatives to Microsoft's productivity software, citing
cost as a major motivating factor. "The move with Microsoft was a purely
economic decision," says a Finance Ministry spokeswoman. "The Israeli
government will not be purchasing new products from Microsoft, but will

computers." The Finance Ministry has been working with Sun Microsystems
and IBM to create a Hebrew language version of OpenOffice software, an
open-source alternative to Microsoft Office. Some federal agencies in
France, China and Germany, as well as the city government in Munich,
have switched over to Linux-based servers and individual workstations.
Other governments exploring open source alternatives include those in
Britain, Brazil, Japan, South Korea, China and Russia. Governments
account for about 10% of global information technology spending,
according to IDC.  [AP/*USA Today*, 31 Dec 2003; NewsScan Daily, 31 Dec
2003]

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jan  6 19:34:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Jan  6 19:34:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Fedora or not?
In-Reply-To: <20040106230602.28329.81259.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040106230602.28329.81259.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040107005726.GA23025@gate.kl-ic.com>

Vincent Yau <v_yau3 at hotmail.com> writes:
> I have a Fedora question.
> 
> Between work and home, I have 2 RH 9 boxes and one Fedora boxes.
> RH 9 are running just fine and the Fedora box is meant to investigate
> how Fedora fairs.
> So far, the last 1.5 months that I have been using Fedora, I am less
> than happy.  Many applications crashed, including simple things such as 
> Mozilla.
> xine runs a lot better on RH 9 (no crashing) than Fedora...
> The Fedora box is a PIII 700 MHZ with 128 MB of RAM.
> 
> Perhaps it will just be a matter of time before Fedora is more stable.
> Should I bank on that?  Or should I go search for another distribution like
> Debian or Slackware?   Or is it perhaps that I configure something wrong
> on my  Fedora installation?
> 
> --Vincent

One thing needing improvement in Linux is hardware testing - it may well
be that the older PIII 700MHz hardware is starting to flake out.  Sadly,
most motherboards are not designed to last more than a couple of years
these days.  Or it may be that Fedora is indeed at fault, or there is
a configuration problem.  You can only tell by comparison testing the
different software with similar hardware.  Perhaps you still have the
old hard drive with RH9 on it so you can compare.

I have been running Fedora on my server since 2 days after the release,
(upgraded from RH9) and I am reasonably pleased with it.  I have seen
nothing screwy that was not screwy before. 

One thing that IS important is that much of Fedora is compiled with a
newer version of gcc.  This affects the versions of plugins that are
compatable for Mozilla, for example.  If you use the newer Mozilla
and the older Java J2RE, for example, it crashes.  I imagine  xine 
will have similar issues with plugins.

Fedora development will probably be a lot more agressive and bleeding
edge than Debian.   RedHat's strategy for Fedora is the same as for
their boxed distros, only more so:  as a testbed for apps that eventually
stabilize in the Enterprise products.  Think "late beta".  Fedora is
where RedHat pours their development effort;  after most of the bugs
go away they include the upgrades in Enterprise.  This does not mean
they are spreading bugs willy-nilly - they are interested in upgrading
Enterprise with stable code as fast as they can, and they would prefer
that stability develops as quickly as possible within Fedora.  After
all, bugs in Enterprise cost them a lot more money to deal with than
bugs in a distro they do not sell support for.  

As some have pointed out, they will focus more attention on the bugs
in Enterprise than on bugs in Fedora.  But that is because dealing
with a bug in a shipped product is a lot more expensive and time
consuming than dealing with a bug in development code, where they
are not expected to handhold zillions of customers through a code
update.  It is in their best interests to make sure that the code is
clean and widely tested before it makes it into Enterprise.  Thus,
they can get more leverage out of investing in Fedora development,
rather than mid-release Enterprise fixes and their attendant user
support costs.  As someone who wants more development and less
handholding (I have this group for the handholding :-) ) I agree
with their choice, even if it means that I suffer from more bugs.

If you want the latest stuff,  like a the latest version of Open Office
or the latest device drivers, then Fedora is your distro.  If you want
stable and free (as in beer), consider Debian stable.  If you want
stable and want to pay for support, consider SUSE.  I don't know about 
Slackware, though there are plenty here that are willing to educate me.

Personally, I like Fedora, don't like SUSE as much, and would consider
Debian if I had time to learn its peculiarities and had the time to
retune my system.  If some of my closed-source CAD tool vendors move
to a different distro (most support RH9 now) I will probably move to
that distro myself.  At the end of the day, I choose distros based on
what lets me get the job done.  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

come into my inbox, but I think the general attitude is that
people don't recognize how many people they actually help,
and how valuable their input is not only to the person on
the other end of the email, but also to the community.
Sure, somebody might answer a question or two on the mailing
list once in a while, but I don't think we as a community
realize how valuable the list, meetings and install fests
are and how big of a role they, as a whole, play in the
computing community in Portland Or.
We have a ton of experts (or at least experienced people, I
wouldn't want to insult you folks by putting you in the same
group as someone like Dvorak) in many fields - and can
educate people not only on the latest Linux distro, but on
everything from basic computer hardware and microcontrollers
to teaching kids to program and even helping people with
stuff that most of us despise - like using outlook and
exchange. We are not only experienced, but also hold jobs
(well, hopefully) in the IT sector and many of us are
involved in making purchases for your company's IT
departments.
Plug is probably the most active / biggest user group in
Portland (it might be the mac folks) and we are also free.
We give advice to anyone who asks and welcome the entire
community to come to our meetings. I'm not necessarily
looking for some text on a page but testimonials from folks
that we've helped out in the past and pics of mass installs
/ clinics. Numbers are great - too. I have no idea how many
emails have actually been posted to the list or how many
active emails, but I'm sure we are well into the thousands.

When you look at it, other community groups get things /
grants etc for much less - I'm not saying that we are
entitled to anything, but we should strive to make a more
people recognize the value of what we do. What goes around
comes around, but sometimes it needs a bit of help ;)

Anyways. . . . (/steps off soapbox)

Thanks in advance.
Karol.

According to Intel, "As a demonstration of
compatibility with gcc, Intel C++ 7.0 compilers for
Linux have successfully built and run the Linux
kernels, version 2.4.18, on IA-32 and Itanium
processors using a limited number of temporary source
patches." (I have an Athlon processor, however.)

Intel has benchmarking software available for those
wishing to compare their C++ compiler with gcc. In my
case, of course, it's a knockout, with gcc not working
at all. With the Intel compiler, the loop count in the
source test code has to be increased because it's so fast.

It's made available for "free" on about the same basis
as Kylix, for example. The source code is not
available, and you can't sell any binaries made with
the non-commercial version. (They DO provide a limited
amount of technical support for the free version,
although it's not as good as for paid users.)

Neutral reviewers think the Intel compiler is about
20% faster on the Pentium IV, more for some tasks. And
it may make more compact code.  You have to weigh this
against the time involved in learning to use a new
product.

Some time today I'm going to repeat the steps involved
in trying to install GCC once I discovered that it was
non-functioning. Perhaps others have had similar
problems, at least with rpm-based distributions.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jan  7 10:03:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] Intel C++, GCC compatibility
In-Reply-To: <20040107174845.45166.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com>

On Wed, 7 Jan 2004, Robert Kopp wrote:

> Neutral reviewers think the Intel compiler is about 20% faster on
> the Pentium IV, more for some tasks. And it may make more compact
> code.  You have to weigh this against the time involved in learning
> to use a new product.

Plus, all icc-produced binaries are linked against the Intel runtime
libraries, so you've either got to put their lib/ directory in your
/etc/ld.so.conf file or do something like

  -Wl,-R/opt/intel/compiler70/ia32/lib

with every build.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Wed Jan  7 14:03:02 2004
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Wed Jan  7 14:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] fanout and fanterm
In-Reply-To: <1073511327.27527.47.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <00c501c3d569$f379e440$6401a8c0@laptop>

I was screwing around on the sans site and came across a ssh webcast
that mentioned these two nifty little utilities. Check out the examples
on the link below. 

http://www.stearns.org/fanout/README.html
Fanout and fanterm are two utilities that allow you to run commands on
multiple machines. The difference is that fanout only runs
non-interactive commands (like dd, cat, adduser, uname -a, etc.) and
pipelines built of these. The output is collected into a single display
that can be viewed by less or redirected to a file.

Fanterm, on the other hand, allows you to run interactive text mode
commands on multiple machines at the same time. Your keystrokes are sent
to a shell or application running on each of the target systems. The
output from each system is shown in a seperate xterm.

cheers,
Sasha

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Wed Jan  7 14:25:03 2004
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed Jan  7 14:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux or Unix Classes(warning: VENTING)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401060633230.28382@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <3ffe0747.7653835@mail.aracnet.com> <20040106140004.GB31140@patch.com> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401060633230.28382@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <200401071424.11331.kyle@silverbeach.net>

Interesting ideas.

On Tuesday 06 January 2004 06:48, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> We've had this discussion before. Many disciplines have a three-way
> distinction between design, creation and maintenance:
>
>   Architect           - Contractor      - Handy man
>   Automotive designer - Plant Engineers - Mechanic
>   Computer Scientist  - Programmer      - Sysadmin
>
> Admittedly, the line is often blurry, but I'll stand by the
> distinctions nonetheless.

It's a very interesting one.

> The maintenance folks typically receive limited formal training; it's
> mostly on-the-job stuff. That's why it's not uncommon to find
> sysadmins with non-CS backgrounds (like me :-).

Hmm, I'd argue on the last line of the breakdown for computer folks.  
Scientists do research.  Materials scientists (such as chemists and some 
physicists and the few real materials scientics) do research on existing and 
new materials.  Eventually, their findings become part of the "playbook" for 
the designers/architects.  An aviation architect/designer works around the 
available materials.

Computer scientists seem to fall in a couple of categories:

1) they're really math people, i.e. crypto folks.

2) they're really working on engineering, i.e. the pattern design people, the 
XP people etc.

3) they're doing basic research, i.e. algorithms, new programming paradigms 
etc.  It is very rare that someone is actually doing something truly new 
these days.

I'd argue that the last line should read:

Software/systems Architect - Programmer - Sysadmin

Of course, since I have a degree in software design/architecture, I feel it is 
a meaningful distinction :-)  My professional experience tends to show that 
there is a difference as well, but that it is not well understood and not 
well acknowleged.  Programmers are just supposed to learn how to be 
designers/architects along the way.  That was true in some other disciplines 
too, but not for a long time in most cases.  This is not to downplay the 
value of a skilled person in the programming (or carpentry field) at all!    
The best architects/designers in most fields started on the creation end of 
things and ended up as architects.  Then, they understand the constraints of 
the discipline and can apply that to the design.

As a former carpenter (not for long), I was in awe of the guys (there were 
very few women in the field at the time) who really knew what they were 
doing.  The architect could give the barest sketch and they'd build a thing 
of beauty that would be on time, use the available materials and would be 
stable and safe.  And, there are certainly architects who will lay out 
buildings that are amazing to look at, but are nearly impossible to build or 
are just plain unsafe. Frank Lloyd Wright was known for doing bad roofs.  He 
even said so.  Many of his buildings need much more maintenance than they 
should due to leaks and bad detail design.

I find that the mindset is really what distinguishes people in the different 
aspects of the work.  Big picture people tend to gravitate more toward 
architecture.  This is, of course, a huge generalization :-)

Interesting approach of breaking stuff into design/creation/maintenance.  I 
like it!  I think it should be four-fold instead of three:  research/design/
creation/maintenance.  And, I think you are definitely right, a surprizing 
number of disciplines fit into those four slots very well.

Best,
Kyle

Uhhh... no.... take a look at it.

It's a full antivirus program (daemonized and non-daemonized scanning)
for Linux, primarily used to scan for nasties on things passing through
a server (file or mail, mainly?).

> if it will go into this?

I would hope not; these things aren't meant to protect your linux
systems, they're meant to protect Windows systems passing data through
linux systems.

In-Reply-To: <200401071424.11331.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <3ffe0747.7653835@mail.aracnet.com> <20040106140004.GB31140@patch.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401060633230.28382@pecos.madboa.com> <200401071424.11331.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401071449330.28382@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 7 Jan 2004, Kyle Hayes wrote:

> On Tuesday 06 January 2004 06:48, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > We've had this discussion before. Many disciplines have a
> > three-way distinction between design, creation and maintenance:
> >
> >   Architect           - Contractor      - Handy man
> >   Automotive designer - Plant Engineers - Mechanic
> >   Computer Scientist  - Programmer      - Sysadmin
>
> I'd argue that the last line should read:
>
> Software/systems Architect - Programmer - Sysadmin

Yeah, that's probably more accurate. I was trying to devise a
vocabulary for someone who does the computing equivalent of
traditional architecture. I didn't realize that I could just use
'architect' and have it fit. :-)

> Of course, since I have a degree in software design/architecture, I
> feel it is a meaningful distinction :-)  My professional experience
> tends to show that there is a difference as well, but that it is not
> well understood and not well acknowleged.  Programmers are just
> supposed to learn how to be designers/architects along the way.

*nod*

The three-way (or, in your thinking, four-way) is much more observable
in large, bureaucratic companies where there are Project Managers who
tend to deal with larger design issues and Programmers who are
primarily concerned with implementing their decisions.

> I find that the mindset is really what distinguishes people in the
> different aspects of the work.  Big picture people tend to gravitate
> more toward architecture.  This is, of course, a huge generalization
> :-)

There's still some truth in it. I think there are some other
dimensions as well:

* Designers are typically more likely to enjoy the rough and tumble of
  decision making in a social setting. Designers, at least in the
  corporate world, are far more likely to be meeting-bound than the
  creators or maintainers. There's good reason for that, of course:
  designers are the ones who typically have to negotiate with clients
  or upper management.

* Designers are more likely to have gotten an early start on their
  vocation, especially as regards formal training. That less true, I
  suppose, in a new field like CS than it is in traditional ones like
  architecture. There's always room for the guy who starts at the
  bottom, but they're the minority.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

 how do you check for specific features supported in the kernel?

 how do you check if they are already applied?
