On Thu, Jan 15, 2004 at 07:27:03PM -0800, David Mandel wrote:

> From: Marsee Henon <marsee at oreilly.com>
> To: plug at sco302.DavidMandel.com
> Subject: Newsletter from O'Reilly UG Program, January 14
---8<-----
> ***Review books are available
> Copies of our books are available for your members to review--
> send me an email and please include the book ISBN number on
> your request. Let me know if you need your book by a certain date.

Why doesn't PLUG start a computer books lending library for our
"members"? This shouldn't be too difficult to implement. I don't even
think it's an original idea.

Those of us that enjoy writing could select an O'Reilly book to review
on occasion. The reviewer's reward for his/her effort would be the use
of the book for a month (or six weeks, or whatever). Other members
interested in the book could sign onto a web-based waiting list. If
there are any members waiting for a particular book, a reasonable time
limit could be placed on a book's loan period. Said web app would also
be used to keep track of who's got what at the moment. There shouldn't
even be a need for any one person to store the books.

Yeah, I know... Just build and they will come. But before I bother to
build anything, I'm curious if there's any interest (especially from
potential reviewers).

BTW, who's in charge of the PLUG web site these days?


Paul




From cstevens at gencom.us  Thu Jan 15 20:52:01 2004
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Jan 15 20:52:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Mailbox Size Monitoring
Message-ID: <1074227171.3459.112.camel@sparticus>

All, 

I wish to warn my users when their mbox is nearly full. I found the
script below to be almost what I am looking for.

The trouble is that 1) I deliver the mail to the mbox file under the
user's home directory, not /var/mail/spool and 2) I don't have a
/etc/postfix/virtual file.

Would anyone quickly adapt the script below to work with my environment?

$25.00 bounty to the first person who does this successfully under the
terms of the GPL...

--------------- Begin Script -------------------------

#! /usr/bin/perl

# postmmon - POSTfix Mailbox MONitor
# Program to monitor Postfix mailbox sizes
#
#    Copyright (C) <2003>  <Ricardo Malafaia/Eduardo Mendes>

#   This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
#   it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
#   the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
#   (at your option) any later version.
#
#   This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
#   but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
#   MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See
#   the GNU General Public License for more details.
#
#   You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
#   along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
#   Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330, Boston, MA 
02111-1307  USA

#   More info: http://www.gnu.org or http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl.txt

# Program to monitor Postfix mailbox sizes
# NOTE: The program MUST run under CRON, otherwise it won't
# be all that helpful

# Nova Prestech.Net http://www.prestech.net
# Developed and coded by Ricardo Malafaia (ricardo at prestech.net)
# Original idea and blames by Eduardo Mendes (mendes at prestech.net) :)
# V 0.0.6 / 17/jul/2003 (gotta get the habit of using CVS...)

# Project's Homepage: http://www.prestech.net/projetos/postmmon

# Look out for the following parameters when configuring postmmon
# for your system.  Don't be afraid to change them, they are meant
# to.  However, just for precaution, get the habit of comenting
# the original lines rather than overwriting them.  It'll do you
# nothing but good... ;)

# Some configurable parameters and their meaning:

# $upperlimit   => mailbox size limit (read from postfix config file)

# $astepaway  => really close to a full mailbox

# $root     => administrative email account.  Will receive notifications
#              from the program about mailboxes going astray

# $warndayslim =>   limit of days between one warning and another.
#                   For users with mailboxes above 50% and below
$astepaway

# $alertdayslim => limit of days between one alert and another.
#                  For users with mailboxes getting close to the limit.
#                  Should be higher than 50%

# In order to test, once more i advise that you comment out
# the lines rather than overwriting them.

# Comment out the following line as well, during tests.

#use warning;


# A global structure for internal administrative accounting.
# It's in charge of keeping track of the number of days
# a user with mbox > 50% was last alerted
# DON'T TOUCH IT UNLESS YOU'RE REWRITING THE CODE!
my %accounts;

# Many initializations
#BEGIN {

$version="0.0.6";

print "<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<Initializing postmmon
v.$version>>>>>>>>>>>>>>\n\n";

# Some size units
$kb=1024;         #kilobyte
$mb=$kb*1024;        #megabyte

$uni=$kb;       #standard unit ($mb, default)

# Mailbox size limit
#$upperlimit=2*$kb;  # this line very obviously for test purposes only

# Automatically reads in the limit from Postfix config file
$upperlimit=`cat /etc/postfix/main.cf | grep -i mailbox_size_limit`;
# extract the numeric field from the line read
if ($upperlimit =~ /\d+/) { $upperlimit = int($&); }

# Just a step away to $upperlimit: time to alert the administrative
# account that some accounts are almost without space.  In the hopes
# that system administrators yells are more effective than irritating
# mail messages. :)
$astepaway = 6*$mb;

# 50% of mbox limit
$half=int($upperlimit/2);

# almost there...
$almosthere=int($upperlimit*85/100);

print "Mailboxes size limit: $upperlimit bytes\n";

# Number of times a day CRON (or any other scheduler) will run it:
$cron=3;

# Limit of days between one warning and another
# for a user with mbox size above $half
$warndayslim = 7; # 7 days

print "Limit of days between notifications for mailboxes above $half%:
$warndayslim\n";

# this will make sense during administrative accounting
# Yes, its ugly.  Ill try to fix that sometime...
$warndayslim = 7*$cron;

# Limit of days between one alert and another
# for users with mbox above $almosthere
$alertdayslim = 2;

print "Limit of days between notifications for mailboxes closer to the
limit ($almosthere bytes): $alertdayslim\n\n";
# sorry, again
$alertdayslim = 2*$cron;

# mail codes to be executed when mailbox above some limits
# mailto later
$code1='mail -s "Warning: Mailbox above $half%"';
$code2='mail -s "Alert: Mailbox getting closer to the limit."';

#    print "Utilized mail codes: \n";
#    print "$code1\n";
#    print "$code2\n\n";

# Mailbox spool directory
# Normally, /var/spool/mail
$dir="/var/spool/mail/";

print "Mailbox Spool: $dir\n";

# Get the names of users from the names of mailboxes
# from $dir through pipe
open(DIR, "ls -l $dir|");

# Name of the file connecting user names to email accounts
$usermail="/etc/postfix/virtual";

print "File holding username/mail accounts connections: $usermail\n";

# An internal usage file to store accountability information
# about mailboxes above $half
$accountbility='/etc/postfix/accountbility';

# the format of said file will be something in the lines of:
# email at domain    126047932    5
# emai2 at domain    32754235     2
# where:
# column 1 is the infringing user email whose mbox is above $half
# column 2 is the mailbox file size since the previous verification
(bytes)
# column 3 is the number of days (fixed unit, damn! thats why we had to
multiply by $cron, remember?) since the user was last warned or alerted

# If there already exists an accountability file, read entries from it
if (open(ACC, $accountbility)){
print "\nReading from previous administrative entries from
$accountbility\n";
  while(<ACC>){
    my($eml, $tm, $dias) = split(/\s+/);
    $accounts{$eml} = [ int($tm), int($dias) ];
print "Email: $eml, Tamanho: $accounts{$eml}->[0], Dias:
$accounts{$eml}->[1]\n";
  }
  close(ACC);
print "Closing administrative accountability file: $accountbility\n\n";
}


# The lines returned by $usermail through pipe will be
# decomposed in fields
# Three of these are:

our $owner=2; # the username of the mbox owner, while not getting used
our $mboxsize=4;  # the fourth field representing the mbox file size
our $mboxfname=8; # the eightieth field as returned by the pipe is the
mbox file name

# Read from pipe the email accounts from users
print "Reading the email accounts from $usermail\n";

open(ARQ, "cat $usermail | sort |");
while(<ARQ>){
    my($email, @user) = split(/[\s+|,+]+/);
    $email{$user[0]} = $email if $#user == 0; # if an user has more than
one email account, only the first one found will get notifications from
the other mboxes
    print "Email do usuario $user[0]: $email{$user[0]}\n" if $#user ==
0;
}
close ARQ; #print "All email accounts accounted\n\n";


# Text file containing the standard notification message
# to infringing mboxes.  Change it to the file you prefer
$msg="/etc/postfix/mboxfull";

# Administrative email account in charge of all others
$root='ricardo at iprestech.net';
#$root='your_email at your_domain';

print "<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<End of initialization section>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>\n\n";
#} # end of inits



# <<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Operational routine >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

print "Getting mailboxes from $dir\n";

while(<DIR>){

# A structure holding the line fields from the line read.
# Comment out, in case you use perl -an (which i was,
# but was getting problems with var scoping inside those
# BEGIN and END blocks)
local (@F) = split;

# Goes to next line, if mbox doesnt have a related email account.
# Mere precaution
next if not defined $email{$F[$mboxfname]};

print "Email being analized: $email{$F[$mboxfname]}\n";

# if mailbox between $half and $almosthere, duh
if ((int($F[$mboxsize]) >= $half) and (int($F[$mboxsize]) <
$almosthere)) {
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]} mailbox above half of mbox limit\n";

    $com=qq($code1 $email{$F[$mboxfname]} < $msg);

    # first, search $accountbility for any previous entry
    # in the accountbility file
print "Searching for any previous entry for $email{$F[$mboxfname]}. ";
  if (defined %accounts) {

    # if there already exists an entry for this email
    # and the mbox file size changed
    if ((defined $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}})
and ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[0] != $F[$mboxsize])){
      # if days gone since last notification > $warndayslim, send
another
      if ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] > $warndayslim){
`$com`;
$accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] = 0;
      } # else, update accountbility: one more day
      else { $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] += 1; }
    }

    # if there still isn't an entry for this user...
    else {
print "No previous entry found.  Generating one. \n";
      # Send notification...
      `$com`;
      # ... and updates accountbility
      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    }
  } # defined %accounts

  # accountbility still empty, let's fill it and send notification
  else {
print "Administrative accounts undefined: defining now: ";
    $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    `$com`;
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]}\t\t$F[$mboxsize]\t\t0\n";
  } # fim

}

# else, if larger than $almosthere and below the mbox limit
elsif ((int($F[$mboxsize]) >= $almosthere) and (int($F[$mboxsize]) <
$upperlimit)) {
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]} mailbox getting close to the limit\n";

    $com=qq($code2 $email{$F[$mboxfname]} < $msg);

print "Looking for any previous entry for $email{$F[$mboxfname]}. ";
  if (defined %accounts) {

    # if there already is an entry for that user and mbox file changed
    if ((defined $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}})
and ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[0] != $F[$mboxsize])){
      # if days gone by since last notification > $alertdayslim, send
another
      if ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] > $alertdayslim){
`$com`;
$accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] = 0;
      }
      #print "else, update accountbility";
      else { $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] += 1; }
    } #print "if there still isn't an entry for this user...";
    else {
print "No previous entry found.  Generating one. \n";
      # send notification...
      `$com`;
      # ... and update accountbility
      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    }
  }

  # accountbility still empty, let's fill it
  else {
print "Accounts undefined: defining now!\n";
    $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    `$com`;
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]}\t\t$F[$mboxsize]\t\t0";
  } # fim

}

# lastly, if mailbox is about to get to the limit,
# mail $root about it and expect for the best... :)
if (int($F[$mboxsize]) > ($upperlimit - $astepaway)) {
    $com=qq(mail -s "$email{$F[$mboxfname]} ($F[$mboxfname]) a step away
from mbox limit: Mailbox utilizing $F[$mboxsize] bytes!" $root < $msg);
    `$com`;
    if (not defined $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}){
print "Accounts undefined: defining now!\n";
      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0 ];
  }
} #elsif
} #while DIR
close DIR;


# Some last details

#END {
print "\n<<<<<<<<<<<Finalizing>>>>>>>>>>\n";
print "Updating the accountbility administrative file\n";

#print "Undefined administrative structure\n" if not defined %accounts;

  open(ACCOUNTS, ">$accountbility");
  foreach my $k (keys %accounts) {
    print ACCOUNTS "$k\t\t$accounts{$k}->[0]\t$accounts{$k}->[1]\n";
    print "$k\t\t$accounts{$k}->[0]\t$accounts{$k}->[1]\n";
  }
  close(ACCOUNTS);

print "Closing the accountbility administrative file\n";
print "<<<<<<<<<<<The End>>>>>>>>>>\n";
#}

---------------End Script--------------------------

Best,

Subject: [PLUG] Mailbox Size Monitoring
Message-ID: <1074228591.3465.129.camel@sparticus>

All, 

I wish to warn my users when their mbox is nearly full. I found the
script below to be almost what I am looking for.

The trouble is that 1) I deliver the mail to the mbox file under the
user's home directory, not /var/mail/spool and 2) I don't have a
/etc/postfix/virtual file.

Would anyone quickly adapt the script below to work with my environment?

$25.00 bounty to the first person who does this successfully under the
terms of the GPL...

    # and the mbox file size changed

another

print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]}\t\t$F[$mboxsize]\t\t0\n";
  } # fim

}

# else, if larger than $almosthere and below the mbox limit
elsif ((int($F[$mboxsize]) >= $almosthere) and (int($F[$mboxsize]) <

another

`$com`;
$accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] = 0;
      }
      #print "else, update accountbility";
      else { $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] += 1; }
    } #print "if there still isn't an entry for this user...";
    else {
print "No previous entry found.  Generating one. \n";
      # send notification...

      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];

  else {
print "Accounts undefined: defining now!\n";

print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]}\t\t$F[$mboxsize]\t\t0";

From cooper at cooper.stevenson.name  Thu Jan 15 21:17:02 2004
From: cooper at cooper.stevenson.name (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Jan 15 21:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Mailbox Size Monitoring
Message-ID: <1074228673.3459.131.camel@sparticus>

All, 

I wish to warn my users when their mbox is nearly full. I found the
script below to be almost what I am looking for.

The trouble is that 1) I deliver the mail to the mbox file under the
user's home directory, not /var/mail/spool and 2) I don't have a
/etc/postfix/virtual file.

Would anyone quickly adapt the script below to work with my environment?

$25.00 bounty to the first person who does this successfully under the
terms of the GPL...

#------------------------- Begin Script --------------------------
#! /usr/bin/perl

# postmmon - POSTfix Mailbox MONitor
# Program to monitor Postfix mailbox sizes
#
#    Copyright (C) <2003>  <Ricardo Malafaia/Eduardo Mendes>

#   This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
#   it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
#   the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
#   (at your option) any later version.
#
#   This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
#   but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
#   MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See
#   the GNU General Public License for more details.
#
#   You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
#   along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
#   Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330, Boston, MA 
02111-1307  USA

#   More info: http://www.gnu.org or http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl.txt

# Program to monitor Postfix mailbox sizes
# NOTE: The program MUST run under CRON, otherwise it won't
# be all that helpful

# Nova Prestech.Net http://www.prestech.net
# Developed and coded by Ricardo Malafaia (ricardo at prestech.net)
# Original idea and blames by Eduardo Mendes (mendes at prestech.net) :)
# V 0.0.6 / 17/jul/2003 (gotta get the habit of using CVS...)

# Project's Homepage: http://www.prestech.net/projetos/postmmon

# Look out for the following parameters when configuring postmmon
# for your system.  Don't be afraid to change them, they are meant
# to.  However, just for precaution, get the habit of comenting
# the original lines rather than overwriting them.  It'll do you
# nothing but good... ;)

# Some configurable parameters and their meaning:

# $upperlimit   => mailbox size limit (read from postfix config file)

# $astepaway  => really close to a full mailbox

# $root     => administrative email account.  Will receive notifications
#              from the program about mailboxes going astray

# $warndayslim =>   limit of days between one warning and another.
#                   For users with mailboxes above 50% and below
$astepaway

# $alertdayslim => limit of days between one alert and another.
#                  For users with mailboxes getting close to the limit.
#                  Should be higher than 50%

# In order to test, once more i advise that you comment out
# the lines rather than overwriting them.

# Comment out the following line as well, during tests.

#use warning;


# A global structure for internal administrative accounting.
# It's in charge of keeping track of the number of days
# a user with mbox > 50% was last alerted
# DON'T TOUCH IT UNLESS YOU'RE REWRITING THE CODE!
my %accounts;

# Many initializations
#BEGIN {

$version="0.0.6";

print "<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<Initializing postmmon
v.$version>>>>>>>>>>>>>>\n\n";

# Some size units
$kb=1024;         #kilobyte
$mb=$kb*1024;        #megabyte

$uni=$kb;       #standard unit ($mb, default)

# Mailbox size limit
#$upperlimit=2*$kb;  # this line very obviously for test purposes only

# Automatically reads in the limit from Postfix config file
$upperlimit=`cat /etc/postfix/main.cf | grep -i mailbox_size_limit`;
# extract the numeric field from the line read
if ($upperlimit =~ /\d+/) { $upperlimit = int($&); }

# Just a step away to $upperlimit: time to alert the administrative
# account that some accounts are almost without space.  In the hopes
# that system administrators yells are more effective than irritating
# mail messages. :)
$astepaway = 6*$mb;

# 50% of mbox limit
$half=int($upperlimit/2);

# almost there...
$almosthere=int($upperlimit*85/100);

print "Mailboxes size limit: $upperlimit bytes\n";

# Number of times a day CRON (or any other scheduler) will run it:
$cron=3;

# Limit of days between one warning and another
# for a user with mbox size above $half
$warndayslim = 7; # 7 days

print "Limit of days between notifications for mailboxes above $half%:
$warndayslim\n";

# this will make sense during administrative accounting
# Yes, its ugly.  Ill try to fix that sometime...
$warndayslim = 7*$cron;

# Limit of days between one alert and another
# for users with mbox above $almosthere
$alertdayslim = 2;

print "Limit of days between notifications for mailboxes closer to the
limit ($almosthere bytes): $alertdayslim\n\n";
# sorry, again
$alertdayslim = 2*$cron;

# mail codes to be executed when mailbox above some limits
# mailto later
$code1='mail -s "Warning: Mailbox above $half%"';
$code2='mail -s "Alert: Mailbox getting closer to the limit."';

#    print "Utilized mail codes: \n";
#    print "$code1\n";
#    print "$code2\n\n";

# Mailbox spool directory
# Normally, /var/spool/mail
$dir="/var/spool/mail/";

print "Mailbox Spool: $dir\n";

# Get the names of users from the names of mailboxes
# from $dir through pipe
open(DIR, "ls -l $dir|");

# Name of the file connecting user names to email accounts
$usermail="/etc/postfix/virtual";

print "File holding username/mail accounts connections: $usermail\n";

# An internal usage file to store accountability information
# about mailboxes above $half
$accountbility='/etc/postfix/accountbility';

# the format of said file will be something in the lines of:
# email at domain    126047932    5
# emai2 at domain    32754235     2
# where:
# column 1 is the infringing user email whose mbox is above $half
# column 2 is the mailbox file size since the previous verification
(bytes)
# column 3 is the number of days (fixed unit, damn! thats why we had to
multiply by $cron, remember?) since the user was last warned or alerted

# If there already exists an accountability file, read entries from it
if (open(ACC, $accountbility)){
print "\nReading from previous administrative entries from
$accountbility\n";
  while(<ACC>){
    my($eml, $tm, $dias) = split(/\s+/);
    $accounts{$eml} = [ int($tm), int($dias) ];
print "Email: $eml, Tamanho: $accounts{$eml}->[0], Dias:
$accounts{$eml}->[1]\n";
  }
  close(ACC);
print "Closing administrative accountability file: $accountbility\n\n";
}


# The lines returned by $usermail through pipe will be
# decomposed in fields
# Three of these are:

our $owner=2; # the username of the mbox owner, while not getting used
our $mboxsize=4;  # the fourth field representing the mbox file size
our $mboxfname=8; # the eightieth field as returned by the pipe is the
mbox file name

# Read from pipe the email accounts from users
print "Reading the email accounts from $usermail\n";

open(ARQ, "cat $usermail | sort |");
while(<ARQ>){
    my($email, @user) = split(/[\s+|,+]+/);
    $email{$user[0]} = $email if $#user == 0; # if an user has more than
one email account, only the first one found will get notifications from
the other mboxes
    print "Email do usuario $user[0]: $email{$user[0]}\n" if $#user ==
0;
}
close ARQ; #print "All email accounts accounted\n\n";


# Text file containing the standard notification message
# to infringing mboxes.  Change it to the file you prefer
$msg="/etc/postfix/mboxfull";

# Administrative email account in charge of all others
$root='ricardo at iprestech.net';
#$root='your_email at your_domain';

print "<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<End of initialization section>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>\n\n";
#} # end of inits



# <<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Operational routine >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

print "Getting mailboxes from $dir\n";

while(<DIR>){

# A structure holding the line fields from the line read.
# Comment out, in case you use perl -an (which i was,
# but was getting problems with var scoping inside those
# BEGIN and END blocks)
local (@F) = split;

# Goes to next line, if mbox doesnt have a related email account.
# Mere precaution
next if not defined $email{$F[$mboxfname]};

print "Email being analized: $email{$F[$mboxfname]}\n";

# if mailbox between $half and $almosthere, duh
if ((int($F[$mboxsize]) >= $half) and (int($F[$mboxsize]) <
$almosthere)) {
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]} mailbox above half of mbox limit\n";

    $com=qq($code1 $email{$F[$mboxfname]} < $msg);

    # first, search $accountbility for any previous entry
    # in the accountbility file
print "Searching for any previous entry for $email{$F[$mboxfname]}. ";
  if (defined %accounts) {

    # if there already exists an entry for this email
    # and the mbox file size changed
    if ((defined $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}})
and ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[0] != $F[$mboxsize])){
      # if days gone since last notification > $warndayslim, send
another
      if ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] > $warndayslim){
`$com`;
$accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] = 0;
      } # else, update accountbility: one more day
      else { $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] += 1; }
    }

    # if there still isn't an entry for this user...
    else {
print "No previous entry found.  Generating one. \n";
      # Send notification...
      `$com`;
      # ... and updates accountbility
      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    }
  } # defined %accounts

  # accountbility still empty, let's fill it and send notification
  else {
print "Administrative accounts undefined: defining now: ";
    $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    `$com`;
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]}\t\t$F[$mboxsize]\t\t0\n";
  } # fim

}

# else, if larger than $almosthere and below the mbox limit
elsif ((int($F[$mboxsize]) >= $almosthere) and (int($F[$mboxsize]) <
$upperlimit)) {
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]} mailbox getting close to the limit\n";

    $com=qq($code2 $email{$F[$mboxfname]} < $msg);

print "Looking for any previous entry for $email{$F[$mboxfname]}. ";
  if (defined %accounts) {

    # if there already is an entry for that user and mbox file changed
    if ((defined $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}})
and ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[0] != $F[$mboxsize])){
      # if days gone by since last notification > $alertdayslim, send
another
      if ($accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] > $alertdayslim){
`$com`;
$accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] = 0;
      }
      #print "else, update accountbility";
      else { $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}->[1] += 1; }
    } #print "if there still isn't an entry for this user...";
    else {
print "No previous entry found.  Generating one. \n";
      # send notification...
      `$com`;
      # ... and update accountbility
      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    }
  }

  # accountbility still empty, let's fill it
  else {
print "Accounts undefined: defining now!\n";
    $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0];
    `$com`;
print "$email{$F[$mboxfname]}\t\t$F[$mboxsize]\t\t0";
  } # fim

}

# lastly, if mailbox is about to get to the limit,
# mail $root about it and expect for the best... :)
if (int($F[$mboxsize]) > ($upperlimit - $astepaway)) {
    $com=qq(mail -s "$email{$F[$mboxfname]} ($F[$mboxfname]) a step away
from mbox limit: Mailbox utilizing $F[$mboxsize] bytes!" $root < $msg);
    `$com`;
    if (not defined $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}}){
print "Accounts undefined: defining now!\n";
      $accounts{$email{$F[$mboxfname]}} = [ $F[$mboxsize], 0 ];
  }
} #elsif
} #while DIR
close DIR;


# Some last details

#END {
print "\n<<<<<<<<<<<Finalizing>>>>>>>>>>\n";
print "Updating the accountbility administrative file\n";

#print "Undefined administrative structure\n" if not defined %accounts;

  open(ACCOUNTS, ">$accountbility");
  foreach my $k (keys %accounts) {
    print ACCOUNTS "$k\t\t$accounts{$k}->[0]\t$accounts{$k}->[1]\n";
    print "$k\t\t$accounts{$k}->[0]\t$accounts{$k}->[1]\n";
  }
  close(ACCOUNTS);

print "Closing the accountbility administrative file\n";
print "<<<<<<<<<<<The End>>>>>>>>>>\n";
#}

#---------------------- End Script --------------------------

Best,

Oh, forget postfix. The script need only look at the size of ~mbox for
each user on the system, that's all. In shell it would something like:

ls /home
while read user
do
  mailbox_size = "ls -l $user/mbox | awk '{ print $3 }'"
  if $mailbox_size > upper_limit
  then
    mail -s $user "Your email is almost full!"
  fi
done

Something along those lines.

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Jan 16 00:48:02 2004
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri Jan 16 00:48:02 2004
Subject: no easy answer (was Re: [PLUG] MySQL v. PostgreSQL -- perhaps an easy answer)
In-Reply-To: <20040116030909.A307D15805D@kanga.canids>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0401141806440.27271-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <200401151651.04486.kyle@silverbeach.net> <20040116030909.A307D15805D@kanga.canids>
Message-ID: <200401160047.38155.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Thursday 15 January 2004 19:09, Felix Lee wrote:
> Kyle Hayes <kyle at silverbeach.net>:
> > >    http://developer.postgresql.org/docs/postgres/backup-file.html
> >
> > The first sentence of the point above on the page you point to seems to
> > contradict what you say.  It seems very clear that Postgres does
> > buffering and what is on disk isn't coherent until it is shut down.  Is
> > there another way to read this point?  This is exactly the doc I was
> > thinking of when I wrote the paragraph you quoted above.  The authors
> > conveniently emphasize the word "must" in the first sentence of point 1
> > just to make it even more clear.
>
> I think it's bad editing in the doc.
>
> the caveats seem to apply to simplistic backup methods like the
> example above it:
>
>     tar -cf backup.tar /usr/local/pgsql/data

That's very far from how I read this.  I asked about it on the Postgres 
list... hmm, two years ago?  Maybe less.  The answer I got was that Postgres 
did not have a consistent disk image until it was down.  You could recover 
from what was on disk (otherwise recovering from crashes would be a bit 
difficult, no?) but you'd lose data doing the recovery potentially.  That 
potential makes this method an emergency backup method at best.

If you can lose data, Murphy will work overtime to ensure that you do lose 
data :-(

> which runs into obvious problems because the tar isn't an atomic
> read.

Exactly.  Difficult to have an atomic read of any size on Linux unless you can 
stop changes to the filesystem (i.e. snapshots).  LVM does it at the block 
device level.

> a later paragraph says:
>
>    An alternative file-system backup approach is to make a
>    "consistent snapshot" of the data directory, if the file
>    system supports that functionality.  Such a snapshot will save
>    the database files in a state where the database server was
>    not properly shut down; therefore, when you start the database
>    server on this backed up directory, it will think the server
>    had crashed and replay the WAL log.  This is not a problem,
>    just be aware of it.
>
> this paragraph seems to me independent of the caveats before it,
> and it implies that the data on the disk is coherent even if the
> database isn't shut down.

I do not read this as you do.  This conflicts with point 1 in the page.  I 
don't see how you could both do a snapshot without problems and not do a 
snapshot without problems.  One is correct.  Someone went to the effort of 
making the two point list and emphasizing "must".  Seems clear to me.

Note that I have asked on the Postgres list in the past and been told that 
snapshots of any kind while the DB is running are bad juju.  That conforms to 
what is written in point one quite well.  If anything is poorly edited on the 
page, it appears to be the stuff lower down.

I've asked more than once in this little flame-fest whether this behavior had 
changed and I've heard resounding silence.  I take that as a "no".

> about the caveats, I'm not really sure what this sentence is
> talking about:
>
>     Half-way measures such as disallowing all connections will
>     not work as there is always some buffering going on.
>
> the word "buffering" is not attached to anything in particular.
> it's not clear to me where this buffering is and why it would
> cause problems.  If the buffering were in disk commits, then the
> database wouldn't be ACID (which I suppose might be true, but at
> the moment it seems unlikely to me, since the rest of the world
> says that postgres is ACID.)

I think you're trying to read entirely too much into this.  Most of this page 
seems quite clear.  I cannot see why the document writers would go out of 
their way to make things confusing.  Postgres docs are pretty good in 
general.  It, and the support on the mailing lists, are some of Postgres' 
real strengths.

> it seems more likely to me that the writer is talking about
> something like: incoming transactions might be buffered
> somewhere, and there's no simple way to say "don't allow new
> connections, and also make sure all existing connections are
> either finished or totally quiet", other than shutting down the
> database.  any non-atomic backup method like "tar" will run into
> problems if a transaction happens while the backup is running.

Buffering can mean several things, but given all the other stuff on the page, 
it seems fairly clear to me that they are talking about buffering of internal 
DB state of some sort that is written to disk when the DB is brought down 
cleanly.

> this sentence is also kind of odd:
>
>     For this reason it is also not advisable to trust file
>     systems that claim to support "consistent snapshots".
>
> the strange thing is the phrasing "claim to support".

LVM certainly had teething pains some time ago.  Other systems such as some 
NAS systems didn't have perfect snapshots and thus filesystem mutations could 
slip in while they were occuring.   Makes sense to me.

Note that a lot of people would assume that because the filesystem supported 
"consistent snapshots" that they could take a snapshot of the running DB and 
have it be consistent.  If some state is only up to date in memory buffers, 
then this is an incorrect assumption and the warning makes a lot of sense.

I think you are trying to read entirely too much into this.  Would you risk 
your data on those assumptions and guesses?  I wouldn't.  If Postgres does 
provide for consistent snapshots in some manner and you still make back ups 
by taking down the DB and copying the data, you haven't risked anything.  If 
it doesn't and you think it does, you're screwed the first time you need that 
backup.  

Best,
Kyle




From felix.1 at canids.net  Fri Jan 16 02:21:01 2004
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri Jan 16 02:21:01 2004
Subject: no easy answer (was Re: [PLUG] MySQL v. PostgreSQL -- perhaps an easy answer) 
In-Reply-To: <200401160047.38155.kyle@silverbeach.net> 
    on Fri, 16 Jan 2004 00:47:38 PST
    from Kyle Hayes <kyle@silverbeach.net> 
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0401141806440.27271-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <200401151651.04486.kyle@silverbeach.net> <20040116030909.A307D15805D@kanga.canids>  <200401160047.38155.kyle@silverbeach.net> 
Message-ID: <20040116102010.0788B15805D@kanga.canids>

Kyle Hayes <kyle at silverbeach.net>:
> That's very far from how I read this.  I asked about it on the Postgres
> list... hmm, two years ago?  Maybe less.  The answer I got was that Postgres
> did not have a consistent disk image until it was down.  You could recover
> from what was on disk (otherwise recovering from crashes would be a bit
> difficult, no?) but you'd lose data doing the recovery potentially.  That
> potential makes this method an emergency backup method at best.

maybe this was before postgres implemented write-ahead logging?
it looks like WAL was added in 7.1, released 2001-04-13.

"before WAL, PostgreSQL was never able to guarantee consistency
in the case of a crash."
    http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/wal.html

with WAL (and fsync on), I think it should always be possible to
recover all committed transactions from a snapshot (or crash).
if not, it's a bug.
--



From felix.1 at canids.net  Fri Jan 16 03:08:01 2004
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri Jan 16 03:08:01 2004
Subject: no easy answer (was Re: [PLUG] MySQL v. PostgreSQL -- perhaps an easy answer) 
In-Reply-To: <200401160047.38155.kyle@silverbeach.net> 
    on Fri, 16 Jan 2004 00:47:38 PST
    from Kyle Hayes <kyle@silverbeach.net> 
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0401141806440.27271-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <200401151651.04486.kyle@silverbeach.net> <20040116030909.A307D15805D@kanga.canids>  <200401160047.38155.kyle@silverbeach.net> 
Message-ID: <20040116110724.61ED315805D@kanga.canids>

> >    An alternative file-system backup approach is to make a
> >    "consistent snapshot" of the data directory, if the file
> >    system supports that functionality.  Such a snapshot will save
> >    the database files in a state where the database server was
> >    not properly shut down; therefore, when you start the database
> >    server on this backed up directory, it will think the server
> >    had crashed and replay the WAL log.  This is not a problem,
> >    just be aware of it.

this paragraph in the documentation was added in the postgres 7.4
release, without editing the rest of that page to be consistent
with that statement.  the CVS revision date is November 2003.  I
don't know why this would be special to 7.4.  it seems to me this
should be true for any release with WAL, except for bugs.

the release notes for 7.4 lists one WAL-related bug
    Make B-tree indexes fully WAL-safe (Tom)

    In prior releases, under certain rare cases, a server crash
    could cause B-tree indexes to become corrupt. This release
    removes those last few rare cases.

anyway, this is as far as I'm going to dig into this.  anyone who
cares will have to do more research themselves, heh.

(I don't have any reason to choose a database right now, and
there's not much value in finding more information until I do,
since technology is changing rapidly, and I suspect any
impressions I form now will be obsolete in a year.  this was
partly an exercise in information gathering, and also to get more
familiar with database issues.)
--

  Every now and then I have need to send an e-mail to a list of recipients

  Is there a way of inserting a bulk list of names without entering each one

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Jan 16 09:30:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jan 16 09:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] pine: inserting a list of addresses
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401160909580.25586@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401160909580.25586@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401160922050.26523@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 16 Jan 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Every now and then I have need to send an e-mail to a list of
> recipients who are not in my addressbook. I discovered that I cannot
> use the file-insert (ctrl-k r) when the cursor is on the address
> field. Nor can I block the list of names displayed in a virtual
> terminal and copy them to the To: field in pine.
>
>   Is there a way of inserting a bulk list of names without entering
> each one individually?

Yeah, but it's a bit tricky. Put your address list (each address
followed by a comma) in an editor configured *not* to do line
wrapping. Then get all the addresses on one (long) line. Cut and paste
that into pine. Works for me, using vi and xterm.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From mikeraz at patch.com  Fri Jan 16 11:04:02 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Fri Jan 16 11:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] rebuilding kernel with NGROUPS_MAX changed
Message-ID: <20040116190232.GA23506@patch.com>

	Background
There is a problem if one if using SAMBA/Winbind and a user attempting to login to a system with their authentication from a NT Domain.  If the user belongs to more than NGROUPS_MAX (defined in limits.h) their authentication will fail.

See http://lists.samba.org/archive/samba-technical/2003-March/027605.html for a reference. 

In Linux this number is 32.  We have many users that belong is 50 or more groups. (Don't ask, I didn't design the model.)

In a followup message to the one linked above it is stated that some utilities in userland are compiled with NGROUPS_MAX.  So if one wants to fix the problem, a change to the kernel source and a recompile can lead to problems down the road.  However, this was in the context of Solaris.

	Question
Is this a problem in Linux land?  Or can we indeed change NGROUPS_MAX, recompile the kernel and be good to go?  What "shoot self in foot" potentials are we looking at?

                              January 17, 2004
                                1PM - 4PM

                          Riverdale High School
                        9727 SW Terwilliger Blvd,
                           Portland, Oregon 
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * T-1 (or better :) Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials

   dhaskell at acm.org

I like smoothwall quite a bit ( http://smoothwall.org). I've been using 
it for a while now and its really easy to set up as well as having more 
advanced features than floppyfw (for example). Its managed via a web 
interface after the initial install and has an IDS, squid, a ipsec vpn, 
dyndns and a bunch of other stuff.

It doesn't fit number  3,  as it runs off a hard drive, but an old P75 
more than handles all of my home traffic easily. I imagine he could get 
the hardware he needed for less than $40.

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jan 16 14:32:01 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jan 16 14:32:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Let's Help Frank Vaughan

On Fri, 2004-01-16 at 13:48, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 16 Jan 2004, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> 
> > The good suggestion for him
> >
> > 1. would have a web interface, preferably one that could identify with
> >    reasonable certainty his internal and external network interfaces
> >
> > 2. would have a set of canned solutions that are easily understood by
> >    someone who's a well informed user but not a systems or network
> >    admin
> >
> > 3. could be run from a CD or floppy so it wouldn't invade his
> >    hard drive until he was really ready
> 
>   In my ignorance that limits the choices to Caldera and Knoppix.

Gibraltar is designed to be a full-featured firewall run from CD, the
configuration can be saved to floppy, usb storage device, or harddrive,
the drawback is that the web interface part can't be accessed until you
buy a key code for 990 euro's (which seems kind of steep to me,
considering that you also have to provide the hardware).  There is a  30
day trial license for testing it out though.  The rest of the
distribution is all GPL (Debian based, of course), so the system can be
downloaded and used for no cost, but the setup will have to be done
without the web interface.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Fri, 2004-01-16 at 14:15, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Fri, 16 Jan 2004, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> > Anyone know of a super easy firewall distro to recommend?  I'm thinking
> > boot from CD with nice friendly web gui.  Less scary than floppyfw.
> 
> There's nothing less scary than floppyfw.
> 
> You edit a text file.  Add your network information, tell it whether you
> want DHCP or not, and go.


I run floppyfw and I am confused by the setup.  It is hard to tweak (it
must be done on another machine) and mistakes can foobar the whole
system.

> No web services to exploit, no nothin'.

I like for it for this reason, but I consider it trickier than a web
interface.

If it just came at you with DHCP Outside, NAT inside and that's it, then
it works great (I think that's it default).

But if that is the case, a < $100 router can do it as well (like most
wireless APs).  And I could argue that's not a firewall, that's a NAT
device.

BTW I have never, ever, seen a firewall under windows that is easy to
understand.

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Jan 16 18:05:03 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Let's Help Frank Vaughan

On Friday 16 January 2004 17:36, Anderson, Rob (Global Trade) wrote:
> http://www.freesco.org
>
> LRP (http://www.linuxrouter.org/) was also a pretty cool distro before it
> died.

I use Smoothwall too and have for several years.  It is quite easy to set up, 
but there are parts that are not trivial for someone to figure out (RED? 
GREEN? What's that?).  The docs are pretty good.

The web interface in Smoothwall is trivial to use for everything I've needed 
to do.  That doesn't mean that it is comprehensive, just that for my limited 
needs, it was just fine.

However, Smoothwall has the most... interesting... mailing list.  One of the 
main authors seems to take great pleasure in flaming newbies on the list.  I 
haven't seen flame fests go from mild taunts to all out nuclear attack in 
such a short time.  Smoothwall is made by a commercial company who would 
really rather that you bought their for-pay version.

IPCop is a fork of Smoothwall and seems to have a much nicer set of mailing 
lists and supportive folks.  Several of the people I got using Smoothwall 
have since started using IPCop.

http://www.ipcop.org/

Best,
Kyle

Well, yeah, I could just SSH in after the OS is loaded.  But what I want
to be able to do instead is watch the hardware boot messages, install new
OS's, enter the BIOS, etc., without having to worry about having a spare
monitor/keyboard with me.  So this device would basically take everything
from the remote box and pipe it over USB to my laptop.  Then I would be
able to run some software that would open a window and let me manipulate
the remote system.

similar -- enough that should one group decide to embrace a
controversial cause (say, official affiliation with NAMBLA --

From ian at znark.com  Sat Jan 17 17:17:02 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sat Jan 17 17:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] NTP oddity
In-Reply-To: <200401161002.40490.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <200401161002.40490.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <4009DE33.1090906@znark.com>

Kyle Hayes wrote:
> I run ntpdate once a night (I should set up xntp or something) to keep my 
> clock in sync.  For the past three years, the usual correction each night was 
> on the order of 30-50ms.  In the past few weeks, this has gone to 14 
> _seconds_.  Is this a sign that my trusty P-II 400 is starting to show signs 
> of age (i.e. the battery is dying)?  Anyone have a clue?
> 

One thing to check is that the hardware clock is being written to after 
ntpdate runs or when the system shuts down.  It is possible that your 
hardware clock has been drifting slowly and is now 14 sec off, ntpdate 
sets the software clock, but the result never gets written back.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

> > correction each night was on the order of 30-50ms.  In the past few
> > weeks, this has gone to 14 _seconds_.  Is this a sign that my trusty
> > P-II 400 is starting to show signs of age (i.e. the battery is
> > dying)?  Anyone have a clue?
> > 
> 
> One thing to check is that the hardware clock is being written to
> after ntpdate runs or when the system shuts down.  It is possible that
> your hardware clock has been drifting slowly and is now 14 sec off,
> ntpdate sets the software clock, but the result never gets written
> back.

#!/bin/sh

NTP_BIN=/usr/sbin/ntpdate
HWCLOCK_BIN=/sbin/hwclock
WC_BIN=/usr/bin/wc

CLOCK_SOURCE_LIST="128.193.4.20 128.193.128.29 128.118.46.3"
COUNT=`echo $CLOCK_SOURCE_LIST | $WC_BIN -w`
let x=1
for SERVER in $CLOCK_SOURCE_LIST ; do
  $NTP_BIN -u $SERVER  >/dev/null  2>&1
  if [ $? = 0 ] ; then
    $HWCLOCK_BIN --systohc  >/dev/null  2>&1
    if [ $? = 0 ] ; then
      exit 0
    fi
  fi
  if [ $x = $COUNT ] ; then
    echo "Clock not set by $0" 
  fi
  let x++
done
exit 0

On Sat, 2004-01-17 at 19:27, Russell Evans wrote:

> I'm having trouble understanding what the issue is, so help me out. Is
> it the name PDXLUG that is the issue?  Is PDXLUG not different enough
> from PLUG? Is it the domains, pdxlinux.org and pdxlug.org are to close?
> What "name" is it that that the people posting want changed? 

The actual names, if you expand the acronyms, are:
PDXLUG - Portland Linux Users Group
PLUG - Portland Linux/UNIX Group, although we were "officially" the
Portland Linux Users Group until some time in the late 1990's, when
(IIRC) I requested we change the name to make it clear that discussion
about other UNIX systems was welcome.  Since "LUG" generally is used to
indicate Linux User Groups, most people assumed that PLUG stood for
Portland Linux Users Group, so we've also by default had that as an
alias.

Wil

>>>>> "J" == J Black <plug201 at jblack.org> writes:

J> Thanks for clarifying (or declarifying) that, Wil!  I thought we
J> _were_ the Portland Linux Users Group!  

We were and are known as the Portland Linux Users[1] Group, we are
just _also_ known as the Portland Linux/Unix Group.  According to what
those at the meeting where this was discussed[2] have told me, the
Linux/Unix name was _added_.  It was agreed that both names would
continue to be acceptable.  Some considerable time later, usage on the
website and materials began emphasizing the "Linux/Unix" name, but
that emphasis does not represent "abandonment" of the "Linux Users"
name, which is still being used by you (Jesse) and many others.

[1] "User" and "Users" are both in use.

[2]  circa September 1998

More or less. Perhaps it would be better summed up as an issue of
intentionally causing confusion and "pissing in the pool".

Forking the group is one thing. There are no shortage of LUGs in
the Portland area, BizNix & BLUE for example, there is no harm in
having yet another. PLUG itself has off-shoots with their own
meetings/lists, Advanced Topics and PLUG for Education for example.

Adding "Portland Linux/UNIX Group" was intended to make PLUG
more inclusive, rather than exclusive, after all. The more the
merrier.

But forking the group in such a way that was intended to cause as
much harm as possible to the original group (using the same name,
having meetings on the same day/time, posting a steady stream of
insults) has rubbed a few people the wrong way.

I, for one, am a bit confused why some of the PDXLUG organizers
feel the need to be so bitter and work so hard at generating bad
blood.

>If one where to do a grep on the web site, would Portland Linux User
>Group be found anywhere but in the mailing lists? 

A Google search for Portland Linux User Group is enlightening.

There is much more to PLUG than the web site. You will note, for
example, that the PLUG Linux Clinic has always used "Portland Linux
User's Group (PLUG)".  The PLUG clinics have been in continuous
operation since 1995. 

-Eric




From russell-evans at qwest.net  Sun Jan 18 11:04:02 2004
From: russell-evans at qwest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun Jan 18 11:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] NTP oddity
In-Reply-To: <200401181011.05276.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <200401161002.40490.kyle@silverbeach.net>
	<4009DE33.1090906@znark.com>
	<200401181011.05276.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <20040118110328.6a7d4193.russell-evans@qwest.net>

On Sun, 18 Jan 2004 10:11:05 -0800
"Kyle Hayes" <kyle at silverbeach.net> wrote:

> On Saturday 17 January 2004 17:15, Ian Burrell wrote:
> > Kyle Hayes wrote:
> > > [sudden change in ntpdate offset]
> >
> > One thing to check is that the hardware clock is being written to
> > after ntpdate runs or when the system shuts down.  It is possible
> > that your hardware clock has been drifting slowly and is now 14 sec
> > off, ntpdate sets the software clock, but the result never gets
> > written back.
> 
> I have hwclock --utc --systohc in the crontab with ntpdate.
> 

So going back and looking at the original script, I don't need the COUNT
stuff.

Thank you
Russell


#!/bin/sh

NTP_BIN=/usr/sbin/ntpdate
HWCLOCK_BIN=/sbin/hwclock

CLOCK_SOURCE_LIST="128.193.4.20 128.193.128.29 128.118.46.3"

for SERVER in $CLOCK_SOURCE_LIST ; do
  $NTP_BIN -u $SERVER  >/dev/null  2>&1
  if [ $? = 0 ] ; then
    $HWCLOCK_BIN --systohc  >/dev/null  2>&1
    if [ $? = 0 ] ; then
      exit 0
    fi
  fi
  # If HWCLOCK_BIN was called the script would have already exited 
  echo "Clock not set by $0" 
  done
exit 1

Message-ID: <20040118154145.256d7b15.russell-evans@qwest.net>

On Sun, 18 Jan 2004 13:02:45 -0800 (PST)
"Steven Raymond" <stever at woo-hoo.com> wrote:

> Perhaps a dumb question, but why doesn't everyone run ntpd instead? 
> It keeps your clock accruate all the time, not just when a cron job
> runs, and uses something like only 1 udp packet per minute to do so. 
> A google for"public ntp servers" turns up hundreds of stratum 2
> devices you can get time from.
> Is the a compelling reason not to use ntpd?

I think I wrote the script when xntp had a security problem, I just
never got rid of it. The issue then was most ntpd servers shut down for
a while while they waited a fix for the issue. I had a long list of
servers and only needed one to work, but didn't want to have to
keep track of what was up or down. I also think I had issues a boot if I
couldn't find a server. I can't remember the exact issue, could have
been error between keyboard and chair. 

Chrony sounds like clockspeed so maybe it is trying to solve the same
issue clockspeed is. 

http://cr.yp.to/proto/utctai.html
What's the problem?
For many years, the UNIX localtime() time-display routine didn't support
leap seconds. In effect it treated TAI as UTC. Its displays slipped 1
second away from the correct local time as each leap second passed.
Nobody cared; clocks weren't set that accurately anyway.

Unfortunately, xntpd, a program that synchronizes clocks using the
Network Time Protocol, pandered to those broken localtime() libraries,
at the expense of reliability. Watch how the xntpd time scale increases
as a leap second occurs:

1997-06-30 23:59:59.7 UTC -> 867715199.7 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:59.8 UTC -> 867715199.8 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:59.9 UTC -> 867715199.9 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.0 UTC -> 867715200.0 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.1 UTC -> 867715200.1 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.2 UTC -> 867715200.2 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.3 UTC -> 867715200.3 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.4 UTC -> 867715200.4 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.5 UTC -> 867715200.5 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.6 UTC -> 867715200.6 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.7 UTC -> 867715200.7 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.8 UTC -> 867715200.8 xntpd
1997-06-30 23:59:60.9 UTC -> 867715200.9 xntpd
1997-07-01 00:00:00.0 UTC -> 867715200.0 xntpd
1997-07-01 00:00:00.1 UTC -> 867715200.1 xntpd
1997-07-01 00:00:00.2 UTC -> 867715200.2 xntpd

The xntpd time scale repeats itself! It cannot be reliably converted to
UTC.

By resetting the clock at each leap second, xntpd extracts a correct UTC
display (except, of course, during leap seconds) from the broken
localtime() libraries. Meanwhile, it produces incorrect results for
applications that add and subtract real times.

Thank you
Russell

From danh at fork.com  Mon Jan 19 00:07:01 2004
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)

Actually it's a really poor analogy for several reasons:

1) We have never entirely "put down" the name.

2) The fact that we have a claim to the name is not the primary issue. The
primary issue is the confusion PDXLUG created when they chose names that
were so similar to ours.

3) If you're going to talk about children, then you're talking to the
wrong group. We have repeatedly tried adult discourse with PDXLUG only to
get adolescent responses like "you suck" and "don't get your panties in a
bunch".

> For those of us that were here last January when the split happened we 
> know that it wasn't a pretty sight. The folks that split off did so with 
> a bitter taste in their mouths, and for good reason (I can't blame 
> anyone for wanting to distance themselves from that level of hostility).

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jan 19 03:17:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Jan 19 03:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MySQL -> PostgreSQL migration
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401181826131.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401181826131.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401190307550.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 18 Jan 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Can someone point me to a primer that might tell me how to move an
> application from MySQL to Postgres?
[snip]
> Anyway, I'm hoping to convert a fairly major application for the benefit
> of all, so any help y'all could give me would help everyone.

After a night's research, I think I've come to believe that the
application SHOULDN'T just be moved to PostgreSQL.  Most of the things
done on the front-end of the application are more appropriately handled as
database functions.

Basically, moving to a higher-functioning database would give you none of
the benefits of having a higher-functioning database system and all the
negative impact of a bloated, front-heavy application.

With a bit of research, I'm pretty well sold on these ideas of views,
triggers, aggregates, and co. and will move to a more robust system.

As I see it, you can make the database itself so robust that the front-end
doesn't do much work at all except put a pretty face on the database.
Putting the logic in the front-end doesn't make sense because it limits
the number of ways you can access your data.

Forgive me if this is extremely obvious to everyone else, but it's
something that just didn't seem to come up in all the MySQL v. PostgreSQL
discussion.  (Right now, the ONLY thing I prefer about MySQL is the
license.)

So I'm a little bit stuck.  I like ARIAS because it seems to have
everything I want in terms of an external feature set (inventory, ledger,
payroll, etc.) but it's all in PHP when much of what is done could be in
the database itself (and, therefore, easier to update with another
front-end, should I choose that route).

SQL-Ledger seems to put the database in the appropriate relationship to
the application, but doesn't support payroll and doesn't have some of the
nicer interface features of ARIAS.  I'm sure you're all (well, those few
who are actually reading my ramblings) thinking that I should just add the
interface bits myself, but, to be perfectly honest, web interface
development is one of my least favorite things to do.

I don't mean to just blog at you guys... but if anybody really likes their
accounting/inventory system, I'd like to know about it.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

PLUG has always been more of an Open Source group than a Linux group
with members using various BSDs and proprietary Unix OSs as well as

reality. Thus, PLUG's official name was changed from the Portland Linux
Users Group to the Portland Linux/Unix Group.

our web page. Even if some of us didn't drop the name, the organization
did.

From robby at planetargon.com  Mon Jan 19 10:07:02 2004
From: robby at planetargon.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Mon Jan 19 10:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MySQL -> PostgreSQL migration
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401190307550.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401181826131.17290@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401190307550.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <400C1C91.50303@planetargon.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Sun, 18 Jan 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
>>Can someone point me to a primer that might tell me how to move an
>>application from MySQL to Postgres?
> 
> [snip]
> 
>>Anyway, I'm hoping to convert a fairly major application for the benefit
>>of all, so any help y'all could give me would help everyone.
> 
> 
> After a night's research, I think I've come to believe that the
> application SHOULDN'T just be moved to PostgreSQL.  Most of the things
> done on the front-end of the application are more appropriately handled as
> database functions.
> 

If you're going to move to a DB like PostgreSQL, than it is definitely 
worthwhile to do the homework and learn how to utilize the many features 
of the system. Put the business logic, rules, etc in the database rather 
than in your application. When you have a solid database design, it 
makes the application building process so much easier and lowers the 
risk of errors in your app affecting your data. If it's managed in the 
DB (as it typically should be in a business environment) it would be 
un-wise to do it elsewhere.

> As I see it, you can make the database itself so robust that the front-end
> doesn't do much work at all except put a pretty face on the database.
> Putting the logic in the front-end doesn't make sense because it limits
> the number of ways you can access your data.

exactly. It's much easier to rebuild a front end when most of the logic 
is in the DB.

cheers,

~Robby

From freyley at gmx.net  Mon Jan 19 12:08:02 2004
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Mon Jan 19 12:08:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] [Fwd: Re: Regarding consistency of data on disk]
Message-ID: <1074542826.1873.26.camel@localhost>

There was some discussion regarding the state of the disk under
Postgres, and consistency, and snapshots. I wanted more information. I
asked. Here is PostgreSQL developer Tom Lane's take on it.

Jeff

-----Forwarded Message-----
From: Tom Lane <tgl at sss.pgh.pa.us>
To: Jeff Schwaber <freyley at gmx.net>
Subject: Re: Regarding consistency of data on disk
Date: Mon, 19 Jan 2004 14:52:23 -0500

> This doc seems to say you can't guarantee consistent state of the data
> on the disk at any time:

No, that's not what it says.  The point is that typical backup tools
copy one file at a time and so do not generate a consistent snapshot
if the fileset is changing during the backup run.  This isn't so
critical for normal backup purposes, but it's absolutely fatal if you
want a consistent database ...

If you have a filesystem that can freeze an instantaneous snapshot of
the volume the PG database is on, it works to copy from the snapshot.
Some people do their backups that way, and it seems to work in practice
as well as in theory.  But without snapshot capability at the filesystem
level, you gotta shut down the database while you copy the files.

If you have your database spread across multiple logical volumes it
gets trickier --- you need to be able to obtain *simultaneous* frozen
snapshots of all the volumes.  I am not sure that the tools available
for LVM, for example, can really handle this.

> The other option is to do pg_dump, but that takes up a lot more
> space because it's SQL and not pure data.

Is this measured fact, or just your guess?  Commonly the pg_dump output
is much smaller than the disk footprint, since it doesn't have to include
index contents, unused space, WAL log, etc.  As a quick example, the
regression database occupies about 32MB on disk on my machine, and the
total size of $PGDATA including WAL log, template0 and template1 is
nearly 100MB.  But pg_dump output is only 4.3MB.

			regards, tom lane

The XFS filesystem supports taking snapshots on live filesystems.  IIRC, 
it uses the journal to cache data so even while the snapshot is being 
taken the filesystem isn't locked (up to some limit obviously).

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Mon Jan 19 13:35:45 2004
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Mon Jan 19 13:35:45 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG vs. PLUG
In-Reply-To: <20040119195601.28376.52107.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040119195601.28376.52107.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1074547946.23956.72.camel@ida.dylanreinhardt.com>

On Mon, 19 Jan 2004 11:41:55, Dan Haskell <danh at fork.com> wrote:
> Dave Mandel has a DBA on it with the State of Oregon. 

True enough:
http://sos-venus.sos.state.or.us:8080/beri_prod/pkg_web_name_srch_inq.do_name_srch?p_regist_nbr=160120-98

It's not clear that DBA registration has any applicability here, as Dave
is not doing business as "PORTLAND LINUX USERS GROUP" and neither is
PDXLUG.  For sake of argument, though, let's say it matters.

Dave registered this name in July 2003.  That stands in contrast to his
registration of "PORTLAND LINUX/UNIX GROUP" in November 1999.  The
ownership of "PORTLAND LINUX USERS GROUP" was not a subject of state
concern prior to 7/03... when PDXLUG was formed.

The value of trade names is directly related to their specificity and
uniqueness.  Registering a name *after* its usage has become confused
confers little of value on the registration holder.  Furthermore, the
fact that PLUG has taken no action to enforce its "right" seriously
undermines any case PLUG may think it has.  It's way too late now.

Be aware as well that there are significant hazards to playing the game
of legal entitlement with names.  After all, the name "PLUG" is a
registered DBA in Oregon and I sort of doubt you've reached an equitable
licensing arrangement with the registrant.  :-)

FWIW,

Dylan

On Mon, 19 Jan 2004, Cliff Wells wrote:
> Brian Beattie wrote:
> >I have seen nothing I would consider slander, a difference of opinion
> >maybe.
> >
> "a totalitarian regime"

This isn't slander.  It's an accurate description of the organization.

It is true that the organization has a few keyholders who make binding
decisions for the organization and must be swayed in order to make
anything happen under that organization's banner.  Their control is total.

If you don't LIKE those words and you think that's a BAD THING, that's a
different story.

It ain't slander if it's true.

> But it's funny, because PLUG is rarely, if ever, discussed on PDXLUG
> (unless this argument happens to somehow spill over from this group).

Anybody that disagrees with the keyholders has been silenced.  Of course
there's no discussion.

> If the intent was to "take over" or "usurp" PLUG's apparently desirable
> position (/me muffles laughter) you would think that the discussions
> there would focus on that.

Absolutely not.  Talking about such a thing openly would make the ploy
obvious and defeat the purpose entirely.

But I don't think anybody's claiming that wsa ever the intent.  The intent
is to disrupt, not usurp.

Anyway, from where I'm sitting, PDXLUG appears to be the vanity project of
a few people who think things are best run from the top down.  Anarchism
is anathema to people like that and so anything that makes it harder for
the community to function without authoritarian controls is good for them.
Bringing this down to a legal argument where the state must intervene is
supportive of the authoritarian philosophy and furthers their cause even
if the final decision of the state is rendered in favor of the open
community.

J.

buy a copy of hte magazine (approx. $3.00 US) but since it is an e-mag (in
PDF) I had a copy in just a few minutes.
   I'm going to work on migrating the php/MySQL users to php/PostgreSQL.  
This got a pretty good review on one of the PostgreSQL lists.  My 
understanding was it was good for non-php people moving to PostgreSQL 
also.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Jan 19 16:07:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Jan 19 16:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] vi mail processing
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401161457480.12525@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401161457480.12525@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20040120000706.GB27885@bavariati.org>

On Fri, Jan 16, 2004 at 02:59:11PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> OK, so a while back (maybe two years ago?) we had a conversation here
> about using vi to edit mail (like with mutt or something).  Some folks
> posted their own clever ways of handling quoting and line wrapping.

Well, having learnt vim in order to impress my girlfriend, I put this in
my ~/.pinerc: editor="vim +%d \"+set textwidth=70\" %s"
(Don't forget enable-alternate-editor, maybe even -implicitly.)

Later, a discussion in Linux-Elitists made me try Mutt again.  It was
uncomfortable to switch, but it defaulted to using vim, so no conf
changes were necessary.

Said discussion included a config to make Mutt work almost like Pine,
but I preferred to learn it as-is, especially in light of the *other*
discussion of how frustrating it was to use a UI that almost, but not
quite mimics another program's UI.

In vim, I use the 'gq' command to reformat text. It handles indent/quote
characters quite nicely.  Others include 'd]]' (delete from here to the
end of file), 'D' (delete to the end of line), 'J' (stick the next line
on the end of this one), '.' (repeat the last command), 'u' (undo) and
'~' (swap upper/lower case; perfect for those cAPS-lOCK accidents.)

From srau at rauhaus.org  Mon Jan 19 16:40:05 2004
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Mon Jan 19 16:40:05 2004
Subject: [PLUG] vi mail processing
In-Reply-To: <20040120000706.GB27885@bavariati.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401161457480.12525@shaft.bitmine.net> <20040120000706.GB27885@bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <20040120003907.GD31045@rauhaus.org>

* Aaron Burt <aaron at speakeasy.org> [040119 16:07]:
> 
> In vim, I use the 'gq' command to reformat text. It handles indent/quote
> characters quite nicely.  Others include 'd]]' (delete from here to the
> end of file), 'D' (delete to the end of line),

You probably are already aware, but you can use 'd' plus any movement
command: 'dG' deletes to the end of the buffer, 'd$' deletes to the end of
the line, 'd/foo' deletes up to the next occurance of 'foo', etc.

I also get a lot of use out of ':%! whatever', which means filter the
entire buffer through 'whatever', with whatever being a shell command or
even pipeline.  I often do something like so:

:%!awk '/.... 0087/ {print $2}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -n

I would guess that could all be accomplished within vim, but it works,
and I know how to do it.

--Stafford



From bspears at easystreet.com  Mon Jan 19 16:40:26 2004
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Mon Jan 19 16:40:26 2004
Subject: [PLUG] FYI: Burning CD-R's from iso's
Message-ID: <1074559355.15158.1330.camel@apollo.spears.org>

I posted earlier about dd hanging when trying to copy from /dev/cdrom to
foobar.iso where the contents of /dev/cdrom are a CD-R burned from say,
yarrow-i386-disc1.iso. (The same happened with cat /dev/cdrom and md5sum
/dev/cdrom.  I  found that the CD-R was actually OK by mounting the
original iso and diff-ing it with /mnt/cdrom. It also checked out OK in
the Fedora install.

I tried dd with a RH 8 disk and it worked fine. So there was some
difference between manufactured CD-ROM's and CD-R's made from iso's.

I found that adding the disk at once option(-dao) to cdrecord produces a
CD-R that works properly with dd, etc.

#cdrecord -v speed=24 dev=0,0,0 -dao -data /tmp/yarrow-i386-disc1.iso
-- 
Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com>

> >/dev/cdrom.  I  found that the CD-R was actually OK by mounting the
> >original iso and diff-ing it with /mnt/cdrom. It also checked out OK in
> >the Fedora install.
> >
> >I tried dd with a RH 8 disk and it worked fine. So there was some
> >difference between manufactured CD-ROM's and CD-R's made from iso's.
> >
> >I found that adding the disk at once option(-dao) to cdrecord produces a
> >CD-R that works properly with dd, etc.
> >
> >#cdrecord -v speed=24 dev=0,0,0 -dao -data /tmp/yarrow-i386-disc1.iso

> >

> to dd:  readcd.  If you have cdrecord installed then you should have

For nearly five weeks now I've been receiving virus-spams from Road
Runner's IP 24.208.135.215 -- about 1-2 per day. I've politely reported
them -- headers and all -- to abuse at rr.com, and always received the
worthless auto-response from them. Apparently, mail to their abuse team
just gets ignored because I'm still getting a steady light drizzle of
klez.

What's the point of trying to stop spam and viruses by reporting them when 
the ISP responsible doesn't care? What does one do to get their attention? 
Does anyone have a procmail recipe to relay these spams to Glenn A. Britt 
(head of Road Runner) or someone at Time Warner (Road Runner owners) who 
cares? If you can't stop spam going through the proper channels, then that 
bodes badly for the future of this problem. Are spammers flooding the 
abuse sites to render them useless? Should I accuse rr.com of harboring 
domestic terrorism? What to do?

I can easily send these to dev/null, but that's so unsatisfying,
especially knowing that the spammer is free to run amok. It's frustrating!

- Bill Thoen

On Mon, Jan 19, 2004 at 03:23:51PM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> I hereby invoke the Law of Godwin.

http://ursine.ca/jargon/html/G/Godwins-Law.html

Godwin's Law states, "As a Usenet discussion grows longer, the
probability of a comparison involving Nazis or Hitler approaches one."

This brings up several issues with your response:

1) Godwin's Law is not invocable because it states a constant:  It
   always applies, even if the topic is not about Nazis, Hitler, World
   War II, the 1930s and 1940s, the Holocaust, or anything else
   remotely related to those subjects.

2) It is possible you mis-learned Godwin's Law states that a
   conversation automatically stops when one of the topics above is
   mentioned.  This is not the case.

3) Even if Godwin's Law did state that the conversation stops,
   Googling for nazi|hitler godwin group:<insert any active group
   here> should give you plenty of examples that this is not the case.
   Leave off the group argument to get as many examples as there are
   dollars added to the national debt by Republican politics within my
   lifetime.  In fact, the opposite is true: Deliberately trying to
   trigger Godwin's Law usually causes the odds of the thread ending
   anytime soon to approach zero.

- --

If a ping on localhost is returning anything other than 127.0.0.1 (as 
the OP claimed) then he's been compromised.   I would never trust that 
machine again.

Follow the earlier advice and reinstall.   Actually, if you're running 
an older version of your distro, then you could probably get away with 
an upgrade to a newer version and see the problem go away since most 
likely the upgrade will replace every binary on your system.   Then you 
just have to check the stuff under /usr/local (and other places that 
aren't typically used by the distro) for lingering binaries/scripts and 
replace/remove them.

> nitpicky, useless, whiny posters who insist on beating irrelevant
> subjects to death.  The noise ratio here is unbelievable. I subscribe
> to a lot of lists, and this one has the largest garbage-to-good stuff

someone tried to steal the name from you. What would you do?

Dan

You've done most of the bad-mouthing yourself.  The statement of

feel their grievance is unwarranted, you should strike it down on merit
rather than insulting the person making the grievance.

> You obviously have a clever, if cowardly, way of trying to turn the
> bitch-fest I've witnessed on this list sound like some free-speech

What was gossip?  Your "it" is ambiguous.

Again, which "it"?
