> doesn't mean I have to respect the person utilizing that freedom.

You don't HAVE to respect people, but I believe it's the decent and
honorable thing to do.

> Try to answer honestly for once:  why is it that when someone (okay, me)
> engages in a discussion about the merits of PostgreSQL vs Access (this
> was several months ago)  a bunch of people scream "OT" and that's *them*
> exercising their freedom of speech, but when *I*, by myself, decide to
> protest their actions, I'm not exercising mine?  Why aren't you
> defending me?

I don't recall the discussion, actually.  But it sounds like you were
really scorned and are quite bitter about it.  If it means anything, I'm
sorry you were treated in a way that made you feel so bad.

Exactly how did you protest the actions of those that screamed "OT"?

The nice thing about PLUG is that everyone and their mother can scream
"OT" and you can go right on discussing it.

> Oh wait:  because it isn't in your best interest.  Duh.

If you think you know the answer, don't ask.  If you don't know the
answer, wait until you get an answer before you dismiss the question.

> >>If I didn't personally know several PDXLUG members and *know* for a
> >>*fact* what their intentions are, then I might not be so defensive about
> >>the mudslinging that several members on this list seem so fond of.
> >
> >Do share.  But you're 0-1 on your guesses up to this point.  It's not
> >about having a list where OT discussion is safe, that's been proven.
> >
> Actually, if you knew anything at all, you would know that most PDXLUG
> conversation doesn't take place on the mailing list.  The mailing list
> is mostly for technical advice and announcements.  That is why going OT
> is discouraged there.

So what does it mean to be a "member" of PDXLUG if subscription to the
mailing list is not a requirement?  Is anyone participating in ANY PDXLUG
condoned event a "member"?  The word "membership" has no meaning if there
isn't some discrete method for telling what is and is not a member.  What
defines the set?

With PLUG, we say that anybody who subscribes to the mailing list is a
member.  It's pretty cut and dry that way.  That, combined with the
unmoderated nature of the list, what makes the organization totally open.

> But then, speaking from ignorance appears to be the one skill you've
> developed to it's fullest potential.

That's 3.

> >>Frankly, knowing Robby quite well (and having a fairly high opinion of
> >>him as a person) and having seen how he has tried to quell this
> >>argument and appease people I've become quite aggravated with the
> >>unreasonableness of many people here.
> >
> >I think perhaps you're letting your prejudices get in the way.  Robby may
> >well be a nice guy, but he has done very little to appease anybody.  He's
> >rigidly stood his ground while others were in distress.
> >
> Distress?   _Distress_???? Are you serious?   One day,  I hope to laugh
> directly in your face for that remark.   You must really have no idea
> what that word means.

I know what the word means.  Some folks felt that they and their work is
suffering from the confusion of the groups and are attempting to take that
grievance up wherever they can to get it resolved and remove the strain.

> >>Robby made an upfront offer to share resources from PDXLUG.
> >
> >Um, no.  Robby pointed out that a resource existed.  It was already open
> >to anybody's participation.  He didn't make any offer.
> >
> Whatever.

Why are you so negative about this?  We are adults here.  You can concede
the point without being dismissive.

> If PDXLUG were really the exclusive group you claim, then those
> resources certainly wouldn't be open to anybody's participation.
> Please be consistent.

There's nothing inconsistent here.

A totalitarian regime can run public services.  Look at the Catholic
Church.

> >>I'm sorry that people who aren't involved had to endure this thread,
> >>but frankly, if public proclamations are going to be made then the
> >>responses should be public as well.
> >
> >I'm perfectly content to see the public responses.  It's shown at least
> >one person that PDXLUG is supports a dictatorship and is non-responsive
> >to public concerns.  (See plug-talk for details.)
> >
> >Discourse is good.  Flinging insults is not.
> >
> If you try to use unsupported claims to support your argument, I'm going
> to call you on it.

By all means.  Which claim needs more support?

> It's easy to fling barbs at others and then retreat behind the "ad
> hominem attack!" shield, but frankly, the harshest words have come
> directly from users in this group, mostly towards people who aren't here
> defending themselves.

It's not a shield.  It's a reason to dismiss your comments.  You don't
really take up the substance of the argument, but, rather, say nasty
things about the people with whom you disagree.  Respond to the substance
with measured, intelligent rebuttal and real steps can be made toward
understanding.

And by the way, ALL of the words in this thread, not just the "harshest",
came directly from users in this group.  We're ALL users in this group.
Every single participant in this discussion is a user in this group.  You
write as though you are somehow not one of those people, but that's
absurd.

> I find it pathetic when people start a fight they're afraid to finish.

Forgive me for the assumption, but this appears to be some kind of defense
mechanism that allows you to feel victorious when, in fact, people just
got sick of going around in circles with your insults and dodges.  When a
point is made to which you have no response, you fling out an insult.
When a response is made to one of your arguments to which you have no
reasonable rebuttal, you dismiss it with "whatever" or the like.

Listen to the arguments and respond to the arguments (and not the people
making the arguments) and see if we don't all find a more pleasant
discussion that might actually improve the state of things.

J.

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 19 20:23:02 2004
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Mon Jan 19 20:23:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Hacked?
In-Reply-To: <20040120030817.GA26114@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <001401c3df0d$01750140$6401a8c0@laptop>

It seems clear that something has happened. Whether or not the 'hack'
has permanently damaged the system and poses a risk to (your) other
computers, I can't say for sure. The question I would recommend you ask
yourself is, are you willing/able to take the chance? 

If the answer is yes, then maybe this is an opportunity to poke around,
learn computer forensics, and have fun. 

If the answer is no, the only way to fix this for sure is to wipe the
system and reinstall. Really. Honestly. Truly. 

For tips on forensics/incident handling, check out:
http://www.sans.org/rr/catindex.php?cat_id=27

Hope that helps,
sasha

From steve at wirex.net  Mon Jan 19 22:55:02 2004
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Mon Jan 19 22:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] vi mail processing
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401191740450.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401161457480.12525@shaft.bitmine.net> <20040120000706.GB27885@bavariati.org> <20040120003907.GD31045@rauhaus.org> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401191740450.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20040120065755.GA2567@wirex.net>

On Mon, Jan 19, 2004 at 05:42:32PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> However, didn't somebody have a more complex reply-quoting scheme that
> involved piping the mail through some external utility?

I think you are referring to something like the following, which I have
in my .vimrc (the latter being taken from Wil Cooley):

  map = {!}fmt -c -u
}
  map + {!}fmt -c -u -p"> "
}

(Note that the '
' is an actual carriage return, ascii 0x0d. I forget
the mechanism for entering it into vi.)

The former will pipe a paragraph through fmt(1), the latter will do
the same, but will only apply to (singlely) quoted text. I find fmt(1)
does a better job of justifying text than vim's internal mechanisms,
though it has some quirks of its own. Also, using fmt(1) like so should
be vi-clone agnostic.

With vim handling email, the other thing I did was modify
~/.vim/after/syntax/mail.vim to modify the quoted text color scheme
to match the scheme I use in mutt (thanks to Seth Arnold for the file
location).

One of the things I miss from yon olden dayes, when nearly everybody's
exposure to a *nix system was an account on a time-sharing system rather
than their own personal desktop machine, was being able to poke around
in other people's homedirs and look at the nifty things they would do
with their dot-files.

On Mon, 2004-01-19 at 23:11, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> On Mon, Jan 19, 2004 at 11:05:51PM -0800, Paul Johnson wrote:
> > Perhaps it would be best if you showed some restraint and stopped
> > posting while angry?  Feel free to write it all out, just hit abort
> > instead of send.  Trust me, it gets it out of your system.
> 
> Yeah, I've written huge diatribes and got to the end of reviewing it
> and sending it, and saying to myself: "Screw it. I don't care that
> much." Feels oh so much better about 10 minutes later.

If it were simply about the name of a user group, I'd concur.  However,
many of the comments have been personal or general attacks on the
integrity of PDXLUG members, at least some of whom are personal friends
of mine.  I can certainly appreciate that there may have been (and
continue to be) personal frictions between certain individuals.  What I
don't appreciate is having people whom I like and respect publicly
attacked for no good reason.  PDXLUG, like PLUG, is composed of
/individuals/, many of whom might say or do things that do not reflect
the ideas or mores of the whole.  I certainly doubt all the members of
PDXLUG would condone my course of action.  I do not pretend to represent
PDXLUG, and it would be nice if the people who are claiming to represent
PLUG would acknowledge the same.

I have certainly fed into this today (intentionally, to be quite frank),
but the "discussion" and mudslinging started long before my first post. 
I am aware that it is a vocal minority who are attempting to speak on
behalf of the whole of PLUG and certainly acknowledge that there are
many decent and intelligent people on this list who have better things
to do with their time than follow this pointless flamewar.  My intention
here today was to highlight exactly how /annoying/ this entire argument
has been for quite some time and how it feels to have a personal attack
leveled at you on a public list.  I'll be quite honest though: if it
comes up again, I'll be right back.  There are apparently people who
cannot see how their constant harassment and bitching can be annoying to
others.  Maybe now that will be a little more clear.  If not, well, I
suppose I will be happy to fling insults and rebuttals as long as
necessary until perhaps they get bored enough to let it go or at least
keep it off of public forums.

Regards,
Cliff

               -The Smiths

The new year brings us another Advanced Topics session and it brings it
to us this Wednesday!

Cooper Stevenson will talk about implementing Anti-Virus systems on
Linux at Jax 826 SW 2nd Ave, Portland OR. Jax is on the MAX Line, next
to Bally's Fitness. 

His implementation is a filter built out of Open Source tools that
include Postfix, SpamAssassin, Amavisd, and clamav. He reports that the
client he developed this for is very happy with this solution. (This
presentation was delayed from November due to the weather.) 

The meeting time will be 7:00pm, and will run until we either run out of
questions or answers or beer.

Happy hour prices are available on food for the first hour of the
meeting.  (But you have to buy a drink to get the happy hour prices.)

As I understand it, O'Reilly was contacted quite early by PLUG and was

O'Reilly assumed it was the same organization and so, understandably, made
no follow-up with the other contact.

> The simple fact is, I have tried to argue a single point all day: there
> is no compelling reason why PDXLUG should change their name.  If you
> won't address that then I'm not really interested in exchanging
> pleasantries with you.

Let's say you wanted to talk to someone about PLUG.  This person is
uninitiated into the deeper idiosynchracies of the community and is really
only superficially interested.  You don't want to overwhelm them with a
list of every group in town and, in fact, are pretty sure that PLUG is
exactly what they want in an organization.  If you tell them about PLUG,
they are going to assume one expansion of the acronym (an acronym with
more than one expansion, sort of like the double-recursive acronym of
HURD, but different -- most importantly, an INTENTIONALLY AMBIGUOUS
acronym), then you point them to the website at www.pdxlinux.org.  You
have to be clear about that because it's NOT pdxlug.org and just plain
"Portland Linux User Group" is not distinctive enough (since two groups go
by that name.  It then becomes necessary to explain the distinction to
prevent confusion.  From outside, this looks very confusing and makes it
appear as though there is some holy war that doesn't really exist.
There's actually no beef at all between the organizations, just a
ridiculous confusion that simply isn't getting addressed.  We all end up
looking way too divided and petty to be serious at all and the person
doesn't ever follow up.

I've sat by cringing while this actually happened.

> > I thought maybe you couldn't see that you were being abusive and
> > insulting and ignoring the real arguments.  I thought I could help you
> > to see that. Help sometimes seems condescending to people who don't
> > know how to take it or don't see that they need it.
>

There's no "No" about it.  You're agreeing with my last sentence.  You see
it as condescending because you do not believe you need help.

Does everything have to be a contradiction with you; even the agreements?

> Just in case you missed it the first couple of times: please explain why
> PDXLUG should change their name.

Done.  But note that I'm not saying they MUST do it or anything.  I'm just
telling you that the situation is confusing to outsiders and makes things
very difficult for casual communication with the unindoctrinated.  The
polite thing to do would be to use an unambiguously distinct moniker.

> For extra points, do it without accusing PDXLUG of being fascists or
> bringing in bizarre conspiracy theories about how they are trying to
> disrupt PLUG.  Just lay out how damage is being done to PLUG (aside from

But since you bring it up, I will note that I'm still totally unclear as
to why you would bother creating a distinct organization when PLUG is
accepting of and open to all types of gatherings and mailing lists unless
you are seeking power or causing other kinds of trouble.

From linuxfan at corneliusconcepts.com  Tue Jan 20 03:37:02 2004
From: linuxfan at corneliusconcepts.com (David Cornelius)
Date: Tue Jan 20 03:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] All I need to know I learned from PLUG vs. PLUG
Message-ID: <E1AiuAt-0003bR-He@jerry.networkeleven.net>

For the longest flame war[1] I've ever read, I actually learned several
things and would like to thank everyone for this increased knowledge. It
took 2 hours to scan through them all, but here are some insights for those
that don't want to take the time...

* "PLUG" is the officially-recorded NAME in Oregon for a computer user group
in the Portland area that focuses on various flavors of Linux and Unix and
related open source software.

* "Portland Linux/Unix Group" is the DESCRIPTION for PLUG, which was changed
from "Portland Linux Users Group" to better described what the group focuses
on.  It is understandable to me that changing the actual name (i.e. to
"PLUUG") would create unnecessary paperwork and possibly cost money.
Besides, the new description fits the original acronym while better
describing what the group is for and everyone knows who "PLUG" is.

* "PDXLUG" is the name of another, less formal, recently-formed computer
user group in the Portland, Oregon area that also focuses on Linux and
related software.  (I had no idea this group existed before this
"discussion" arose.)

* "A Portland Linux Users Group" is the DESCRIPTION for PDXLUG.

* Godwin's Law[2] can be handy, but must be applied carefully.  However, the
passionate people involved in the thread for which it is applied, can be so
overheated they ignore those trying to put out the fire.

* I really hope I never meet certain individuals when they're behind the
wheel of a large, motorized vehicle and get a bad case of road rage, because
they just never, ever stop!


And one thing that could've been applied here that I learned years ago when
my ex-wife was giving up all rights to our son so that she could get out of
thousands of dollars of back child-support:

* Sometimes, it really helps to write a seriously venting letter SEPARATE
from the one you actually send!


David Cornelius
CorneliusConcepts.com

[1] http://members.aol.com/intwg/flamewars.htm

[2] http://info.astrian.net/jargon/terms/g/Godwin_s_Law.html

Subject: [PLUG] Re: Easy SMB browser?
Message-ID: <012020041450.23682.17ca@comcast.net>

Actually Konqueror does have samba support, i'm not sure if its a special plugin or not but i'm running gentoo and in the location bar you can use:

smb://servername/sharename/...

and if you do just "smb://servername" it'll grab the list of shares(if its accessible).

On Mon, 19 Jan 2004, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> Is there an easy SMB browser for Linux?  I'd prefer a plug-in
> solution for Nautilus, but something for Konqueror would work fine,
> too.

From gepr at tempusdictum.com  Tue Jan 20 11:06:02 2004
From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (gepr at tempusdictum.com)
Date: Tue Jan 20 11:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] secure methods for pushing content
Message-ID: <16397.31609.411007.78578@eris.dischordia.net>

What is the recommended way to push content from a local computer to a
server _without_ granting user-level access to the pusher?

I don't want a CMF, because all the ones I've seen present way too 
much overhead for the simple sites I'm dealing with.  There are 
no databases backing the sites, no separation between presentation
and content layers, no cgi's, etc.  (No lectures, please. [grin])

It would be really cool to simulate a push with a polling mechanism so
the website author could just hang the files somewhere and the server
goes out periodically and grabs the relevant parts, checks them for
undesirable features, then installs them.  But, I think that's just
a fantasy of mine.

Thanks for any advice.

--

M: 971.219.3846                               http://www.tempusdictum.com




From danh at fork.com  Tue Jan 20 11:22:01 2004
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Tue Jan 20 11:22:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Conclusion to PDXLUG argument
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0401201052540.6013-100000@cohiba.fork.com>

I know the argument yesterday was painful to all involved but it was
designed to send a specific set of messages. Given that they had blocked
other channels of communication, it was necessary to do so in the PLUG
forum. Once again, here are the points:

1) Let PDXLUG know that this issue is not trivial to us.

2) Remind PDXLUG know that we have a legal right to the name.

3) Let PDXLUG know that the issue has not and will not go away until they
"do the right thing".

The messages have been sent. I want to thank everyone who participated. I
also want to apologize to the PLUG members who found it intolerable.

Dan




From griffint at pobox.com  Tue Jan 20 11:30:03 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Tue Jan 20 11:30:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] All I need to know I learned from PLUG vs. PLUG
In-Reply-To: <E1AiuAt-0003bR-He@jerry.networkeleven.net>
References: <E1AiuAt-0003bR-He@jerry.networkeleven.net>
Message-ID: <20040120192701.GA12659@aracnet.com>

> * "Portland Linux/Unix Group" is the DESCRIPTION for PLUG, which was changed
> from "Portland Linux Users Group" to better described what the group focuses
> on.  It is understandable to me that changing the actual name (i.e. to
> "PLUUG") would create unnecessary paperwork and possibly cost money.
> Besides, the new description fits the original acronym while better
> describing what the group is for and everyone knows who "PLUG" is.
>
The description change was mostly a nod to the Free/Open/NetBSD people.
We wanted them to feel welcome. While users of proprietary Unix flavors
were and still are welcomed to participate in PLUG as well, those users 
were not the main focus of attention at the time of the change.

I faintly recall discussing the idea of changing PLUG to PLBG or some
such thing (for Portland Linux/BSD Group). But you can't pronounce
"PLBG" and there would have been that ugly paperwork.

Terry
-- 
Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com>
http://www.blindchicken.com/~terryg/

group PDXLUG when people ask what it is. We call ourselves PDXLUG not 
'Portland Linux User Group' and this has been mentioned over and over 
and over...and yet you refuse to acknowledge this

3.) I felt that I had done the right thing when I helped start PDXLUG 
over a year ago and your posting has only reaffirmed this.

Thanks to all those who have joined PDXLUG over the past year (and the 
few that joined since this all started yesterday morning)... we offer a 
much more on topic discussion group....and do our best (even if it mean 
banning off-topic posters) to keep it that way.

http://www.pdxlug.org/ (a portland linux user group)

Cheers,

-Robby

Dan Haskell wrote:

>I know the argument yesterday was painful to all involved but it was

>other channels of communication, it was necessary to do so in the PLUG
>forum. Once again, here are the points:
>
>1) Let PDXLUG know that this issue is not trivial to us.
>
>2) Remind PDXLUG know that we have a legal right to the name.
>
>3) Let PDXLUG know that the issue has not and will not go away until they
>"do the right thing".

>The messages have been sent. I want to thank everyone who participated. I
>also want to apologize to the PLUG members who found it intolerable.

Dan,

Before you throw the gauntlet down again (and take us right back to day 
1, as you've just done), why don't you consider a more diplomatic 
approach.   We both know that Robby at least has made some attempts to 
pacify you despite misgivings about the whole deal.   While I'm loathe 
to speak for PDXLUG, it seems obvious that most people are a bit 
reactionary and don't take well to having demands placed on them.   I'd 
suggest that these are the counter-points:

1)  We think the issue is trivial.  This aspect will probably never be 
agreed on, so we can simply agree to disagree.

2)  PLUG has no legal right to anything.  Linux is a registered 
trademark of another entity <wink> and there is nothing to claim damages 
about even were it not (there is no money or misrepresentation involved; 
you might think the info about PLUG on pdxlug.org is insufficient, but I 
doubt a judge would agree with you).   But please feel free to waste 
everyone's money on lawyers or your breath on idle threats.

3) The "issue" would have probably gone away long ago if people such as 
yourself would simply approach the other side in a reasonably adult 
fashion and present your request as such and not as a demand.  As far as 
I'm concerned, and I suspect most others involved with PDXLUG, neither 
you nor anyone else in PLUG has any right to demand anything from 
PDXLUG.   As such your demands are bound to have the opposite of the 
intended effect.  The side that you fail to see is that PDXLUG feels 
*you* should "do the right thing" and concentrate on more serious 
issues, like why people find PLUG so annoying (hint).

In short, feel free to open the flamewar all over again if you like.   
I'll be a frequent contributor.  Or you can "do the right thing" and try 
to resolve the issue with Robby and PDXLUG in a respectful and 
considerate fashion.   Please don't bore me with "we've tried that" 
because you haven't.   We can sit here all day and post links to emails 
to prove our points or we can resolve the issue.  But I can assure you 
that any resolution *will* be a compromise and so far you and your 
compatriots haven't seemed willing to accept that.

Regards,
Cliff

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Tue Jan 20 12:54:02 2004
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)

At the risk of belaboring this further...


On Tue, 20 Jan 2004 11:21:16, Dan Haskell <danh at fork.com> wrote:
> 
> Once again, here are the points:
> 
> 1) Let PDXLUG know that this issue is not trivial to us.

Please know that many of PDXLUG's members have heard this loud and
clear.  I, for one, have gone on record on both group's lists as
advocating greater clarity.  

Please also hear that PDXLUG does not exist to antagonize PLUG, though I
don't blame you for perceiving antagonism in the words and actions of
some members.  In contrast, many (perhaps most) of us keep tabs on both
groups and have no particular bone to pick.

> 
> 2) Remind PDXLUG ... that we have a legal right to the name.

This assertion is both counter-productive and factually suspect.

I agree that providing greater clarity is the *right* thing to do, but
let's be serious about what making broad legal claims does: it makes a
threat.  Making threats (even subtle ones) isn't likely to make anyone
feel like working toward an amicable resolution

Your DBA probably wouldn't prove to be very valuable if it were ever to
be tested in court.  You're free to "claim* whatever you want, but as a
practical matter, it will be quite difficult to convince a court that
you exclusively own the use of a highly generic phrase that was in use
by multiple entities for at least 7 months prior to your registration.

Even if you *had* a claim, the fact that you've taken no legal action
for a year pretty much kills it. When you fail to enforce IP rights, you
cease to have them in any meaningful way.

>From a moral and ethical viewpoint, I respect your opinion, but from a
legal perspective, you don't appear to have a leg to stand on. Please,
let's back away from the legal opinions and stick to the issue at hand:
you're pissed and PDXLUG needs to figure out how to respond to that.


> 
> 3) Let PDXLUG know that the issue has not and will not go away until they
> "do the right thing".

Heard and understood... by me, anyway.

FWIW,

Dylan

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Jan 20 19:59:24 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Jan 20 19:59:24 2004
Subject: [PLUG] vi mail processing
In-Reply-To: <slrnc0rt6p.krt.aaron@aluminum.bavariati.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401161457480.12525@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <20040120000706.GB27885@bavariati.org> <20040120003907.GD31045@rauhaus.org>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401191740450.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <20040120065755.GA2567@wirex.net>
	 <slrnc0rt6p.krt.aaron@aluminum.bavariati.org>
Message-ID: <1074657491.20818.175.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Tue, 2004-01-20 at 19:41, Aaron Burt wrote:
> Steve Beattie <steve at wirex.net> wrote:
> >
> > I think you are referring to something like the following, which I have
> > in my .vimrc (the latter being taken from Wil Cooley):
> >
> >   map =3D {!}fmt -c -u=0D}
> >   map + {!}fmt -c -u -p"> "=0D}
> 
> Nifty.  What's the =3D?

There's a problem with the MIME-conversion going from Mailman into NNTP
or within slrn; the '=3D' is actually an escaped equals; the '=0D' is
actually a literal newline character (CTRL-V Enter lets you insert it). 
Vim lets you use '<cr>' instead of having to insert a literal control
character.

Wil

From chris at maybe.net  Tue Jan 20 21:16:01 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Jan 20 21:16:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] secure methods for pushing content
In-Reply-To: <16397.31609.411007.78578@eris.dischordia.net>
References: <16397.31609.411007.78578@eris.dischordia.net>
Message-ID: <20040121051523.GB9962@maybe.net>

On Tue, Jan 20, 2004 at 11:03:21AM -0800, gepr at tempusdictum.com wrote:
> What is the recommended way to push content from a local computer to a
> server _without_ granting user-level access to the pusher?

Dunno about "recommended", but if you control the server you are
pushing to, you could use "scponly"[1]. It allows you to scp to a
target account without the account needing shell access. So, e.g., you
set up an account called, say, "mover", set it up with the allowed RSA
id's, set its shell to scponly, and then from your client station, you
just do "scp *.html mover at server:public_html/" like normal. Getting
the framework securely locked down requires attention to detail, but
you get the gist.

[1] http://www.sublimation.org/scponly/

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

On Tue, 2004-01-20 at 22:44, Russell Evans wrote:

> I don't think that are many LUGs Doing Business As "* Linux User Group".
> The DBA thing is worrisome and am surprised / shocked by its existence. 

Well, the fact of the matter is that certain parties are using their
status in the group as leverage in gaining business for their firm(s). 
I personally don't find much wrong with that aspect of it, and in fact
consider it fairly reasonable.   People often use membership in clubs as
a reference.  However, much of the concern over the name of PDXLUG
arises from a fear that confusion among potential *customers* might
arise, *not* potential LUG users as has been so vehemently claimed. 
Therefore these individuals have instrumented much of the current heated
battle in an attempt to quell PDXLUG or at least make it a non-entity in
the LUG realm.  This I *do* have a problem with.  Further, I find it
repulsive that these persons would manipulate others into doing their
dirty work under the guise of protecting the community when really all
they are doing is protecting their income.  But then again, it rings of
the finest of American corporate manipulation.  I just expected better
of people with standing (however limited) in the OSS community.

As a side note, I am not aware that any of the active participants in
this argument in the last couple of days are directly involved in this,
and despite what I might think of their intelligence, I have refrained
from making accusations of such.  They may or may not be involved, but I
haven't seen any evidence to support that notion, aside from their own
inexplicable concern over the name.  I am more inclined to believe that
they are simple puppets in the matter (emphasis on simple).  However, I
have seen *proof* of other's doings but am currently forced to withhold
that person's name out of respect for the source of the information.


Regards,
Cliff

Good.  That was going to be my first point when I got home.

> However, much of the concern over the name of PDXLUG arises from a fear
> that confusion among potential *customers* might arise, *not* potential

I think some of the people who do get commercial contacts through their
association with PLUG are concerned about continuing those contacts with
the confusion, but there are plenty of us that have no business interest
in PLUG that are just as concerned about the confusion and how this whole
mess is making all of us look.

> Further, I find it repulsive that these persons would manipulate others
> into doing their dirty work under the guise of protecting the community
> when really all they are doing is protecting their income.

Again, just because some people are concerned about business contacts
getting confused doesn't mean that's the only reason to try and avoid
confusion.


I'm also going to go ahead and point out here that a DBA has
non-commercial purposes.  A DBA is simply a registered legal entity that
is not a person.  A DBA allows, for example, items to be granted or loaned
to PLUG without being granted or loaned to a particular individual.

So, the existence of a DBA does not imply that a person is doing
_commercial_ business as PLUG, just public business.

From chris at maybe.net  Wed Jan 21 06:35:06 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Jan 21 06:35:06 2004
Subject: [PLUG] syslog.conf
In-Reply-To: <200401210649.WAA32156@smtp.gssf.org>
References: <200401210649.WAA32156@smtp.gssf.org>
Message-ID: <20040121143454.GA15117@maybe.net>

On Tue, Jan 20, 2004 at 10:47:36PM -0800, Guy Noire wrote:
> I need to get these lines out of /var/log/auth.log
> 
> 
> Jan 20 22:39:01 kosmal cron(pam_unix)[12621]: session closed for user kevan
> [...]
> 
> So I changed /etc/syslog.conf to this.
> 
> 
> auth,authpriv.*;cron.none        /var/log/auth.log
> <added cron.none>
> 
> Question is ??
> 
> What am I doing wrong??
> Shouldn't that stop cron logging in auth.log??

You'd think so, eh?

> I am missing something here..

The log lines in question *aren't* coming from cron, they're coming
from pam_unix.so and they're coming at authpriv.info, not cron.*.  The
following may work (untested):

authpriv.!info;auth,authpriv.*   /var/log/auth.log

Although this may lose information in other ways.

What you should do is use a program like logcheck to filter and send
you email of suspicious log entries. Then you can tweak the filters
with regex's to get rid of this stuff on a more fine-grained level.

HTH

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 21 06:37:08 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jan 21 06:37:08 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Signal:Noise -- an Observation
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401210626330.12791@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I read messages posted to this list that express concern, dislike even,
for the too low signal:noise ratio. It occurs to me why we see this and I
share my reason for seeing what we do.

  Too many exchanges that should be private (i.e., person-to-person) are
posted to the list instead. A benign example is Keith's request of last
evening for a contract attorney reference. Three responses to his request
went to the list rather than directly to him. Why? If others want to know
they can ask Keith by direct e-mail what names he's received.

  I equate this public exposure of private conversations to the clueless
masses who conduct what should be private telephone conversations all too
publicly on their cell phones. They walk retail store aisles chatting away
and do not care that others overhear their half of the conversation. More
importantly, they don't care that we just do not want to hear their
conversations and that it's intrusive on our privacy.

  Please think about this when a question is posted to the list and you
respond to it. Many times the answer would be of general interest and should
be captured in the list archives. Too often that is not the case.

Thanks,

Rich

From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] OT: Consulting Contracts
In-Reply-To: <20040121144234.GB15117@maybe.net>
References: <20040121071527.GA4133@gate.kl-ic.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401210616060.12600@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401210635480.12791@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <20040121144234.GB15117@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401210650190.29481@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 21 Jan 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:

> BTW-Threaded mail makes this all soooo much better. I come in and
> there's 43 (honestly!) new messages on PLUG vs PLUG over the past
> hour (in this example)--they're all in one thread, so I just hit
> "M-d $ y" in mutt and the entire batch of that thread is gone.

In pine, it's "$h/d" :-) Verbosely:

  $ -- sort
  h -- by thread
  / -- collapse thread
  d -- mark as deleted

You can always have pine use threads as the default sorting mechanism
as well, though I prefer arrival time.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Not at all.  I'm quite aware that PLUG consists of a large and mostly

interest in an operating system.  I think I've clearly stated my
intention here, which is to get a small but vocal minority to shut up

own interests.  Early in my postings (and after this thread was at least
a day old all on its own [and simply a rehash of earlier threads on both

that they were concerned that PDXLUG was damaging PLUG in some
ill-defined fashion while they themselves were demonstrably damaging it
themselves (via the announcements of people abandoning the list).  I

necessary to revise history and to change the stated goals of the group.

there are certainly a number of interpretations of those events, these
are just mine.

other than Dave and have probably done more harm than good to any
prospects of financial gain form PLUG by my participation in this
donnybrook.  I just find trolls annoying.

PDXLUG, because that is what I call them.  The portland Maine Linux

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Jan 21 12:11:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Jan 21 12:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] FYI: Burning CD-R's from iso's
In-Reply-To: <1074559355.15158.1330.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1074559355.15158.1330.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <3156-21864@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 19 Jan 2004, Bill Spears bspears-at-easystreet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I tried dd with a RH 8 disk and it worked fine. So there was some
> difference between manufactured CD-ROM's and CD-R's made from iso's.

I've noticed the same thing.  I suspect it's because of updates made to
the distribution after pressing the in-box CDs.  Alas, I just nuked my
collection of RH 8 ISOs or I'd give you the MD5sums from each version.

> I found that adding the disk at once option(-dao) to cdrecord produces a
> CD-R that works properly with dd, etc.
>
> #cdrecord -v speed=24 dev=0,0,0 -dao -data /tmp/yarrow-i386-disc1.iso

It sounds like you may have a throughput issue.  24x is pretty damn fast,
and you might be pushing the limits of your hardware, drivers, OS, or
media at that speed.  "DAO" may be reducing your speed to where you're
able to cope better.

I'd suggest trying the same thing at 8x and see if it helps.  The cdrecord
utility should have warned you if it couldn't keep up, though.

  -- Steve

else who wants to know can send email to ask for the answers too.

many reasons this can fail to get a timely answer, or any answer
at all.  it's simpler if questions and answers are both just
automatically archived and indexed.

one common workaround is "respond to me privately, and I'll
summarize".

From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (gepr at tempusdictum.com)
Date: Wed Jan 21 12:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] secure methods for pushing content
In-Reply-To: <20040121051523.GB9962@maybe.net>
References: <16397.31609.411007.78578@eris.dischordia.net>
	<20040121051523.GB9962@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <16398.58785.952589.426237@eris.dischordia.net>

Russell Senior writes:
 > Hmm.  How about email?  Include a key somewhere in the message to use
 > in filtering out the inevitable junk (or go the full-blown PGP/GPG
 > route), have procmail (or equivalent) check the key and plop the
 > content in the right spot.

Excellent idea!  I hadn't even considered the immense powers of
procmail.

Chris Jantzen writes:
 > Dunno about "recommended", but if you control the server you are
 > pushing to, you could use "scponly"[1]. It allows you to scp to a
 > target account without the account needing shell access. So, e.g., you
 > set up an account called, say, "mover", set it up with the allowed RSA
 > id's, set its shell to scponly, and then from your client station, you
 > just do "scp *.html mover at server:public_html/" like normal. Getting
 > the framework securely locked down requires attention to detail, but
 > you get the gist.
 > 
 > [1] http://www.sublimation.org/scponly/

This one would be perfect.  The problem is that it's some non-computer
people (artists no less... the worst kind of user [grin]) who want to
do the updating.  So, I'm worried about their ability to correctly 
install and operate scp.

I'm going to give both of these a shot.

Thanks!

Subject: [PLUG] taking it off list (OT)

The problem with taking it off list, is that it leaves ones opponent
with the last public word on the matter, unchallenged.  This is
especially difficult when one feels they have been maligned in some way.
But of course, this a meta discussion and simply adds to the OT chatter,
as do pleas by the uninvolved. (Note, pleas by the uninvolved to the
combatantsto, "get a room" etc... should be in private email not sent to
the entire list further reducing the signal to noise).

Subject: [PLUG] FYI: Burning CD-R's from iso's
In-Reply-To: <3156-21864@sneakemail.com>
References: <1074559355.15158.1330.camel@apollo.spears.org>
	 <3156-21864@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1074726582.30587.40.camel@apollo.spears.org>

On Wed, 2004-01-21 at 12:10, Steve Bonds wrote:
> On Mon, 19 Jan 2004, Bill Spears bspears-at-easystreet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:
> 
> > I tried dd with a RH 8 disk and it worked fine. So there was some
> > difference between manufactured CD-ROM's and CD-R's made from iso's.
> 
> I've noticed the same thing.  I suspect it's because of updates made to
> the distribution after pressing the in-box CDs.  Alas, I just nuked my
> collection of RH 8 ISOs or I'd give you the MD5sums from each version.
> 
> > I found that adding the disk at once option(-dao) to cdrecord produces a
> > CD-R that works properly with dd, etc.
> >
> > #cdrecord -v speed=24 dev=0,0,0 -dao -data /tmp/yarrow-i386-disc1.iso
> 
> It sounds like you may have a throughput issue.  24x is pretty damn fast,
> and you might be pushing the limits of your hardware, drivers, OS, or
> media at that speed.  "DAO" may be reducing your speed to where you're
> able to cope better.
> 
> I'd suggest trying the same thing at 8x and see if it helps.  The cdrecord
> utility should have warned you if it couldn't keep up, though.
> 
>   -- Steve
> 



Steve, I'm pretty sure it's the -dao option.  I burned one yarrow-i386-disc1.iso
with -dao and one without.  The one with -dao exhibited no problems.  I can't be
completely sure, but the bad one was burned at speed=12 and the good one was
 burned at speed=24.  Also keep in mind even the 'bad' one was accurate at the
file level.  It passed the disk check during the Fedora update and the mount
 and diff test.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jan 21 15:28:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Jan 21 15:28:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS
In-Reply-To: <1074727249.30594.43.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1074727249.30594.43.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1074727629.20818.220.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2004-01-21 at 15:20, Bill Spears wrote:
> I'm attempting to get CUPS working on a update of RH8 by Fedora Core 1.
> Let's call the computers A and Z. A is running RH8 and Z is running
> Fedora. CUPS is installed on A and works.  My first attempt on Z didn't
> work.  In a debugging effort, I attempted to access SWAT on A using a
> browser on Z using the address http://A:631 and received the error:"You
> don't have permission to access the resource on this server."
> 
> Does this suggest a solution?

Indeed.  CUPS by default (on RH/Fdr at least) will only accept
connections from localhost.  Edit the /etc/cups/cupsd.conf file and
permit access from your local IP network.  (And "swat" is the Samba web
tool; I don't know if CUPS has a name for their web-admin tool.)

Wil

>from pam_unix.so and they're coming at authpriv.info, not cron.*.  The

>
>authpriv.!info;auth,authpriv.*   /var/log/auth.log

>you email of suspicious log entries. Then you can tweak the filters
>with regex's to get rid of this stuff on a more fine-grained level.

On Wed, 2004-01-21 at 22:16, Keith wrote:
> Apparently McBride has been inspired by the conspiracy theory crowd
> and is now telling Congress that Open Source Software is a criminal
> conspiracy.
> http://www.osaia.org/letters/sco_hill.pdf

When I fist started reading the pdf, I thought this must be some kind of
parody or sham!  It is just so totally misrepresentative of the Open
Source movement.  People who develop software and give of their time and
intellect and donate it to the world for free are doing it out of
altruism for the betterment of society in much the same way that people
give blood in one country to help quake victims in another.  All we ask
is that nobody in the delivery chain sells the "blood" we have donated!

Another analogy (closer to the "intellectual property" arena) is
Representative Democracy.  Nobody owns the blueprint for it.  The US has
done a pretty good job of implementing it, and is trying to export it to
every country in the world not only so the rest of the world is better
off, but so that we too will be better off when they have it.  It would
be unAmerican to claim we invented it, and to sue other countries who
try to implement it.

Alas, too many of the older generation just don't have clue about it,
and too many competitor companies see it as a threat to their business.

- Jesse

(and please, I don't want to start any partisan political rants!)




From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Jan 22 03:11:02 2004
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)

Message-ID: <20040122111004.DD1E0158047@kanga.canids>

Cliff Wells <clifford.wells at comcast.net>:
> I pointed out the inconsistency of the claims of those who said
> that they were concerned that PDXLUG was damaging PLUG in some
> ill-defined fashion while they themselves were demonstrably damaging it
> themselves (via the announcements of people abandoning the list).

they're different types of damage.  anyone can care about one
type but not another without being particularly inconsistent.
though I think most of the people who do care dropped out early
from the flame war.  the bulk of it was you and Jeme, and the
announced unsubscriptions happened after you two were going at it
for a while.

Jeme is pretty predictable in his allegiance to cyber-anarchy.
I'm not sure PLUG as a whole is committed to cyber-anarchy, but
if the people who control the infrastructure are, then the group
will tend to self-select for people who value it or are willing
to tolerate it.  to cyber-anarchists, unsubscriptions are not
damage, they're expected, and the people who leave are those who
aren't compatible with cyber-anarchy ideals, which is fine.

"unfair competition" is not ill-defined damage.  the law's been
around since the 60s.  in trademark infringement, intent is
irrelevant.  what matters is whether people may be confused or
not.

I'm not advocating legal action, by the way.  this is just to
point out that there's precedent for a particular method for
resolving this type of dispute, and if a law's been around for a
while, it's possible that people generally feel the principles
behind it are sensible.  domain registrars have similar
resolution methods.

the issue is not the name "PDXLUG", it's the use of the phrase
"Portland Linux User Group", which I would naturally abbreviate
as "PLUG", which seems like reasonable grounds for confusion, and
there may be concrete evidence of specific cases of confusion.

for your example about the "The Beaverton Honda Dealers", I think
Wil was focusing on the wrong thing, which was something like
whether the phrase seems too generic for a trademark to be valid.
it doesn't matter how the phrase seems.  what matters is how it's
being used.  if there were a long-established company called
that, with an ad campaign and brand recognition and such, I think
a judge would rule in favor of them, since that's the intent of
the unfair competition law.

one example that I thought of: the phrase "Girl Scouts" is pretty
generic, but it's commonly understood to refer to one particular
entity, and I suspect someone who tries to sell their own brand
of "Girl Scout Cookies" would lose a lawsuit.  I'd have to go
digging into case law to be sure, and I'm not going to go do
that.  I'm also unclear how the UCC affects any of this.  my
curiosity about intellectual property laws happened a few years
before UCC took effect, and I haven't paid much attention since
then.

I gather PDXLUG has been phasing out the use of the phrase
"Portland Linux User Group", but it looks like it's been
happening in a slow and inconsistent manner, perhaps because the
PDXLUG people don't feel it's an important issue.

it's not an important issue to me either, but I can see why
people would care, and I think it's generally a good idea to
listen to that, because volunteer work is often done by people
who feel passionate about what they do.  it's natural for people
to become emotionally attached to their pet projects.  telling
them they shouldn't care so much is usually counter-productive.

I didn't sort through the profit/nonprofit thing, but it doesn't
particularly bother me if people claim PLUG as a merit badge.
saying "I helped make that happen" is normal pride.  everyone has
their own trophies, and most people understand the caveats and
limitations of that.

the personality conflicts, I generally have no idea about,
because I don't know any of the people involved, and that stuff
usually isn't discussed openly.

Jeme is an easy case.  you have an issue with the way he applied
the description "totalitarian regime" to PDXLUG.  Jeme is just
nutty about that.  this is not usually a problem.  any large,
diverse group of people will have some that are predictably nutty
about something or other, and people learn to deal with it.

his worldview is logically consistent to him, but the statements
he make sound absurd to many other people, because he uses words
in abnormal ways, focusing on the semantic associations that are
meaningful to him and ignoring the ones meaningful to others.  he
ends up expending a lot of energy trying to explain his
unconventional worldview over and over again, which doesn't
really improve his credibility with anyone who doesn't already
understand his worldview.

and he's going to keep doing that, because cyber-anarchists do
not have any other method for resolving disagreements.  to him,
restricting free expression is an ultimate evil, and I'm guessing
he will fight for your right to flame endlessly.  your attempt to
annoy him enough to make him go away is never going to work.

I'm sure I'm leaving things out, but that's what I remember from
the flame war.  anything else you'd like a response to?

oh, in case it isn't clear, I don't speak for anyone but me.
--

I think this is a pretty darn good way of explaining this in retrospect.

I take the term "nutty" above to be meant as "peculiar" or "not like you
and me".  The respect and understanding shown in the rest of the message
clearly indicate that Felix did not intend it to be synonymous with
"crank" or "loon" or something.

I do spend a lot of energy trying to explain my views to people and, I
must say, it pays off.  Whenever anybody "gets it", after explanation or
right off, we get along swimmingly and often come to fantastic new
understanding of things together.  This doesn't mean they always agree
with my opinions, but understand my analysis and come to a common
understanding of terms.  Lots of people, though, just throw up their hands
either because they are so repulsed by what they think I'm saying that
they become mentally paralyzed or because they believe they do not have
time to listen to another person who doesn't share their narrow view.
It's a shame, but it's reality.

And you're darn right that we do not have any other method for resolving
disagreements.  The ONLY way to resolve disagreements is to talk them out
until you both understand the situation and can reach real agreement.
That might seem crazy to those out there who want to solve a problem by
picking up a gun or withholding food (essentially the same thing --
violence) or just dismissing and insulting those with whom they disagree
(essentially the same thing -- disrespect).  But it works with anyone who
takes the time and applies the intelligence and shows the respect
necessary.  Needless to say, this requires actually wanting to solve the
problem.

Y'all might be surprised to find that Cliff and I have, in fact, come to
mutual understanding off-list.  There remain a couple of tiny points of
interpretation where we differ, but that's just the spice of life... or
something.

The only real obstacle to anarchism (and I don't have any idea what a
"cyber-anarchist" is) is ego or pride.  When you can accept change (of
mind, of heart, of anything) without seeing that as an admission of
weakness, then real peace and understanding are possible.  For some
people, this requires a trust that they will not be ridiculed for showing
this supposed weakness.  Those people can be helped along by giving them
as much love and understanding back as you can possibly muster.

Tempers may flare, but respect should be always maintained and worn on
your sleeve.

Some people think that you have to show yourself as some kind of threat to
be taken seriously.  I believe it's exactly the opposite.

This has nothing to do with PLUG and I won't follow up anything on this
topic anymore on this list, but I just wanted to share and see if maybe
there aren't some kindred minds out there that might be ready to help move
in this direction.

J.

Double quotes, i.e. ", they prevent special character expansion, but not
variable expansion (yeah I know there is a contradiction there)


# foo="bing bar"
# `cat "$foo"`
cat: bing bar: No such file or directory
# `cat $foo`
cat: bing: No such file or directory
cat: bar: No such file or directory

From bspears at easystreet.com  Thu Jan 22 08:22:27 2004
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Thu Jan 22 08:22:27 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Getting CUPS to Broadcast
In-Reply-To: <1074727249.30594.43.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1074727249.30594.43.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1074788536.30594.82.camel@apollo.spears.org>

I was trying to get computer Z to use computer A as a CUPS print
server.  My difficulty was my own fault since I have done this in
various ways before and simply forgot what I had done.  I have a
notebook running RH8 that prints to computer A just fine (using lpr,
though), a  Win98 that works through Samba, and I'm pretty sure that I
had something running CUPS that worked. I don't believe I ever had CUPS
broadcasting: 

        this means that when you use the CUPS admin tool
        (http://localhost:631/) you will see a list of all CUPS printers
        on the LAN, and thus there is nothing to do on the client
        
I found this website:

http://people.trustcommerce.com/~adam/hacks/cups-network.php

which solved my problem.  You need to make the following edits to

/etc/cups/cupsd.conf

BrowseAddress 10.0.1.255

or whatever your LAN broadcast address is.

Under Security Options, change to
<Location />
Order Deny,Allow
Allow From All

This assumes you are behind a firewall.

Restart cups and you're done:
/etc/init.d/cups restart

Your printer should now show up on any networked computer running cups.

From ed at alcpress.com  Thu Jan 22 13:50:03 2004

> > promotional materials, etc.
> > 
> > Dan
> > 
> 
> Thanks for clearing that up for me/us.
> 
> Is this something he sees happening in the near future?

David and I discussed this a few months ago. PLUG would have to
become a legal entity and that brings with it obligations and
expenses. PLUG has no membership dues now but that may have
to change if it incorporates. The concept of PLUG "membership"
may need to be nailed down so the organization can function
according to its Bylaws. 

Once you have Bylaws and corporate officers, you will eventually
run into political struggles that can suck the life out of the
group. The best example of this is the Portland PC User Group,
which had a complete meltdown some years back that stopped the
group from functioning for a time, involved claims of theft of
capital assets, and (if I recall correctly) drained the bank
account.

PANUG had a similar squabble, where the Board of Directors had
a total meltdown and could no longer operate according to its
Bylaws. Fortunately, the group had contracted with an outsource
company that ran the group until the membership could replace
the Board. However, the first action of the new Board was to
discuss the group purchasing insurance to protect Board members
from being sued by one another. 

One only has to have monitored the silly pissing match on the
PLUG list this week to easily envision similar or worse things
happening to PLUG. My suggestion is to remain free.

Ed

From gepr at tempusdictum.com  Thu Jan 22 14:22:01 2004
From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (gepr at tempusdictum.com)
Date: Thu Jan 22 14:22:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The wrong app
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401221354590.7471@localhost.localdomain>

	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0401221354590.7471@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <16400.19568.784447.59620@eris.dischordia.net>

Paul Heinlein writes:
 > On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Ed Sawicki wrote:
 > 
 > > I'm teaching a college course and I'd like to give my students some
 > > rough stats on how often people use the wrong program for given
 > > tasks. I see it frequently but I wonder if my experiences are
 > > typical. For example, I see many people use spreadsheet programs
 > > when a database is the clearly better way. I think that all but one
 > > of my consulting customers is using at least one wrong app. What's
 > > your experience?
 > 
 > The biggest example of this that I see is using smtp to push large
 > attachments to others. Many headaches are saved when people learn how
 > to use http and/or ftp instead.

This is a bad one.  However, I regularly see a worse one, that of
using Excel (or other spreadsheets) to process (reduce), analyze, and
visualize scientific data.

I admit to having written entire missile simulations in spreadsheets
before; so, I can't cast the first stone.  But nothing is more
frustrating than trying to teach a grad student to use SAS, R, or any
of the other serious tools... don't even consider trying to get them
to understand when to use things like CVS or or a numerics library
like LAPACK.  It seems like there's a gene for using judgement in
picking the right tool for a job... either you're born with it or
you're not.

Of course, this is all very subjective.  Artifacts are, in some ways,
autotelic.  They may have been created teleologically; but, as soon 
as an ignorant user can pick it up and start farting around with it
(like a 5 year old with a playstation), the final cause becomes an 
emergent property of the usage patterns.

Anyway, good luck getting actual stats.  The only thing I've seen
in this regard are the IDS and forensic tools that track "abnormal"
behavior.  There were also projects at IBM and UNM to dynamically
learn typical usage patterns for tools like lpr.  But, I doubt one
could ever quantify how often, say, Acrobat is used wrongly.

On Thu, 2004-01-22 at 13:17, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I'm teaching a college course and I'd like to give my
> students some rough stats on how often people use the
> wrong program for given tasks. I see it frequently but
> I wonder if my experiences are typical. For example, I
> see many people use spreadsheet programs when a database
> is the clearly better way. I think that all but one of my
> consulting customers is using at least one wrong app.
> What's your experience?

People distributing text documents as Microsoft Word Documents.  Friends
of mine (rarely) receive MS Word Docs as email forward/jokes (not
viruses, clean).  Idiot professors at PSU regularly post MS Word
Documents on their websites, be it WebCT or other pages.

For that matter, people distributing text as PDF documents.  Completely
unformatted text, or text that doesn't need to be printed (only
viewed).  People utilize PDFs instead of html files on websites far too
often - I *hate* having to load a plugin for them!  Not that there
aren't good uses for PDFs, there are plenty... I regularly print to PDF
then put the PDF on a website when I need to print a report but don't
have physical access to my printer at the time.

I've also had friends and family (not myself these days) receive
pictures attached to emails in the form of MS Word Documents.  You open
the MS Word Document and what do you see?  A picture on a piece of
paper.  Nice.

Rob

perspective email is perfect, just fire and forget.

> > how to use http and/or ftp instead.

I agree on both counts: it's easy, and it's up to IT to provide an
easy alternative.

I could have stated the problem a little better. It's one thing to
send an attachment to someone; that's quick and easy.

It's another thing to send the same attachment to many people; that's
when dropping it in ~/public_html (or H:\public_html in the unified
NFS/CIFS environment we provide here) make so much more sense, and
I'd be hard-pressed not to laugh out loud if someone claims it's a
difficult procedure.

From chris at maybe.net  Thu Jan 22 16:24:02 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Thu Jan 22 16:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] BASHing my head on the keys.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401221614220.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401220541380.17290@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401220723030.7663@debs.cse.ogi.edu> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401221457350.17290@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401221614220.17290@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20040123002313.GA5766@maybe.net>

On Thu, Jan 22, 2004 at 04:15:16PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > > Does backslashing the quotes help?
> > >
> > >   $(command \"$filename\")
> >
> > Backslashing the quotes give me the right output when I echo the command
> > back, i.e.
> >
> > command "file with spaces"
> >
> > But it still seems to try to execute with three arguments.
> 
> For the record, I'm getting something like:
> 
> file not found: '"file'
> file not found: 'with'
> file not found: 'spaces"'
> 
> What gives?


According to the manpage (look under "Word Splitting") enclosing a
variable expansion in quotation marks makes it one parameter, while on
its own, it will split words. 

I made a script called "foo" that just did "echo $#" -- i.e., when
run, it would echo back the number of parameters it was passed. Made
the following run:

omoikane:~$ export VAR="one two three"
omoikane:~$ echo $VAR
one two three
omoikane:~$ ./foo $VAR
3
omoikane:~$ ./foo "$VAR"
1
omoikane:~$ echo $(./foo "$VAR")
1
omoikane:~$ echo $(./foo $VAR)
3
omoikane:~$ ./foo $(echo $VAR)
3
omoikane:~$ ./foo $(echo "$VAR")
3
omoikane:~$ ./foo "$(echo $VAR)"
1
omoikane:~$ ./foo "$(echo "$VAR")"
1
omoikane:~$

Is one of these what you were looking for?

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

> > # foo="bing bar"

> > cat: bar: No such file or directory

> argument.

Try something like this:

# myfilename="a file name.avi"
# find . -name "$myfilename" -print -exec mplayer {} \;

I have done similar things in the past to get mplayer to run on files with spaces in the name.

From bsr at spek.org  Thu Jan 22 17:28:02 2004
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Thu Jan 22 17:28:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The wrong app
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401221508300.2731@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <1074806235.3539.163.camel@nat.alcpress.com> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401221354590.7471@localhost.localdomain> <4010538F.30109@spek.org> <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401221508300.2731@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <40107862.4040104@spek.org>

Paul Heinlein wrote:
> It's another thing to send the same attachment to many people; that's
> when dropping it in ~/public_html (or H:\public_html in the unified
> NFS/CIFS environment we provide here) make so much more sense, and
> I'd be hard-pressed not to laugh out loud if someone claims it's a
> difficult procedure.

I've had the same setup in many places I've been, and you're right it's 
not difficult for you and I and perhaps the people you work with, but it 
is difficult for the vast majority of the computer using public.

Here's what I've witnessed multiple times: instead of Joe Salesguy just 
attaching a file to an email and letting email do what it does he now 
has to copy it to h:\public_html.

And figure out that that maps to "http://www.companyname.com/bobo/".

And tack the name of the file onto it and send the email containing the 
url of the file.

And the file's name is "4th quarter sales projections (eastern 
division).ppt".

And then all of the recipients' mail program's url parsers won't 
properly parse a bare url with spaces in it and everybody trys to grab 
the file at "http://www.companyname.com/bobo/4th"

And then all of the recipients email Joe back and say they couldn't get it.

And then Joe just attaches the file to an email and sends it off and 
calls up the IT department and (very rightly) bitches at them (for the 
wrong reasons).

--Brent

From ramunro at speakeasy.net  Thu Jan 22 18:10:03 2004
From: ramunro at speakeasy.net (Robert Munro)
Date: Thu Jan 22 18:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The wrong app
Message-ID: <1074823793.3516.151.camel@griffin>

> On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Dan Haskell responded:
> 
> On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> 
> > I'm teaching a college course and I'd like to give my students some
> > rough stats on how often people use the wrong program for given
> tasks.
> > I see it frequently but I wonder if my experiences are typical. For
> > example, I see many people use spreadsheet programs when a database
> is
> > the clearly better way. I think that all but one of my consulting
> > customers is using at least one wrong app. What's your experience?
> 
> IMHO, the spreadsheet-as-swiss-army-knife mistake is the most common.
> 
The Big-5 accounting/consulting firms were (and likely still are) most
consistent offenders.  Ernst & Young once flew me to Dallas for a week
to salvage a tangle of spreadsheets built by the Government Consulting
Group to detail the effects of maintenance cost increases at Lockheed. 
Someone had created over a dozen spreadsheets requiring consolidation,
but loading then all under Windows95 crashed the OS.  I ran OS/2, so I
was able to consolidate them all, load OS/2 on a PC there, and escape.

> Same employer different problem - someone developed a "database" for a
> mission critical group using... wait for it... Microsoft Access. They
> made the stupid thing multi-user by loading it on a Novell server.
> Doh!

IBM Global Services used MS-Access under WindowsNT for the Los Angeles
Public Schools E-Rate project (fiber to the desktop in the classrooms). 
They had a separate Access database for each school's equipment and yet
other databases to track subcontractor work, invoices and payments.  It
couldn't have been managed worse if they'd tried to screw up by design. 
(IBM also pirated a few dozen copies of MS-Access software to do this.)

I strongly suspect such instances are not anomalies in many companies.

Regards,
Robert Munro

From plug201 at jblack.org  Thu Jan 22 20:20:03 2004
From: plug201 at jblack.org (J Black)
Date: Thu Jan 22 20:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] IMAP client
In-Reply-To: <20040122231801.31846.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040122231801.31846.qmail@web40806.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1074831426.12312.14.camel@prism>

On Thu, 2004-01-22 at 15:18, Scott Van Hoosen wrote:
...
> Also, what is a quick way to kill all processes that contain the word
> "evolution" such as "evolution-mail," "evolution-calen," etc.?
> 

$ evolution --force-shutdown
gets a lot of them.  Worked on my own processes, at least... don't know
about others.

if you really want to kill them all, try one of these:
$ ps -ef | grep evolution | grep -v grep
# ps -ef | grep -e 'evolut[i]on'
to see if these are the ones you don't like.  (In the 2nd form, the
square brackets are a trick to "not see" the process that has is doing
the grep-ing. The brackets can be on any character in the word.)
then add awk to get just the process id's and then add kill to kill
those processes as follows:
$ kill -9 `ps -ef | grep -e 'evolut[i]on' | awk '{print $2}' `

Hope this helps, and that nobody is editing a term paper on evolution at
the time.

- Jesse

***Open Source in Government: Newport News, VA
Open source software is often attractive to local governments due to cost
savings, stability, security, and open access. Migration is still tricky
though. Andy Stein, CIO of Newport News, VA, is tackling the problems of
adopting open source. In this interview with Tom Adelstein, Andy explains
why local governments should form an alliance to share their knowledge and
their code.
http://linux.oreillynet.com/pub/a/linux/2004/01/15/andy_stein_interview.html


***Five Tips for a Better sendmail Configuration
Using the vendor-configured version of sendmail bundled with your Unix OS
may seem like the easy route to take, but Craig Hunt, author of "sendmail
Cookbook," says don't be fooled by this apparent simplicity. Creating a
custom sendmail configuration gives you better performance, reliability,
security, and maintainability. Craig offers five tips to building a better
sendmail configuration.
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2004/01/15/sendmail.html

new XML-based markup language, codenamed XAML (short for eXtensible
Application Markup Language, and pronounced "Zammel"). User interfaces in

at how XAML relates to the underlying support provided by WinFX.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Jan 22 22:26:02 2004
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu Jan 22 22:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A poorly-performing hard drive
In-Reply-To: <1074835339.23840.4.camel@timmy>
References: <1074835339.23840.4.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040123062547.GA21804@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Thu, Jan 22, 2004 at 09:22:19PM -0800, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> # hdparm -tT /dev/hdb
> 
> /dev/hdb:
>  Timing buffer-cache reads:   1568 MB in  2.00 seconds = 784.00 MB/sec
>  Timing buffered disk reads:   22 MB in  3.25 seconds =   6.77 MB/sec

Have you enabled any features with hdparm? This is frequently the
cause of poor performance (at least in my experience).

run hdparm on the drive w/out any flags, you should get something like
this:

-($) hdparm /dev/hde

/dev/hde:
 multcount    = 16 (on)
 IO_support   =  3 (32-bit w/sync)
 unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
 using_dma    =  1 (on)
 keepsettings =  0 (off)
 readonly     =  0 (off)
 readahead    =  8 (on)
 geometry     = 23989/16/63, sectors = 156301488, start = 0


This is a good article on the subject:

http://linux.oreillynet.com/pub/a/linux/2000/06/29/hdparm.html

and here are the switches I use (on an 80gig DMA-100 baracuda):

/sbin/hdparm -m16 -c3 -d1 /dev/hde



-Rogan

> 
> I was expecting the second number to be over 20MB/s, because my old 15G
> produces around 18 MB/s. What does this mean?
> 
> Evan
> 
>

From: plug201 at jblack.org (J Black)

Subject: [PLUG] A poorly-performing hard drive

On Thu, 2004-01-22 at 21:22, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> Just for grins, I decided to do a benchmark test on my big shiny new
> 120G WD. I came up with some weird numbers:
> 
> # hdparm -tT /dev/hdb
> 
> /dev/hdb:
>  Timing buffer-cache reads:   1568 MB in  2.00 seconds = 784.00 MB/sec
>  Timing buffered disk reads:   22 MB in  3.25 seconds =   6.77 MB/sec
> 
> I was expecting the second number to be over 20MB/s, because my old 15G
> produces around 18 MB/s. What does this mean?

Ooh, that's pitiful!

Are you asking what does it all mean, or are you asking why your
buffered disk read throughput is so low?  I get 40 MB/sec from my WD and
57 MB/sec from my Maxtor.  

Were there other particularly active processes running on your system?
Are you using the ribbon cable that came with your hard drive?
Are you sure your motherboard supports UDMA100 or UDMA133?
Did you remember to remove the big red flag that says "Remove before
flight"?  (Just kidding...)

Might be helpful to post the output of # hdparm /dev/hdb

- Jesse

Most of us. One is tempted to suggest a content management system, but I
have never seen a content management system that satisfied the following
requirements:

1) had a _simple_ web front end, which was:
    a) secure
    b) fast
2) had a gui or cui front end, with searching capabilities
3) could easily import items from other sources (email, web pages)
   a) would like to be able to put a url in, and have it screenscrape,
either content or the entire page with images
   b) would like to forward an email to a gateway, or dump an mbox file
or Maildir dir at it in some way (http upload? upload through the
gui/cui?) and have it keep it intelligently.

Until that exists, do you have a better way of doing things than email?

Or does that exist? (please?)

  1992: The US Air Force awards New York University (NYU) a contract
        to build an open source compiler for what is now called Ada
        95. The NYU team chooses GNU GCC for code generation and calls
        their compiler GNAT (GNU NYU Ada 95 Translator).

From: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Date: Thursday, January 22, 2004 13:50:28
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] David Mandel - Where are you?
 
On Thu, 2004-01-22 at 12:57, Robby Russell wrote:
> Dan Haskell wrote:
> > On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Robby Russell wrote:
> > 
> > 
> >>Just curious if PLUG has a donation system or something that helps pay 
> >>for promotional stuff, hosting, etc. I am not saying that it is wrong, 
> >>just wasn't aware that such a financial backing existed in PLUG.
> >>
> >>No concerns, just curiousity.
> > 
> > 
> > PLUG does not have a bank account. Mention of an account was wishful
> > thinking on Dave's part. He has always wanted to formalize the group's
> > existence so that it could have things like bank accounts, group-funded
> > promotional materials, etc.
> > 
> > Dan
> > 
> 
> Thanks for clearing that up for me/us.
> 
> Is this something he sees happening in the near future?

David and I discussed this a few months ago. PLUG would have to
become a legal entity and that brings with it obligations and
expenses. PLUG has no membership dues now but that may have
to change if it incorporates. The concept of PLUG "membership"
may need to be nailed down so the organization can function
according to its Bylaws. 

Once you have Bylaws and corporate officers, you will eventually
run into political struggles that can suck the life out of the
group. The best example of this is the Portland PC User Group,
which had a complete meltdown some years back that stopped the
group from functioning for a time, involved claims of theft of
capital assets, and (if I recall correctly) drained the bank
account.

PANUG had a similar squabble, where the Board of Directors had
a total meltdown and could no longer operate according to its
Bylaws. Fortunately, the group had contracted with an outsource
company that ran the group until the membership could replace
the Board. However, the first action of the new Board was to
discuss the group purchasing insurance to protect Board members
from being sued by one another. 

One only has to have monitored the silly pissing match on the
PLUG list this week to easily envision similar or worse things
happening to PLUG. My suggestion is to remain free.

Ed

From Cadigan_J at hotmail.com  Fri Jan 23 12:51:02 2004
From: Cadigan_J at hotmail.com (John Cadigan)
Date: Fri Jan 23 12:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] A poorly-performing hard drive
References: <1074835339.23840.4.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <401188E5.000004.03864@GIDEON>

Keeping in mind that not all drives are created equal, some other factors
must be considered. Mainly things like, how much cache or memory buffer
exists? A drive with 2 MB of cache memory, verses newer drives with 8 MB
will obviously perform differently...so you must compare apples w/ apples. I
am assuming you may have considered these things in comparing the two (WD?)
drives.  Not to get off subject, but Maxtor has some nice features of late..
speaking of speed and such. Also concider, IDE v.s. SCSI etc, (but I know
you must be doing this)? 
 
-------Original Message-------
 
From: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Date: Thursday, January 22, 2004 21:56:45
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] A poorly-performing hard drive
 
Just for grins, I decided to do a benchmark test on my big shiny new
120G WD. I came up with some weird numbers:

# hdparm -tT /dev/hdb

/dev/hdb:
Timing buffer-cache reads: 1568 MB in 2.00 seconds = 784.00 MB/sec

produces around 18 MB/s. What does this mean?

Evan

From chris at maybe.net  Fri Jan 23 13:24:29 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Fri Jan 23 13:24:29 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Runaway process
In-Reply-To: <20040123211913.GA8743@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040123211913.GA8743@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <20040123212357.GD30088@maybe.net>

On Fri, Jan 23, 2004 at 01:19:13PM -0800, Michael Montagne wrote:
> How do I kill a runaway command?  I started a "rm -rf" command on a
> huge directory and now it can't be killed.  I tried "kill -9" and
> "killall rm".

It's probably in "D" state, i.e., blocked by the kernel processing a
huge number of disk requests. If you kill -9'd it, and there aren't
real issues, it'll stop ... eventually.

chris kb7rnl =->

> Keeping in mind that not all drives are created equal, some other

> memory buffer exists? A drive with 2 MB of cache memory, verses newer
> drives with 8 MB will obviously perform differently...so you must
> compare apples w/ apples. I am assuming you may have considered these
> things in comparing the two (WD?) drives.  Not to get off subject, but
> Maxtor has some nice features of late...speaking of speed and such.
> Also concider, IDE v.s. SCSI etc, (but I know you must be doing this)?

> 

The old one that's performing well (~18MB/s) is a Maxtor with a 2MB
buffer on a separate debian system. It has the following parameters set:

/dev/hda:
 multcount    = 16 (on)
 I/O support  =  0 (default 16-bit)
 unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
 using_dma    =  1 (on)
 keepsettings =  0 (off)
 nowerr       =  0 (off)
 readonly     =  0 (off)
 readahead    =  8 (on)
 geometry     = 1860/255/63, sectors = 29888820, start = 0
 busstate     =  1 (on)

On this machine, I have two nearly identical 120GB WD drives (with 8MB
buffers), both performing the same. These are performing poorly (~7MB/s)
and have these parameters set:

/dev/hdb:
 multcount    = 16 (on)
 IO_support   =  0 (default 16-bit)
 unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
 using_dma    =  0 (off)
 keepsettings =  0 (off)
 readonly     =  0 (off)
 readahead    =  8 (on)
 geometry     = 14589/255/63, sectors = 234375000, start = 0

Judging from the article posted earlier, DMA ought to speed things up
considerably. I do have the VIA chipset and I was experiencing the
"Operation not permitted" error. I have just now recompiled my kernel
with both of those flags on. I'll see if the error goes away once I
reboot in the new kernel.

Thanks for everyone's information!

Evan

Nice! I didn't even have to touch anything. The drive now has the
following flags:

/dev/hdb:
 multcount    = 16 (on)
 IO_support   =  1 (32-bit)
 unmaskirq    =  1 (on)
 using_dma    =  1 (on)
 keepsettings =  0 (off)
 readonly     =  0 (off)
 readahead    =  8 (on)
 geometry     = 14589/255/63, sectors = 234375000, start = 0

Apparently, my startup scripts were trying to set those flags all along
but couldn't because of the kernel issue. Now that the kernel has
support for it, I get the following much better benchmarks:

# hdparm -tT /dev/hdb

/dev/hdb:
 Timing buffer-cache reads:   1528 MB in  2.00 seconds = 762.86 MB/sec
 Timing buffered disk reads:  166 MB in  3.02 seconds =  55.06 MB/sec
