From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jan 23 14:22:01 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri Jan 23 14:22:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Runaway process
In-Reply-To: <20040123214116.GA8956@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040123211913.GA8743@themontagnes.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401231328310.32107@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <20040123214116.GA8956@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <20801-96216@sneakemail.com>

On Fri, 23 Jan 2004, Michael Montagne michael-at-themontagnes.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Not reiser, ext2.
> It also is not in D state. This is ps output:
>
> root      8532 81.9  0.1  1800  452 ?        R    12:58  31:52 rm -i -rf doug
>
> Weird, cause I also did not use the -i flag.  -f should force it
> anyways, I guess.

The "-i" comes from a RedHat default for root.  If you type "alais" it
will show you that "rm" has been aliased to "rm -i".  To avoid the alias
you can either use "-f" or use /bin/rm instead of just "rm".

> kill -9 8532 does not do anything.  There is no feedback whatsoever.

Is that process still accumulating CPU time?  If not, it's probably stuck
on an I/O somewhere.  (Though "ps" should have reflected that...)

  -- Steve

From cwells at commandprompt.com  Fri Jan 23 14:39:02 2004
From: cwells at commandprompt.com (Cliff Wells)
Date: Fri Jan 23 14:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Runaway process
In-Reply-To: <20040123211913.GA8743@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040123211913.GA8743@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <4011A27A.2060700@commandprompt.com>

Michael Montagne wrote:

>How do I kill a runaway command?  I started a "rm -rf" command on a
>huge directory and now it can't be killed.  I tried "kill -9" and
>"killall rm".
>
>  
>
If the process is still attached to a console, you can sometimes kill a 
process that doesn't seem to accept ^C by suspending it (^Z) and then 
'kill %n' the job (where n is determined by the output of 'jobs').   For 
some reason suspending the process always seems to work even when 
killing it doesn't.

Cliff

From edasher at javelin.net  Fri Jan 23 16:00:27 2004
From: edasher at javelin.net (Erik)
Date: Fri Jan 23 16:00:27 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Displaying in TV with GeForce MX 5200
Message-ID: <000501c3e20c$f3309c40$0b01a8c0@lemonhead>

Vincent,

Regarding your pre X-Windows video mode issues, there are a couple of
things I know of that may help:

1.	Use VGA=ASK in your lilo or grub configuration.  During boot,
you should be prompted to enter a video mode and provided a list of
video modes that you can choose from.  When you find one that works, you
can make the setting permant in lilo or grub.

I'm using vga=791, which sets my text mode to 48k x 60hz, 1024x768x 64k
colors.

Check
http://gate.csl.mtu.edu/lxr/http/source/Documentation/fb/vesafb.txt for
better documentation and a list of possible video modes.

2.	You could install and configure SVGATextMode, a linux utility
that helps with this kind of thing.  I've never used it so I can't write
to it's effectiveness, by my research indicates it has a decent
reputation on other LUG lists.

Hope that helps.  I assume you already know this, but be careful not to
cook your TV or monitor.
-EcD

--__--__--

It's a kernel process flushing dirty buffers to disk. If it's really
sucking up all your processing power so frequently, perhaps you don't
have enough RAM? Just a guess, though.

From chris at maybe.net  Fri Jan 23 17:07:02 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Fri Jan 23 17:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] kupdated - What is it?
In-Reply-To: <1074902223.2190.12.camel@timmy>
References: <1074896767.2184.8.camel@timmy> <20040124004847.GA4667@maybe.net> <1074902223.2190.12.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040124010648.GC4667@maybe.net>

On Fri, Jan 23, 2004 at 03:57:03PM -0800, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> On Fri, 2004-01-23 at 16:48, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> > It's a kernel process flushing dirty buffers to disk. If it's really
> > sucking up all your processing power so frequently, perhaps you don't
> > have enough RAM? Just a guess, though.
> 
> I've got what seems to be plenty of RAM (774044K). From what I've since
> read, it seems the problem might have been caused by my pitifully slow
> HD. Now that's it's sped up by a factor of 8, maybe the problem will
> disappear.
> 
> By the way, what is a "dirty buffer"?

Changes have been made to memory buffer (making it "dirty"), and some
process has requested data or memory be swapped/read in on top of it,
so the kernel has to write out the old buffer first.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Date: Fri Jan 23 22:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Proper setup of HOSTAP Driver in client mode
Message-ID: <20040124062231.GA27546@gate.kl-ic.com>

Greetings (especially to AthlonRob, Russ, and Mike Rassmussen, who
know more than I do about HostAP):

if I need to do some reconfiguration.

First, like AthlonRob, I was running wlan-ng.  On top of Redhat 9.
Headache city.  Also like A-R, I was under the mistaken impression
that HostAP was only for running Access Points.  Silly me.

Keegan Quinn at ptp pointed out that HostAP would improve my life,
and would operate in client ("Managed") mode.  So I ripped out
important bits of wlan-ng, then installed HostAP, and built a few
ifcfg- files.  I will describe a bit of what I did, and please
correct me if I kludged too stinkily.

First, the wlan-ng tearout;  I moved the old wlan-ng driver from
/lib/modules/<mykernel>/pcmcia/prism2_cs.o to a directory .../pcmcia/old/ .
Then I moved the wlan* files in /etc/pcmcia to /etc/pcmcia/old/ .  

I ran the make script for hostap-driver, with the make script modified
to point to my kernel source.  Then I made and installed hostap-utils.  

After that, kluging began.  I wrote a configuration file
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-wlan0, with ESSID=ANY .
Then I built a /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-klsg, with
ESSID=KLSG (my home network) and KEY="##########" (my WEP key). 
I also built a few other ifcfg- files, for personaltelco, tmobile,
boingo, and wayport, should I find myself in places with multiple APs.

I suspect there is a better way to do this, but right now, when
I insert my card, the system hotplugs the drivers and tries to
connect to an open AP in the vicinity.  It will automagically
find the ESSIDs for www.personaltelco.net or tmobile, for example.
It won't have much luck with my WEPed home network, so in that case
I type "ifdown wlan0" followed by "ifup klsg" and it connects.  I
do something similar if it connects to the wrong open site where
there is a choice. 

However I suspect there is a cleaner way to do this.  Any suggestions?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

Why do you have to pay to use these drivers and license them on
a card per card basis?  I'm trying to get the builtin Soundmaker
Cadenza on my D845PEBT2 to work under Linux.  I'm extremely
frustrated because I specifically picked this motherboard to be
Linux compatible in the first place.  Does the organization 
running www.opensound.com ever release versions of OSS under 
the GPL?  Not only can I not find free drivers, Intel is 
distributing the wrong ones for people using the D845PEBT2 
under Linux.

One thing I don't get is why Intel doesn't distribute sound card
drivers for a single card instead of distributing huge packages
containing multiple drivers?  I go to all the trouble of searching
on my specific desktop board only to find that Intel won't give me 
the specific driver I need giving me the wrong ones instead on a
page their support search engine misleads me to.

If the sound card wasn't permanently integrated into the motherboard
and case, I'd have jerked it and replaced with a Linux compatible one 
a long time ago.  How can I avoid making the same mistake with another 
desktop board purchase in the future?  The fee to buy an OSS license 
is $20 for the personal version alone.  Even if the driver works, you 
not only don't get to see the source code, you aren't allowed to use 
it on multiple machines without licensing a copy for each one.  They
say you get upgrades for a year, but do they ever give the drivers 
to you under a GPL license when they move on to other hardware?

To install third party sound drivers to kernel source, do I need to 
say no to sound card support or do I just exclude stock kernel 
source drivers?  Is not distributing or information on how to write
one the means by which Intel discourages use of their Pentium 4 
systems for Linux workstations?  I wonder if anyone can hack this 
sound system and release a free driver?  I'd rather sell it and 
pick up an Athlon than work around this issue, I don't want a 
bunch of dead ports or a nightmere scenario when I try to dual
boot Windows and it detects the disabled sound card.

On Friday 23 January 2004 19:28 pm, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> I have been having some issues with the system clock getting set back
> whenever I boot. I have isolated the problem to something that gets
> run during the init process. When I boot with init=/bin/bash, the
> time remains intact. The time is also not disrupted by a Windows boot
> or being off for some time.
>
> I think it always sets the clock back by half an hour, but after this
> latest boot I'm not quite sure. My time zone is set correctly (I
> think):
>
> /etc/localtime -> /usr/share/zoneinfo/America/Vancouver
>
> This is really puzzling. Even if the timezone is wrong, the date
> shouldn't be getting adjusted, should it?
>
> Thanks,
> Evan
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

One thought here...

When dual booting, Linux expects the hardware clock to be in UTC while 
Windows keeps it set to local time. What you need to do is keep the 
haredware clock set to local time and make sure in your date/time setup  
you have in Linux is set so that it specifies that the hardware clock 
is on local not UTC time.

Tony

From john at johntelford.com  Sat Jan 24 13:35:02 2004
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Sat Jan 24 13:35:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix-STD
Message-ID: <r02010000-1032-0B87D9344EB511D8BD60000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>

Here's something useful for your networking and security tool kit.

Knoppix-STD is a customized distribution of the Knoppix Live Linux CD
<http://www.knopper.net/knoppix/index-en.html>.  "KNOPPIX is a bootable
CD with a collection of GNU/Linux software, automatic hardware
detection, and support for many graphics cards, sound cards, SCSI and
USB devices and other peripherals.  KNOPPIX can be used as a Linux demo,
educational CD, rescue system, or adapted and used as a platform for
commercial software product demos. It is not necessary to install
anything on a hard disk. Due to on-the-fly decompression, the CD can
have up to 2 GB of executable software installed on it."

Knoppix-STD focuses on security and network management tools.  It is
meant to be used by both the novice looking to learn more about
networking and security, and the professional looking for another swiss
army knife for their tool kit.

The Knoppix-STD 0.1 iso image is available at
<http://www.knoppix-std.org/>

Burn it and give it a spin.  You may like it.

...John

Web: http://www.johntelford.com  Weblog: http://ITnews.johntelford.com

On 22 Jan 2004, none wrote:

>Why do you have to pay to use these drivers and license them on
>a card per card basis?  I'm trying to get the builtin Soundmaker
>Cadenza on my D845PEBT2 to work under Linux.  I'm extremely
>frustrated because I specifically picked this motherboard to be
>Linux compatible in the first place.  Does the organization 
>running www.opensound.com ever release versions of OSS under 
>the GPL?  Not only can I not find free drivers, Intel is 
>distributing the wrong ones for people using the D845PEBT2 
>under Linux.

>From a quick Google seach, it appears that you have four choices:
1) buy some stinking $20 close-source driver and have to spend
   at least another $20 within a year (not to mention the pain of
   getting a new driver version whenever you update/change your
   kernel)
2) buy a supported sound card ("real" Sound Blaster cards has 
   always "just worked" for me. ENU here in Portland sells them
   for as little as $16, you can probably mail order them for less).
   Odds are very good that a currently supported ~$10-20 sound card
   will be fully supported for more than one year ;-)
3) You can buy a new motherboard/cpu/memory setup with a supported
   onboard sound card (the most expensive possible solution)
4) "Silence is golden"
5) I may be wrong

<snip>
>If the sound card wasn't permanently integrated into the motherboard
>and case, I'd have jerked it and replaced with a Linux compatible one 
>a long time ago. 
<snip>

You can have multiple sound cards, just has you can have multiple
network or video cards. Usually you can disable the on-board sound
card in BIOS and the operating system will not be able to detect/see
it. Under Linux you can have multiple sound cards active and set
the default one by editing /etc/modules.conf.

>
>     --  Michael Robinson

Welcome back ;-)

-Eric

> whenever I boot. I have isolated the problem to something that gets run
> during the init process. When I boot with init=/bin/bash, the time
> remains intact. The time is also not disrupted by a Windows boot or
> being off for some time.

Linux expects the system clock to speak GMT.  Windows does not.  You
might want to google to find out how to let it know the clock is also
set to that timezone instead of GMT.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Jan 25 00:27:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Jan 25 00:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] X server wedged, how to close shells gracefully (as possible)
In-Reply-To: <hs19s5.3m2@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <hs19s5.3m2@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86isj0mo1p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com> writes:

Russell> I have a longrunning X server wedged with some xterms open on
Russell> it.  I'd like to recover the command histories from the
Russell> shells in the xterms. How?  I tried (with test shells)
Russell> killing with various likely signals, and they didn't save the
Russell> histories before dying.  I tried to kill -SEGV but couldn't
Russell> find the core files if they were created.

Russell> Any clues?

Ahh.  I got my xserver back.  There were two running, on :0 and :1.
Something went haywire with the one on :1 (vague anecdotal association
is running acroread within mozilla).  The something prevented me from
switching virtual consoles.  From another machine, I was able to kill
the :1 xserver (my wife's, heh).  The server on :0 was still runnning
but I couldn't switch to it.  I had tried an Alt-SysRq-r with no
visible effect.  From the other machine, I eventually discovered that
the keyboard on the "frozen" machine was working (I started a process
that I could see from the remote machine).  I realized that I was
typing into a shell, even though I couldn't see anything but a
corrupted version of the xserver on :0.  So, I exited the shell and,
presto, I could change virtual consoles again.  Woohoo!

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sun Jan 25 20:43:01 2004
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun Jan 25 20:43:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Finding application parent PID?
In-Reply-To: <200401251901.16916.alex@daniloff.com>
References: <200401251901.16916.alex@daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20040126044253.GA23879@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

I don't understand your question, but here are the answers to
questions you might be asking:

On Sun, Jan 25, 2004 at 07:01:16PM -0800, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> Assuming that I don't know the location of an application .pid file.

Are you referring to a file that acts like a lock of sorts, and
prevents the application from starting again?

These files don't have a standard location, or anything that defines
or requires their existence.  ~/.<programName>/ is a good place to
look, or search for <programName>.pid.  /var and /etc are also common
places for these files.

> How can I find or identify the application pid without using 
> 'ps -ef|grep application' or scanning all /proc/pid_number/cmdline 
> files?

If you just want the pid of a program, "pidof" works well.

$ pidof bash
5795 5794 7372

although you can't see which pid corresponds to which instance of the
program (obviously not an issue if there is only one instance
running).

If you are interested in the parents of a program, the f option
(--forest) to ps is fun.

$ ps -ef f

<snip>
root       599     1  0 Jan17 ?        S      0:00 /usr/bin/gdm
root     17742   599  0 Jan20 ?        S      0:00  \_ /usr/bin/gdm
root     17743 17742  6 Jan20 ?        S<   500:37      \_ /usr/X11R6/bin/X :0 -
rogue    17751 17742  0 Jan20 ?        S     47:55      \_ /usr/bin/enlightenmen
rogue    17799 17751  0 Jan20 ?        S      0:01          \_ /usr/bin/ssh-agen
rogue    17800 17751  0 Jan20 ?        S      0:11          \_ xscreensaver -nos
rogue    17804 17751  0 Jan20 ?        S      0:00          \_ licq
rogue    17805 17804  0 Jan20 ?        S      0:05          |   \_ licq
rogue    17806 17805  0 Jan20 ?        S      0:07          |       \_ licq
<snip>


Hopefully that helps someone.  If I didn't address your question, can
you clarify it?

-Rogan



From alex at daniloff.com  Sun Jan 25 21:18:02 2004
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Sun Jan 25 21:18:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Finding application parent PID?
In-Reply-To: <20040126044253.GA23879@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <200401251901.16916.alex@daniloff.com> <20040126044253.GA23879@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <200401252114.30068.alex@daniloff.com>

Hello Rogan, thanks for your reply

On Sunday 25 January 2004 08:42 pm, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> I don't understand your question, but here are the answers to
> questions you might be asking:

The question is very simple :)

Some applications have .pid files with the process id.
Look for example into /var/run directory
The other pid's are listed as directories in /proc.
There is a file cmdline in the each pid directory, which shows
with what command an application or a process was launched.

Now I want to determine pid of an application or a process without
using 'ps -ef|grep appl_name'  or scanning all /proc/proc_id/cmdline files.
pidof appl_name doesn't provide a definite answer all the time.

Is there any other way to find pid of application by the name of application 
or the name of its executable file?

Regards,

Alex





From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Sun Jan 25 21:59:02 2004
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sun Jan 25 21:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Finding application parent PID?
In-Reply-To: <200401252114.30068.alex@daniloff.com>
References: <200401251901.16916.alex@daniloff.com> <20040126044253.GA23879@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU> <200401252114.30068.alex@daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <20040126055828.GA23953@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Sun, Jan 25, 2004 at 09:14:30PM -0800, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Rogan, thanks for your reply
> 
> Now I want to determine pid of an application or a process without
> using 'ps -ef|grep appl_name'  or scanning all /proc/proc_id/cmdline files.
> pidof appl_name doesn't provide a definite answer all the time.
> 
> Is there any other way to find pid of application by the name of application 
> or the name of its executable file?

There probably are other methods, but I believe they are all
equivelent to the methods listed above.  

You must specify the instance of the program that you are interested
in.  The .pid files are usualy used when only one instance of a
program _can_ run at a time, or when it is unsafe to run multiple
copies of a program at once.  Licq does this because the typical user
dosen't want to have more than one instance running at a time.

If there are multiple instances of a program (say bash) running, how
would the system know which instance you wanted the pid of?  (pidof
provides the -s switch to return just one pid, but how it decides to
do this is unknown--I speculate that it returns the first one it
finds.)


What are you trying to accomplish overall (what are you doing with the
pid you find)? Perhaps we can help you find a solution.

-Rogan

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Sun Jan 25 23:02:02 2004
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Sun Jan 25 23:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The wrong app
In-Reply-To: <1074806235.3539.163.camel@nat.alcpress.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401252238240.15933-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On Thu, 22 Jan 2004, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I'm teaching a college course and I'd like to give my
> students some rough stats on how often people use the
> wrong program for given tasks. I see it frequently but
> I wonder if my experiences are typical....

I don't have any statistics.  In fact, I suspect one might
have a difficult time defining "wrong application" in an
objective way that would allow one to obtain meaningful
statistics.

On the other hand, anyone with any experience sees this problem
all the time.

I remember BLM/Oregon capturing meta data on their GIS inventory.
This involved capturing complex information about survey field notes,
physical maps, digital map files, and so on.  This resulted in
thousands and thousands of records - all captured as individual
MS Word documents.  Yes, MS Word!!  Just try to search these to
get a complete list of everything using State Plane Coordinates
or having a certain accuracy or containing data before a certain
date or ....  I don't know if BLM ever converted this stuff to
a data base or not, but the MS Word documents were filled with
trival inconsistancies which would have make the conversion
difficult and expensive.

On the other hand, BLM was one of the earliest organizations to
realize the difference between GIS (Geographic Information Systems)
and CAD or computer graphics.  To this day, one sees organizations
putting their maps into AutoCad or even paint packages without
ever considering the desirability of doing geometric calculations
and/or data base manipulation on the data.  You see this in city
engineering departments all the time.

Another app people seem to shy away from is statistics.  One sees
a lot of data analysis attempted in spread sheets that really
should to be done in a decent statistical package.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jan 26 05:08:03 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jan 26 05:08:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] group
In-Reply-To: <200401260344.TAA03352@smtp.gssf.org>
References: <200401260344.TAA03352@smtp.gssf.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401260453550.16841@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 25 Jan 2004, Guy Noire wrote:

> example..
>
> I belong to more then one group.
>
> I want to create a file with a specific group name.
>
> I want to change to that group before I create the file

As Rob mentioned, sg will work. The 'newgrp' utility will create a
subshell in which you assume a different gid.

My favorite approach, when all the files in a given directory will be
owned by a given group, is just to set the sticky bit on the parent
directory and let the filesystem do the work:

  [heinlein]$ groups
  heinlein wheel uucp
  [tmp]$ cd /tmp
  [tmp]$ mkdir grouptest
  [tmp]$ ls -ld grouptest/
  drwxr-xr-x    2 heinlein heinlein     4096 Jan 26 04:58 grouptest
  [tmp]$ cd grouptest/
  [grouptest]$ touch testfile
  [grouptest]$ ls -l testfile
  -rw-r--r--    1 heinlein heinlein        0 Jan 26 04:58 testfile
  [grouptest]$ cd ..
  [tmp]$ chgrp wheel grouptest
  [tmp]$ chmod g+ws grouptest
  [tmp]$ ls -ld grouptest/
  drwxrwsr-x    2 heinlein wheel        4096 Jan 26 04:58 grouptest
  [tmp]$ cd grouptest
  [grouptest]$ touch test2
  [grouptest]$ ls -l
  total 0
  -rw-r--r--    1 heinlein wheel           0 Jan 26 05:00 test2
  -rw-r--r--    1 heinlein heinlein        0 Jan 26 04:58 testfile

>From that point on, any file created in that directory will be owned
by the 'wheel' group.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Jan 26 06:53:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon Jan 26 06:53:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The wrong app
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401252238240.15933-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401252238240.15933-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401260617370.19991@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 25 Jan 2004, David Mandel wrote:

> I don't have any statistics.  In fact, I suspect one might have a
> difficult time defining "wrong application" in an objective way that would
> allow one to obtain meaningful statistics.

  I'll add two mis-uses of applications and validate Dave's comments on GIS
and statistics. I've seen too many people try to use a spreadsheet rather
than a database and a flat-file database rather than a relational one.

  One instance of the latter that I clearly remember from more than a decade
ago involved a local medical research unit at a hospital not to be named.
They kept patient data in a DOS DBMS (R-base), but no one there knew 1) how
to design or normalize a database or 2) how to use the relational features
of R-base. There was, of course, no relational integrity and every time one
patient had a new procedure another column was added to the table, even if
there was only 1 record with a value for that attribute.

  I reorganized that database in Paradox and discovered a number of
duplicate records; some were identical, some were inconsistent. In any case,
the results of queries were different between the R-base table and the
Paradox tables. "Research" papers were written based on these queries.

  Unfortunately, I did not handle the situation as tactfully as I should
have done so I suspect that not much as done to correct the errors.

> On the other hand, BLM was one of the earliest organizations to realize
> the difference between GIS (Geographic Information Systems) and CAD or
> computer graphics.  To this day, one sees organizations putting their maps
> into AutoCad or even paint packages without ever considering the
> desirability of doing geometric calculations and/or data base manipulation
> on the data.  You see this in city engineering departments all the time.

  In my environmental work I've seen not only the use of CAD or other
drawing packages used when a GIS was the proper application, but a more
egregious error: not understanding the differences between mapping and
spatial analyses. There is a huge difference between the two. With the
former (on a GIS, not on a CAD) one can ask "what's here?" or "where is
...?". With the latter one can ask "why do we see mass wasting (landslides)
here and not there?" or "what is the total runoff from this drainage basin
with precipitation total of X cm in Y time?".

> Another app people seem to shy away from is statistics.  One sees a lot of
> data analysis attempted in spread sheets that really should to be done in
> a decent statistical package.

  This is another area where too many users don't understand the knowledge
underlying the tool. Years ago, someone discovered that the standard
deviation function in Lotus-1-2-3 (on DOS) used the population formula, not
the sample formula. It does make a difference in the results. Apparently the
coders didn't understand statistics, either.

  I worked on a project in the mid-1990s where an engineering consultancy
(PE's, all of 'em) was looking at the settling rate of a filled site. They
set out stakes in a grid and surveyed the elevation of each stake top over
time. Then they did multiple T-tests to see if there were any differences in
the settling rate at different places along the fill surface. There were two
problems here.

  First, when comparing multiple data sets, and asking if the between-set
variance is greater than the within-set variance, the proper statistic is
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), not the T-test which is for two data sets.
Also, the consultants discarded data that showed a rise in elevation at a
stake because that "was not expected".

  Second, since the objective was to determine if the fill had fully settled
and compacted, or was still moving (which would determine the weight of
structures built on it), the appropriate analysis was that of a Time Series,
not just ANOVA. Unfortunately, the engineers used an increasing time period
between samples so time series analyses was not possible.

  My client gave them my report and had them re-do the entire study at no
extra charge. Of course, it delayed development for a couple of years while
the data were collected properly.

  The analogy I've used for years with reference to GIS and spatial analyses
also applies to statistical software. I tell people that you can teach
someone how to use a word processor, but that does not make her a writer.
Similarly, you can teach someone how to use a GIS (or statistical) software
application, but that does not make her a spatial analyst (or statistician).

  So, Ed, in addition to "wrong" applications being used there is the danger
of not understanding the underlying system that the application automates. I
don't know that one problem is more serious than is the other. Both are bad,
IMO.

Rich

On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 10:22, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Is there a way to stop a process, with Ctrl-Z for example, save it's
> state, reboot, and then start the process again where it left off?

I don't think so, not without the process being involved.  There is a
patch that lets you suspend the whole running system to disk.  you can
then reboot, poweroff, etc...  It does use the swap space so you can't
run just anything in the meantime.

On Mon, 26 Jan 2004, Guy Noire wrote:

> >  [tmp]$ chmod g+ws grouptest
>
> What is this in octal??

The problem is that octal perms are absolute, not relative. Assuming
that the grouptest directory originally had drwxr-xr-x (0755) perms,
then it'd be

  chmod 2775 grouptest

But octal perms can't be used for something like "give the group owner
write permission on all files and directories below this point." I
mean, you probably know that, but ...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 26 10:02:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Jan 26 10:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] UML
In-Reply-To: <200401252318.53599.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <200401252318.53599.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <1075140114.5744.249.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Sun, 2004-01-25 at 23:18, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> Anyone here have some experience with user mode linux?

A little bit, yes.  I've run them locally to play with and am leasing
one for $5/month in Canada.

> I'm trying to set up a UML instance (or three) to run Debian on top of my 
> Gentoo machine.  

You shouldn't have any problems.  Wait... then again... Gentoo... did
you enable any grsecurity things?  It has been rumored (but I haven't
seen any tests) that grsecurity may well break uml.

> I've got a UML kernel built (2.4.23) and I think I've configured everything 
> correctly.  However, when I have md support in the kernel, it just stops cold 
> when it starts doing the speed tests for various kinds of md RAID5 checksum 
> calculations (i.e. using MMX, SSE or 8087 registers).  When I take md support 
> out, it seems to get fairly far.

Forgive my ignorance... md is *not* multidisk, right?  It is something
else?  Why don't you start with one of their precompiled kernels and
test beginning with that?

> I got a minimal Debian image off of the UML site on Source Forge.  This 
> doesn't appear to come with a kernel.  In trying to use mine, I found that I 
> had to make /dev/ubd/0 point to /dev/ubd0.  The devfs-like path wasn't 
> already there and the kernel persists in trying to use it.  I thought that I 
> had devfs turned off in the kernel...

The UML devs decided they liked devfs for some reason, so it's default. 
The kernel looks for its root filesystem on /dev/ubd/0, all devfs
style.  To disable devfs, you need to install the device files, make
that ubd symlink and adjust the commandline used to boot the UML;

./linux-2.4.19-5 eth0=tuntap,tap0 mem=16M devfs=nomount

...assuming the kernel is built with devfs, as their provided kernels
are.  I think due to distros not providing a ubd device file to begin
with, they decided devfs would be easier to implement across
distributions.

> The kernel boots, finds the root image (a big file, not COW) and seems to 
> start moving right along.  Until it gets to the end of the boot process for 
> run level 2.  Then nothing happens.  No login prompt:

> After this, nothing at all happens.  The last things that runs 
> is /etc/init.d/rmnologin.  This is some sort of guard against allowing logins 
> during boot that Debian appears to use.  

Do you know you can mount that root_fs loopback?  Just do it, go in, and
fix the scripts.  Look at the logs.  Figure out from there, I think.... 
:-)

> Is it just a bad image?  Should I get another Debian image from somewhere?  
> 
> I'm totally new to UML, so I'm sure I'm asking dumb questions :-)

I haven't used the debian filesystems, only the slackware 8.1 one and a
friend made a 9.1 image he shared with me.

I think your best bet would be to start off with as many of their
defaults as possible; use their kernel to begin with, then start playing
with making your own kernel so you can rule out the image as being the
source of any problems.

Have fun, UMLs are real cool!  :-)

Rob

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Jan 26 13:36:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)

On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 12:31, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 10:01, AthlonRob wrote:
>
> > A little bit, yes.  I've run them locally to play with and am leasing
> > one for $5/month in Canada.
> 
> What site is that?

http://vps.pigscanfly.ca

Overall, I would say it is worth the $5/month for the 16MB UML.  You get
your own IP address.  5GB/month over the Internet, which (in my
experience) hasn't been able to pull more than 30KB/sec down.

I'm running bind, postfix, openvpn, sshd, and apache on there.  I do
still have room to spare (about 6MB of RAM, believe it or not).  Getting
it set up, initially, was a bit of a pain.

After they set up the box, they email you your root password.  I can
tell you right now what it is, it doesn't seem to change.  You log in. 
If you reboot, you may hose their network setup, ending up with some
downtime; about five hours last time when I rebooted.

After I got the box, they had only given me about 200MB of space,
instead of a full gig.  When they resized it (on a live system, I'm
guessing), they hosed the filesystem and I had to start from scratch
again... no biggy, I had only put in about three hours on the thing.

Other issues... hmmm... their default image is Slackware, which is
great, but it is version 8.1, which is outdated a bit.  Several people
are running Debian on the system, I've seen.

They rebooted me twenty three hours ago for no apparent reason, I didn't
get any notice about it.  My init scripts work, though.  <g>

Before the reboot (I don't know about now, I haven't checked) there was
a significant security hole on the UML host.  It is significant enough
that you do *not* want to store anything on the box you wouldn't be okay
with fifty other people being able to see.

The real plus is it's only five bucks a month, and comes with a static
IP.  What I plan on using it for (they don't have reverse DNS working
yet) is a smart relay for postfix.  It's already working as backup DNS
just fine.  It's set up for backup MX, as well, but I haven't changed my
zone files to include it as an MX yet.

For five bucks a month, I can't complain too much... :-)

Rob

On Mon, 26 Jan 2004 14:43:30 -0800 (PST)
Matt Alexander <m at pdxlug.org> wrote:

>In Perl I can use ? to stop after the first match.
>
>Does anyone know how to do the same type of lazy/minimal-matching in vim?
>
>
>

:%s/search-for-string/replacement-string/        once only
:%s/search-for-string/replacement-string/g       global  
:%s/search-for-string/replacement-string/gc      global confirm

This is only the answer if I understood the question.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jan 26 14:59:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401260823030.29866@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
 <200401262243.OAA03770@smtp.gssf.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401261451040.29866@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 26 Jan 2004, Guy Noire wrote:

> >> >  [tmp]$ chmod g+ws grouptest
> >>
> >> What is this in octal??
> >
> >The problem is that octal perms are absolute, not relative.
> >Assuming that the grouptest directory originally had drwxr-xr-x
> >(0755) perms, then it'd be
> >
> >  chmod 2775 grouptest
>
>
> Aren't chmod g+ws and 2777 the same??

No. The first is relative; it will do nothing but adjust the group and
sticky bits, regardless of the original perms. It's a bitwise
operation.

The second is absolute; it'll overwrite all existing perms withe the
specified mask. No bitwise ops are needed; just rewrite the perms.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

OK...  here's a little more info on my problem...

Here's a line of text...

something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.

I don't know what the text is before each period, and I don't know how
many periods will appear, but after the first period that I encounter I
want to insert a tab after that period.  The following does not work:

:%s/\(^.*\.\)/\1\t/

The problem with this is that it would match everything up to the very
last period and would substitute the tab at the end.  Yes, I could use
Perl, but I encounter this problem all the time and I'd like to be able to
do it from within vim.

From mikeraz at patch.com  Mon Jan 26 15:03:31 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)

Message-ID: <20040126230218.GB27660@patch.com>

On Mon, Jan 26, 2004 at 02:41:41PM -0800, Guy Noire wrote:
> >that the grouptest directory originally had drwxr-xr-x (0755) perms,
> >then it'd be
> >
> >  chmod 2775 grouptest
> 
> 
> Aren't chmod g+ws and 2777 the same??

Not with the presumed original perms of 0755.  Chmod o+ws would create 2777, if 
sticky meant anything for the other crowd.   The g+ws gives write permission to 
the group.

For the symbolic chmod:
  u - user who owns it
  g - group
  o - others

Bad nmeonics to my way of thinks since "o" maps to owner.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jan 26 15:13:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon Jan 26 15:13:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] group
In-Reply-To: <20040126230218.GB27660@patch.com>
References: <200401260344.TAA03352@smtp.gssf.org>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401260453550.16841@pecos.madboa.com> <200401261418.GAA16756@smtp.gssf.org>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401260823030.29866@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
 <200401262243.OAA03770@smtp.gssf.org> <20040126230218.GB27660@patch.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401261506170.29866@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 26 Jan 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:

> Not with the presumed original perms of 0755.  Chmod o+ws would
> create 2777, if sticky meant anything for the other crowd.

Not exactly. chmod o+s does mean something, but it's meaning varies
depending on whether it applies to a directory or a regular file.

In the case of a directory, it means something to the effect of
"prevent anyone from removing or renaming a file in a directory except
the owner." Check out the perms on /tmp:

  [heinlein at glenfiddich tmp]$ ls -ld /tmp
  drwxrwxrwt   14 root     root         4096 Jan 26 15:03 /tmp

See the 't' at the end of perm string? That's what it means.

In the case of a file, doing chmod o+s will save a program's image to
swap, sometimes reducing load time.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Mon Jan 26 15:14:02 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Mon Jan 26 15:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] vim regex lazy/minimal-matching?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401261455490.6576-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401261441100.6576-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401261455490.6576-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <20040126231300.GH17570@dalsemi.com>

On Mon, Jan 26, 2004 at 03:02:29PM -0800, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> OK...  here's a little more info on my problem...
> 
> Here's a line of text...
> 
> something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.
> 
> I don't know what the text is before each period, and I don't know how
> many periods will appear, but after the first period that I encounter I
> want to insert a tab after that period.  The following does not work:
> 
> :%s/\(^.*\.\)/\1\t/

I don't know if you've ever read anyting written by Damian Conway,
but one of his central concepts in parsing is to identify what's
important and throw the rest away.

So, slightly restating your problem, you want to insert a
tab after the first period:

:%s/\./.\t/

Now back to the original problem.  How do you make * less greedy in
vim?  As far as I know, you can't.  But you can use a different idiom
to state what you're looking for:

:%s/([^\.]+\.)/\1\t/

You use an inverted character class.  Find anything but periods,
followed by a period.  Replace that with what you found followed
by a tab.  That's perl regex syntax, so you'll need to find out
how vim does it, but it should translate pretty easily if it's
different.

Colin

Traditionally, yes.  But not in the case of Linux based systems:

(man page)
STICKY FILES
       On  older  Unix  systems,  the sticky bit caused executable files to be
       hoarded in swap space.  This feature is not useful on  modern  VM  sys-
       tems, and the Linux kernel ignores the sticky bit on files.  Other ker-
       nels may use the sticky bit on files for system-defined  purposes.   On
       some systems, only the superuser can set the sticky bit on files.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Mon Jan 26 15:58:01 2004

On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 15:02, Matt Alexander wrote:
> On Mon, 26 Jan 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:

> > In Perl I can use ? to stop after the first match.
> > 
> > Does anyone know how to do the same type of lazy/minimal-matching in vim?

> 
> Here's a line of text...

> something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.

Ummm, this is going to sound too simple but:

s/\./.^I

Does what you want.  Find a '.' and replace it with a .TAB

Unless 'g' is given, 's' only works on the first one.

So to be clearer the line

something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep

And I hit

        :s/\./.zot
Becomes:

something.zot  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.

Is this what you want?

> > OK...  here's a little more info on my problem...
> > 
> > Here's a line of text...
> > 
> > something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.
> > 
> 
> Ummm, this is going to sound too simple but:
> 
> s/\./.^I
> 
> Does what you want.  Find a '.' and replace it with a .TAB
> 
> Unless 'g' is given, 's' only works on the first one.
> 
> So to be clearer the line
> 
> something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep
> 
> And I hit
> 
>         :s/\./.zot
> Becomes:
> 
> something.zot  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.
> 
> Is this what you want?


Yes, that works.  I was just using an example to see if it was possible to
do minimal-matching with vim.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jan 26 16:51:02 2004

On Mon, 26 Jan 2004, Russell Senior wrote:
>   a) who has tried the freezer trick;

Me.

>   b) if the freezer trick worked on not;

Yes.  Twice.

>   c) describe the freezer trick that they used.

I wrapped the drive in a towel and then put it in a plastic bag and placed
it in the freezer for four or five hours.  (The towel and bag were my
guess at how to eliminate condensation and ice forming on the metal
surfaces... seemed to work.)

While the drive was really, really cold, I hooked it up to a system and
started a dd.

One time doing this, the drive started clicking about 3/4 of the way
through and I could no longer read, so it went back in the freezer
overnight and I started the dd again in the morning.  Apparently it warmed
too fast.

I don't know anything about why this worked, but I've read some educated
guesses.  But I can say that I've used it with success.

> It'd be kind of handy to get the old data off the mortally wounded
> drive.

Aye.

From dzl at frenetic.com  Mon Jan 26 17:45:03 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Mon Jan 26 17:45:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] vim regex lazy/minimal-matching?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401261455490.6576-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>

Matt Alexander wrote:
> On Mon, 26 Jan 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> 
>>In Perl I can use ? to stop after the first match.
>>
>>Does anyone know how to do the same type of lazy/minimal-matching in vim?
> 
> 
> 
> OK...  here's a little more info on my problem...
> 
> Here's a line of text...
> 
> something.  something.  something else.  maybe something else too.  yep.
> 
> I don't know what the text is before each period, and I don't know how
> many periods will appear, but after the first period that I encounter I
> want to insert a tab after that period.  The following does not work:
> 
> :%s/\(^.*\.\)/\1\t/
> 
> The problem with this is that it would match everything up to the very
> last period and would substitute the tab at the end.  Yes, I could use
> Perl, but I encounter this problem all the time and I'd like to be able to
> do it from within vim.
> Thanks,
> ~M


I think what you're after in vim is \{-} so your pattern above would be:
:%s/\(^.{-}\.\)/\1\t/





From garl.grigsby at ugsplm.com  Mon Jan 26 17:49:02 2004
From: garl.grigsby at ugsplm.com (Grigsby, Garl)
Date: Mon Jan 26 17:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sound and Mime?
Message-ID: <159441354A896D4A8886543D5043BC31B228F4@uscimplm001.net.plm.eds.com>

> Via Browser.  It used to work before upgrade  (RH -> Fedora)
> I seem to have Realplayer8 installed, but it no longer works.

Assuming you have Mozilla, if not it will be slightly different:

Edit - Preferences - Helper Applications - New Type 

MIME type: audio/x-pn-realaudio
Description: Real Media Files
File extension: rm, ram, ra
Open With: /usr/X11/bin/realplay "%u"
Uncheck: Always ask me before......

Ok. 
Restart Browser.

> > I've got a UML kernel built (2.4.23) and I think I've configured
> > everything correctly.  However, when I have md support in the kernel, it
> > just stops cold when it starts doing the speed tests for various kinds of
> > md RAID5 checksum calculations (i.e. using MMX, SSE or 8087 registers). 
> > When I take md support out, it seems to get fairly far.
>
> Forgive my ignorance... md is *not* multidisk, right?  It is something
> else?  Why don't you start with one of their precompiled kernels and
> test beginning with that?

Yes, for some reason it was in the default UML kernel.  It is very useful to 
have MD in UML so that tests of RAID configurations etc. can be done.  Other 
posters explained this at length.

> > I got a minimal Debian image off of the UML site on Source Forge.  This
> > doesn't appear to come with a kernel.  In trying to use mine, I found
> > that I had to make /dev/ubd/0 point to /dev/ubd0.  The devfs-like path
> > wasn't already there and the kernel persists in trying to use it.  I
> > thought that I had devfs turned off in the kernel...
>
> The UML devs decided they liked devfs for some reason, so it's default.
> The kernel looks for its root filesystem on /dev/ubd/0, all devfs
> style.  To disable devfs, you need to install the device files, make
> that ubd symlink and adjust the commandline used to boot the UML;
>
> ./linux-2.4.19-5 eth0=tuntap,tap0 mem=16M devfs=nomount
>
> ...assuming the kernel is built with devfs, as their provided kernels
> are.  I think due to distros not providing a ubd device file to begin
> with, they decided devfs would be easier to implement across
> distributions.

I turned off devfs completely in the kernel and still had this problem.   I 
worked around it by creating a hard link from /dev/ubd/0 to /dev/ubd0.

> > The kernel boots, finds the root image (a big file, not COW) and seems to
> > start moving right along.  Until it gets to the end of the boot process
> > for run level 2.  Then nothing happens.  No login prompt:
> >
> > After this, nothing at all happens.  The last things that runs
> > is /etc/init.d/rmnologin.  This is some sort of guard against allowing
> > logins during boot that Debian appears to use.
>
> Do you know you can mount that root_fs loopback?  Just do it, go in, and
> fix the scripts.  Look at the logs.  Figure out from there, I think....

Yep, that's how I fixed up /dev :-)

Logging does start, but I need to check how much it is logging.  I should set 
that to the most logging possible.  

It is acting very much like it is simply waiting for someone to log in, but 
tha the mgetty start up didn't work. I've checked /etc/inittab and it should 
be starting, and respawing, mgetty.

> :-)

> > Is it just a bad image?  Should I get another Debian image from
> > somewhere?
> >

They seem quite interesting.  I've also found QEMU, which was able to boot and 
get a ways into KNOPPIX before something went wrong with the X support.  It 
should be working, but didn't.  I will be interested to compare UML and QEMU.  
Since QEMU is basically a replacement for VMWare, it should be able to boot 
and run nearly anything eventually.  Right now Linux seems to work fine and 
it reasonably fast.  Once I figure out how to make X pretend to be a local 
server, I'll be fine (this isn't remote X, that's easy).

There's also FauMachine, Bochs and plex86 (the Source Forge project is more 
recent than the Savannah project).  Bochs will run nearly everything I've 
thrown at it, but tends to be about two orders of magnitude slower than 
QEMU :-(

KNOPPIX, AFAIK, boots with an initrd that includes a cloop module for
the kernel you boot with.  It then mounts the big image file with that
cloop driver.... I don't think they use zisofs.

On Monday 26 January 2004 19:24, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 19:10, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> > > A little bit, yes.  I've run them locally to play with and am leasing
> > > one for $5/month in Canada.
> >
> > I saw the thread on that.  Sounds very interesting.  How's performance?
>
> I wouldn't know where to test that, even.  :-)
>
> I suppose I could play with bzip2 and stuff?  bind, apache, sshd,
> they're all responsive as I would expect on such a shared machine.

Yeah, how to test performance is a good question.  User-land code should run 
pretty well unless it does a lot of IO or somehow interacts a lot with the 
kernel.  Heavily threaded apps probably aren't too great.

> > I turned off devfs completely in the kernel and still had this problem.  
> > I worked around it by creating a hard link from /dev/ubd/0 to /dev/ubd0.
>
> You can pass root=/dev/ubd0 to the kernel for that.

Here's the command line the ends up with it asking for /dev/ubd/0:

linux root=/dev/ubd0 ubd0=root_fs

You'll note that I did NOT put "root=/dev/ubd/0", yet that is what it is 
looking for :-(

> > I tried KNOPPIX, but the disk image seems to be unreadable for the
> > kernel.  I think I need the zisofs patches.
>
> KNOPPIX, AFAIK, boots with an initrd that includes a cloop module for
> the kernel you boot with.  It then mounts the big image file with that
> cloop driver.... I don't think they use zisofs.

Ah, I think you're right.  I'm going to try with something a little easier 
than KNOPPIX for a while :-)

UML looks very cool, but most of the images on the web site are quite old and 
may not even work with newer kernels.

Best,
Kyle

On Mon, Jan 26, 2004 at 05:22:47PM -0800, Bill Spears wrote:

> Via Browser.  It used to work before upgrade  (RH -> Fedora)
> I seem to have Realplayer8 installed, but it no longer works.

realplayer has trouble with the kernel installed by Fedora.
something to do with Posix threads.
As a workaround use this from the command line

env LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.4.19 realplay pnm://64.4.116.228/xyz.rm

or you could install  Realplayer9
http://rpm.pbone.net/index.php3/stat/4/idpl/713146/com/RealPlayer9-9.0.7.151-4.i386.rpm.html

Bill Barry

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Tue Jan 27 11:25:34 2004
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Tue Jan 27 11:25:34 2004
Subject: [PLUG] configuring Postfix relay to reject messages for specific recipients
Message-ID: <4016BB06.30002@easystreet.com>


Can anyone tell me how to configure a Postfix relay to reject messages for
specific recipients?  

-------

We have 2 Postfix systems (outside of the firewalls, on different ISP's) 
which
receive all e-mail for our company.  I.e.

     $ dig imoveinc.com mx
      ...
     ;; ANSWER SECTION:
     imoveinc.com.           14400   IN      MX      10 p5.imoveinc.com.
     imoveinc.com.           14400   IN      MX      20 p2.imoveinc.com.
      ...

As expected, these systems just talk to the external world and relay 
communiques
to the internal "imoveinc.com" mail server (Lotus Notes/Domino R5).  
Right now,
the Domino server is under a bit of a load.  And we would like to have 
our external
relays just ditch any messages for non-existant recipients like:

      john at imoveinc.com
      bill at imoveinc.com
      mike at imoveinc.com

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Tue Jan 27 11:50:02 2004
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Tue Jan 27 11:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] configuring Postfix relay to reject messages for specific recipients
In-Reply-To: <4016BB06.30002@easystreet.com>
References: <4016BB06.30002@easystreet.com>
Message-ID: <36852.207.173.0.68.1075232987.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> Can anyone tell me how to configure a Postfix relay to reject messages
> for specific recipients?

Am confused- do you want to reject mail to only some local valid users? 
Or reject all unknown users?  If the latter, in your main.cf file:

# REJECTING UNKNOWN LOCAL USERS
#
# The local_recipient_maps parameter specifies optional lookup tables
# with all names (not addresses) of users that are local with respect
# to $mydestination and $inet_interfaces.  If this parameter is
# defined, then the SMTP server will reject mail for unknown local
# users.
#
# If you use the default Postfix local delivery agent for local
# delivery, uncomment the definition below.
#
# Beware: if the Postfix SMTP server runs chrooted, you may have to
# copy the passwd (not shadow) database into the jail. This is
# system dependent.
#
local_recipient_maps = $alias_maps unix:passwd.byname

That is the easy part.  But when doing so, you have to tell postfix what
local users are valid.  One way to do so is by putting a symlink to
/etc/passwd under /var/spool/postfix/etc (on RH9, anyway).  For reasons I
don't remember, I have actually done a hard link but I think a symlink
will work too.

I believe that is all you need to do- but beware, if something goes wrong
and postfix can't identify the list of local users, it will 5xx reject all
incoming mail so you may want to test this carefully before implementing.

Regards

From dzl at frenetic.com  Tue Jan 27 12:49:02 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Tue Jan 27 12:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Testing files for existence in /proc
In-Reply-To: <200401271921.i0RJLIU19473@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200401271921.i0RJLIU19473@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <4016CE9C.3020208@frenetic.com>

Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> I need to test for existence files in /proc:
> /proc/pid_num/cmdline
> /proc/pid_num/exe
> /proc/pid_num/stat
> The unary file test operators in perl (-r -w -l -z and so on)
> don't work in this case. I believe 'cause these files are not real.
> 
> Could somebody please advise me a better way to check
> these files for existence.

The unary file tests work for me, both in perl and in bash. Perhaps the 
problem is you don't have permisions on the files you're testing. Most 
of the files in /proc/pid/ are readable only by the process owner, so 
even though you can see them if you ls /proc/pid/ testing for their 
existence gives a permision denied error, and returns false.

They are perfectly real files as far as the system is concerned.

Also, if you're just testing for existence perhaps the -e operator would 
be the best choice.

> I have a linux box with multiple CPU's.  How do I assign a process to
> one cpu?

The default Linux kernel doesn't have processor affinity (yet--there
are patches, if you're interested). Your processes will be balanced
across both CPU's automatically.

> This article has convinced me that Windows is better

Are you still there? As I read the article, I myself
was using Windows XP. Despite what some on this list
have said, after all was said and done, I couldn't get
the Promise drive controller to work with Linux on the
system I have. (Unless there is some kind of
workaround, that would limit me to "live"
distributions not needing HD access.)

Anyhow, back to the article. One advantage to Windows
is that, because of the activation requirement, people
don't dare modify their hardware. So you don't get
annoying calls from friends who tried such
modifications and don't know what they're doing.

Windows is closed source. You don't have to worry
about copyright infringement by independent
developers, as in the SCO business. I can't imagine,
though, why the author of the article didn't realize
that this means you can't make a custom kernel, and I
hardly consider this an advantage.

There were a couple of things he forgot to mention
about Windows XP. It rarely crashes, though individual
applications often do. This includes Outlook and MSIE,
two of the ones you use most often. Installing an
incompatible driver is the kiss of death: the system
won't boot. And, because the registry is NTFS and
cannot be edited by any other OS, some users have
resorted to installing multiple copies of XP as a
precaution. 

I didn't see any speed benchmarks. Those I have seen
elsewhere seem to show XP and Linux comparable in this
respect.

If you're serious about Windows, avoid reading books
about it by the MS Press. Third-party books which are
candid about the problems associated with Windows are
much more valuable.

> 
> You must specify the instance of the program that you are interested
> in.  The .pid files are usualy used when only one instance of a
> program _can_ run at a time, or when it is unsafe to run multiple
> copies of a program at once.  Licq does this because the typical user
> dosen't want to have more than one instance running at a time.
> 
> If there are multiple instances of a program (say bash) running, how
> would the system know which instance you wanted the pid of?  (pidof
> provides the -s switch to return just one pid, but how it decides to
> do this is unknown--I speculate that it returns the first one it
> finds.)
> 
> 
> What are you trying to accomplish overall (what are you doing with the
> pid you find)? Perhaps we can help you find a solution.
> 
> -Rogan
> 
> 
> > 
> > Regards,
> > 
> > Alex

grep <command> /proc/*/cmdline

The command will return the PID in the second level directory, if root. 
As stated before these directories are visible to owners.

Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM

From chris at maybe.net  Tue Jan 27 21:50:03 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Jan 27 21:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] multiple CPU's and process assignment
In-Reply-To: <1624.216.99.218.67.1075259820.squirrel@sautez.com>
References: <2108.134.244.174.76.1075242410.squirrel@sautez.com> <20040127233528.GC9433@maybe.net> <1624.216.99.218.67.1075259820.squirrel@sautez.com>
Message-ID: <20040128054921.GE9433@maybe.net>

On Tue, Jan 27, 2004 at 07:17:00PM -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
> > On Tue, Jan 27, 2004 at 02:26:50PM -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
> >> I have a linux box with multiple CPU's.  How do I assign a process
> >> to
> >> one cpu?
> >
> > The default Linux kernel doesn't have processor affinity (yet--there
> > are patches, if you're interested). Your processes will be balanced
> > across both CPU's automatically.
> 
> That is nice.  But I don't want the OS to automatically balance.  I
> want to select which processor the process will use.  I do this on our
> windows servers assigning the affinity in the task manager.  I'm sure
> there is some way in Linux.  I know I need the SMP processor for linux
> but don't know how to tell the OS to only have this process use a
> particular process only.

Yeah, I know.

> Is there such a way?  A tool?  A config file?  Not possible?

It is possible, though you'll need heavy patching in 2.4 and moderate
patching with a 2.6 kernel.

Aside: If you really do have >= 8 processors, skip the following
paragraph as you likely know it already. Others on the list may find
it interesting. And while I think I'm right, I'm not a CE, just a
CS/Math. :-)

It's not been a highly motivated feature, because in SMP systems that
are 4-way and below, you really won't see much of a performance
difference with user-controlled processor affinity. The only small
benefit you'll get is avoiding some cache flushes. Linux already does
a good job minimizing TLB flushes (and you'll get those even in UP
systems -- it's a fact of life for "multitasking"). And on small SMP
systems, the hardware will do cacheline snooping between the
processors, minimizing a CPU jump cost. (As I understand it.) In other
words, SMP hardware is *designed* for processor hopping.

Now, what you have in Windows is a throw down from larger enterprise
situations where all this really does matter, i.e., you shouldn't use
it in Windows for quads and below, either. Like Linux, increasingly,
Windows can run on really big systems. When your RAM isn't close
enough to a processor group such that they can snoop or when RAM
fetches are going to be longer, it does make sense to hint to the
scheduler that certain applications should be held together in the
same processor(s).

If you still really, really want to, I can do some further research
for you. It will be non-trivial until well into late-2.6 or 2.8
timeframe.

Again: As I Understand It.(tm) I've followed the kernel-traffic
summaries, and I understand that all of this is covered very well in
various flavors of the kernel, but that the mainline release is still
much more conservative with respect to NUMA features.

As far as how it works, iirc in one of the patches it was something
simple like:

If we assume the process pid in question is, say "543"; and assume you
want to bind it to processor "13", you would do

echo 13 > /proc/543/processor_affinity

(Oddly, I have a PPro system who's MPS tables list the two CPU's as
"0" and "13" and none else. And /proc/cpuinfo lists them like that. Go
figure.)

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 28 06:46:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jan 28 06:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] xfd: printing the displayed font table
In-Reply-To: <20040128055735.GG9433@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401271741450.25018@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <20040128055735.GG9433@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401280620020.31983@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 27 Jan 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:

> May I kibitz and ask:

  Sure, Chris.

> a) Why are you doing book illustrations for what don't sound like "user
> manual" things at screen resolution and DPI?  Your printer does at least
> 300dpi, if not 600dpi. And you'll be publishing a book at at least
> 1200dpi. I suspect a non-fullscreen 72dpi illustration will look like
> garbage.

  Tgif has verious modes for exporting both graphics and text. I set the
output so when I "print" the figure the output is .eps with embedded LaTeX
for the text.

> b) Why aren't you using LaTeX? It would avoid having to look up odd
> keystrokes and tends to do a much better job of laying out formulas
> anyways. I could give you several PDF files of homework I've done for my
> math degree if you'd like to see samples.

  The book is being written in LyX, the gui front end to LaTeX that saves a
huge learning curve. Of course, I have significant amounts of pure LaTeX
(which LyX disparagingly calls ERT for Evil Red Text because it displays in
red on the screen) in the text and many mathematical equations, both inline
and in display mode. The figures are embedded in figure floats and, when I
export to pdflatex are beautifly typeset (as is the rest of the text).

> You surely have valid reasons, so I know that open discussion would
> benefit the list. :-)

  Originally, I tried using xfig but had a terrible time getting curves
(such as simulated plot output of bell curves) to look good. In my search
for a solution I discovered at least 7 different 2D vector drawing packages
for linux. Among these are tgif, ipe, dia, sketch, grace, xfig and a couple
of more I cannot remember. Each has its adherents and long-time users.

  I asked about xfig on the lyx-users mail list and my experience with
getting nice looking curves easily was confirmed. So, that was eliminated. I
could not get sketch or dia installed; some dependencies related to gnome or
kde, IIRC. IPE looked good for a while but I ran into a hurdle and couldn't
find the answer in a couple of days. Tgif is quite a simple, but powerful
package. The key to getting up to speed is to know that the button hints
don'e appear on a pop-up window, but are displayed at the left end of the
status line on the bottom of the window. And, most properties can be
controlled by clicking on the appropriate icon; they cycle through the
available options.

  Tfig's author is really great about answering questions. The documentation
consists almost exclusively of a 65-page man page (yuck!) and the FAQs on
the Web site. It took a while for me to really understand how to get the
desired Greek letters and math symbols. But, when I did I wrote it up as a
3-step process and Bill put my explanation below his on the Web page.

  Drawing curves as I want them took some trial-and-error, but I'm almost
competent in quickly getting what I want. I use polyline mode to place the
nodes in approximately the proper locations. Then I change the line type to
interpolated spline to smooth the curve and adjust the shape.

  I need to get my book, "Quantifying Environmental Impact Assessments Using
Fuzzy Logic" to my publisher, Springer-Verlag, by mid-April so as long as it
works, I don't care which tool I use. Springer-Verlag has their own set of
LaTeX macros for their monographs (my book will probably be in their
"Environmental Management Series" of monographs) and they accept
camera-ready copy using LaTeX. I'm certainly learning a lot of LaTeX and LyX
from this project!

  An editor at another publisher told a friend of mine that it is highly
unusual for Springer-Verlag to ask to publish a book by a first-time book
author. They are the premier science publisher (others focus on text books)
so I'm quite honored. Sample chapters are available for any who are
interested; I've not yet had time to add them to my Web site.

HTH,

Rich

I know it's late in your development cycle, so disrupting workflow is
out of the question, but I'd highly recommend auctex-mode and
x-symbol-mode in xemacs over using LyX. Especially x-symbol-mode. It
will take things like \alpha and collapse it into a visual font
automagickally. But, it has shortcut keys as above, and you can find
out what they are by typing in the LaTeX code and then just sitting
the point right next to it and it will show you the key binding in the
minibuffer. So, e.g. \alpha is C-= a #. On top of auctex's otherwise
very helpful LaTeX support. :-)

  The math is sprinkled throughout the text. For example, the first 7
chapters of the book describe environmental impact analyses as they have
been done for the first 30+ years and where contention and legal challenge
arise. No math at all. In Part II, "The Modern Approach", there is a chapter
as an introduction to fuzzy sets, fuzzy logic and approximate reasoning.

method of taking social values (compared pair-wise across the entire set) in

eigen vector to come up with what Yager developed: an ordered, weighted
average (OWA). Again, lots of math.

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Wed Jan 28 09:01:01 2004
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed Jan 28 09:01:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] configuring Postfix relay to reject messages for specific
 recipients
In-Reply-To: <36852.207.173.0.68.1075232987.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <4016BB06.30002@easystreet.com> <36852.207.173.0.68.1075232987.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <4017EAB8.5040004@easystreet.com>

Steven Raymond wrote:

>>Can anyone tell me how to configure a Postfix relay to reject messages
>>for specific recipients?
>>    
>>
>
>Am confused- do you want to reject mail to only some local valid users? 
>Or reject all unknown users?  If the latter, in your main.cf file:
>
Steve,

Thanks for the pointer.  Other (non-mail system) projects are co-opting 
my time to
work on this, but I suspect the "local_recipient_maps"  parameter is 
what I need.

Without some experimentation, I'm not 100% sure it will work, as the 
actual mail
recipients don't have accounts on the relays.  But it sounds like just 
creating a
simple map of allowable usernames/addresses will work.  (Damn, another 
list to
maintain ... oh, well, it'll be less work than the SASL database 
required for the
road warriors SMTPAuth service on these boxes. :-) )

As Jeme mentioned, for the chroot'd daemon, you had to use the hard link 
since
the chroot environment won't follow a symlink out of it's "jail".

I shoulda posted this question months ago.  :-)

- Don

>
># REJECTING UNKNOWN LOCAL USERS
>#
># The local_recipient_maps parameter specifies optional lookup tables
># with all names (not addresses) of users that are local with respect
># to $mydestination and $inet_interfaces.  If this parameter is
># defined, then the SMTP server will reject mail for unknown local
># users.
>#
># If you use the default Postfix local delivery agent for local
># delivery, uncomment the definition below.
>#
># Beware: if the Postfix SMTP server runs chrooted, you may have to
># copy the passwd (not shadow) database into the jail. This is
># system dependent.
>#
>local_recipient_maps = $alias_maps unix:passwd.byname
>
>That is the easy part.  But when doing so, you have to tell postfix what
>local users are valid.  One way to do so is by putting a symlink to
>/etc/passwd under /var/spool/postfix/etc (on RH9, anyway).  For reasons I
>don't remember, I have actually done a hard link but I think a symlink
>will work too.
>
>I believe that is all you need to do- but beware, if something goes wrong
>and postfix can't identify the list of local users, it will 5xx reject all
>incoming mail so you may want to test this carefully before implementing.
>
>Regards
>
>
>
>
>

>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

Well, the names aren't in a list.  And the internal Domino R5 mail 
server does
"fuzzy" name matching, and it can't be turned off.  Hence, when a bozo sends
mail to a common first name like "bob at imoveinc.com" or "mary at imoveinc.com"
the blasted thing doesn't just say "no such user" and bounce the message, it
does it's best to find someone with a first/last name which approximates 
"bob"
or "mary".  So, the problem now is to figure out how to have the Postfix 
relays
(which actually receive the incoming mail) pre-qualify the addressee(s).  I
think Steve Raymond gave me the answer (Postfix' local_recipient_maps 
parameter),
and I hope to try it out soon.

- Don

"survival
of the fittest" cut in evolution.  All that HTML stuff makes it really 
hard to do
a clean reply on mailling lists such as this one.  Any chance you can 
configure
it to only send ASCII/text messages to "plug at lists.pdxlinux.org"?

From MSmith at clark.edu  Wed Jan 28 09:55:38 2004

Dear All,

 

I'm the UNIX / Linux program coordinator here at Clark College in
Vancouver.  The program is hoping to serve students who would like to
make their way into UNIX / Linux sys admin or technician jobs in our
area.  I would like to ask the help of this list in determining what
topics should be included in the program.  It would be great to have a
dialog about this on this list, but I would also hope to have face to
face meetings with those of you who can.

 

Here are topics our current (4 quarter) UNIX / Linux Certificate offers:

 

pc hardware fundamentals / repair

bash command line fundamentals

host system admin & security fundamentals

network admin & security fundamentals

bash shell programming

sed & awk

C

Perl

Java

UNIX system call programming interface (in C)

 

as well as general ed requirements

 

As you can see, there's only so much you can squeeze into 4 terms.  Do
we have our priorities straight?  What do you suggest?  Also we expect
that many certificate grads will already have an AS in Computer Network
Admin (CNET) or Software Solutions Development (SSD).  We are also
considering expanding the Certificate Program into an AS degree - a 6
quarter sequence.

 

These are all pretty much introductory courses, and may change depending
on what kind of feedback we get from you.  A graduate of this program
would hopefully be someone who would be eligible for consideration as an
assistant system administrator / technician.  So the question becomes:

 

What topics / skills are needed to qualify as an entry level sys admin
assistant / technician?  Otherwise, what sort of position would the
above courses qualify a graduate for?

 

If you have suggestions that are way different or way more detailed than
this, I really want to hear about it!

 

Any help you can provide on or off this list is greatly appreciated,

 

Mark

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 28 10:15:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jan 28 10:15:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] please help with UNIX / Linux program at Clark College
In-Reply-To: <B52C1E7AE3795B499FF6DD3C957E762E26BCB4@odin.clark.edu>
References: <B52C1E7AE3795B499FF6DD3C957E762E26BCB4@odin.clark.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401281000180.32753@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, Smith, Mark wrote:

> I'm the UNIX / Linux program coordinator here at Clark College in
> Vancouver.  The program is hoping to serve students who would like to make
> their way into UNIX / Linux sys admin or technician jobs in our area.  I
> would like to ask the help of this list in determining what topics should
> be included in the program.  It would be great to have a dialog about this
> on this list, but I would also hope to have face to face meetings with
> those of you who can.

> Here are topics our current (4 quarter) UNIX / Linux Certificate offers:
>
> pc hardware fundamentals / repair

  This is not OS specific and quite probably not as good use of time as are
other topics.

> bash command line fundamentals
> host system admin & security fundamentals
> network admin & security fundamentals
> bash shell programming
> sed & awk
> C
> Perl
> Java
> UNIX system call programming interface (in C)

  Whew! What a mis-mash. I'm not a computer professional, but I've held
faculty positions at universities and taught both undergraduate and graduate
training. I'd like to offer my ideas; I'm sure the professional SysAdmins
will chime in with practical advice.

> As you can see, there's only so much you can squeeze into 4 terms.  Do we
> have our priorities straight?  What do you suggest?

  First, start off with a course in operating systems (very general) and
linux/UNIX overviews. What an OS does, what components it has, filesystems,
permissions, disk organization and so on. Andy Tannenbaum's book is probably
too out of date, but there was a relatively recent one called "Linux A-Z"
that was excellent. (I just sent it to a colleague I'm trying to
defenestrate so I don't recall the author's name.) This is the basis for
your systems administration and security training.

  Then have a course in TCP/IP networking. Cover all of networking, from
physical topology and media to administration and security. Flavor as
desired.

  Third, introduce shells (bash and others). Include shell scripting and
lead into the use of other administrative scripting languages such as perl
and python. sed and awk would fit into this portion, too, as they are all
related.

  Fourth, discuss the differences among linux distributions, the *BSDs
(including OpenBSD for it's solid security), solaris and other unices that
still have legs. Your graduates will probably need to work in different
environments and understanding the differences between BSD-style init script
and Sys-V init scripts, where files are found on the filesystems and so on
will be more valuable to them than programming languages.

  The SysAdmins I know and admire don't do either systems or applications
programming. Drop the C, java and system calls (that would be covered in the
language courses in any case). As Paul pointed out so well a couple of weeks
ago, the SysAdmins are the maintenance engineers in the computer hierarchy.
Programmers have a different role.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jan 28 10:30:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jan 28 10:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] please help with UNIX / Linux program at Clark College
In-Reply-To: <B52C1E7AE3795B499FF6DD3C957E762E26BCB4@odin.clark.edu>
References: <B52C1E7AE3795B499FF6DD3C957E762E26BCB4@odin.clark.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0401281012350.16841@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, Smith, Mark wrote:

> As you can see, there's only so much you can squeeze into 4 terms.
> Do we have our priorities straight?  What do you suggest?

Mark,

The topics/courses you list are all good and necessary, and I know
that focusing your students on acquiring technical skills needs to be
the heart of your curriculum. The topics I'm going to suggest are less
worthy of a course and more like meta-emphases applicable to many of
them:

* scaling

  Once you've got one system working well, how are you going to
  transfer your efforts to other systems? Configuration management,
  version control, and remote monitoring would be key topics here.

* documentation

  This is a subset of scaling, I suppose, but it deserves special
  mention. How do you document what you've done for a) management, b)
  users, and c) colleagues? The amount of wheel reinvention that goes
  on among sysadmins is staggering :-(

* communication

  - with management: How do you help company management make good IT
    decisions? How do you report on your work?

  - with users: How do you find out how well your systems are meeting
    users' expectations? How do you provide help-desk service? What
    medium of communication (verbal, hands-on, e-mail) is expected?

  - with community: How do you discover and adhere to standards (e.g.,
    RFCs, standard protocols, etc.)? How do you discover what help the
    technical community can offer? How do you provide help in return?

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
