From chris at maybe.net  Wed Jan 28 10:58:02 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Jan 28 10:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] please help with UNIX / Linux program at Clark College
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401281000180.32753@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <B52C1E7AE3795B499FF6DD3C957E762E26BCB4@odin.clark.edu> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401281000180.32753@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040128185730.GP9433@maybe.net>

On Wed, Jan 28, 2004 at 10:14:29AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   The SysAdmins I know and admire don't do either systems or applications
> programming. Drop the C, java and system calls (that would be covered in the
> language courses in any case). As Paul pointed out so well a couple of weeks
> ago, the SysAdmins are the maintenance engineers in the computer hierarchy.
> Programmers have a different role.

IME, a good sysadmin has a working knowledge of C -- this is
particularly important in the "Open Source Age". When there isn't
documentation, or when you're trying to figure out why the system
software is behaving in a peculiar way, it helps tremendously to
actually be able to "RTFS" as they say. One need not be able to build
software from the grond up, but being able to read and interpret code
as well as hack it a bit is invaluable as a sysadmin.

Plus, if you have to learn C and Perl and understand the subtle
differences between them, you have all the tools to be able to hack
just about any source out there. Kind of like learning Latin and, say,
Spanish and then being able to grok just about any other Romantic
language.

Plus plus, C is stricter than Perl, in general, so it will provide a
good mindset for writing more robust Perl scripts.

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From chris at maybe.net  Wed Jan 28 11:03:02 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Wed Jan 28 11:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Morning wakeup
In-Reply-To: <40180429.9060800@spek.org>

Message-ID: <20040128190240.GQ9433@maybe.net>

On Wed, Jan 28, 2004 at 10:49:13AM -0800, Brent Rieck wrote:
> The same thing used to happen to me until I reduced the size of my swap, 
> it was 2G because I had the vague idea that more was better.  I reduced 
> my swap size to the 1/2 size of ram (I have 512M ram, so 256M) and the 
> "morning wakeup" improved dramatically (as did a bunch of other
> things).

As I understand it, twice is better, but at least equivalent amount of
swap. The current kernels reserve the right to map every address in
RAM to swap, whether or not it's actually swapped out at the time. If
you have less swap, both the probably of processes being dismissed by
the kernel increases and level of "during the day" swap activity
increases.

If I'm wrong, I welcome someone to update my "brainbase" :)

You had a lot of good points here, Rich.

I had a college unix systems administration class back in (ouch) 1992 or
so. It was a very hands-on, lab work-based course and it really got me
hooked in the field.

Now that I think about it, I took the required prerequisite for it,
which was something like "Intro to UNIX and C programming". That one
covered the real basics, thinks like ls and all of its switches, basic
regular expressions via grep & sed, a bit of awk, the basics of job
control.

>   Then have a course in TCP/IP networking. Cover all of networking, from
> physical topology and media to administration and security. Flavor as
> desired.

If you're not really focused, this could stretch to a few semesters,
especially if you're going to talk about security and layer 1 and 2
stuff. I would probably stick to layer 3, with just enough
Ethernet-specific layer 2 work to explain arp, packet forwarding, etc.

>   Third, introduce shells (bash and others). Include shell scripting and
> lead into the use of other administrative scripting languages such as perl
> and python. sed and awk would fit into this portion, too, as they are all
> related.

Using bash is fine, and it is my favorite user shell, but for the
purposes of this class I'd probably stick to just the "sh" compatible
subset of features for shell scripting.

>   Fourth, discuss the differences among linux distributions, the *BSDs
> (including OpenBSD for it's solid security), solaris and other unices that
> still have legs. Your graduates will probably need to work in different
> environments and understanding the differences between BSD-style init script
> and Sys-V init scripts, where files are found on the filesystems and so on
> will be more valuable to them than programming languages.

Is it the purple Evi Nemeth book that has the big section on how to
perform common tasks on different flavors? Regardless, the Nemeth book
might make a good, albeit very expensive text to use. 

--Stafford

The registry is still just a flat file, sitting on the file system.

That's why Bill made the Windows CD with a recovery console. Although,

etc). In fact, I once wrote a how-to on how to compress and reindex your 
Windows 95 registry when I worked for one of the large software 
companies. Just like most databases, removed registry entries are NOT 
gone... Just marked as deleted, and ignored by the system. Just one of 
the reasons Windows gets slower as time goes on.

Also one of the reasons I run Linux. :)

Russ

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Jan 28 11:51:02 2004
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Wed Jan 28 11:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] configuring Postfix relay to reject messages for specific recipients
References: <4016BB06.30002@easystreet.com> <mailman.1075233033.24434.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86ptd3lv3k.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Steven" == Steven Raymond <stever at woo-hoo.com> writes:

Steven> That is the easy part.  But when doing so, you have to tell
Steven> postfix what local users are valid.  One way to do so is by
Steven> putting a symlink to /etc/passwd under /var/spool/postfix/etc
Steven> (on RH9, anyway).  For reasons I don't remember, I have
Steven> actually done a hard link but I think a symlink will work too.

A chrooted process cannot follow the symlink out of the jail.
And I recall a bug that lets a chrooted process get out of the jail
if a hardlink to an outside file is provided.

Best instead to either copy the passwd file via cron or as part of a
new user script.

That is how I accomplished things, as well.  I also set up some

spams in the last week or so... making much too large a list to
effectively check by hand.  When I can't do an "ls spam*" in the
directory, you know it's too much spam.

Of those ~4500 spams, about four have gotten through to my inbox.  :-(

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Wed Jan 28 13:38:01 2004
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Wed Jan 28 13:38:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] multiple CPU's and process assignment
In-Reply-To: <20040128054921.GE9433@maybe.net>
References: <2108.134.244.174.76.1075242410.squirrel@sautez.com>
    <20040127233528.GC9433@maybe.net>
    <1624.216.99.218.67.1075259820.squirrel@sautez.com>
    <20040128054921.GE9433@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <4812.134.244.174.76.1075325849.squirrel@sautez.com>

Chris,

Thank you for the detailed explainaton below.  It will help me explain
the possibilities to another.

Josh

> On Tue, Jan 27, 2004 at 07:17:00PM -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
>> > On Tue, Jan 27, 2004 at 02:26:50PM -0800, Josh Orchard wrote:
>> >> I have a linux box with multiple CPU's.  How do I assign a
>> process
>> >> to
>> >> one cpu?
>> >
>> > The default Linux kernel doesn't have processor affinity
>> (yet--there
>> > are patches, if you're interested). Your processes will be
>> balanced
>> > across both CPU's automatically.
>>
>> That is nice.  But I don't want the OS to automatically balance.  I
>> want to select which processor the process will use.  I do this on
>> our
>> windows servers assigning the affinity in the task manager.  I'm
>> sure
>> there is some way in Linux.  I know I need the SMP processor for
>> linux
>> but don't know how to tell the OS to only have this process use a
>> particular process only.
>
> Yeah, I know.
>
>> Is there such a way?  A tool?  A config file?  Not possible?
>
> It is possible, though you'll need heavy patching in 2.4 and moderate
> patching with a 2.6 kernel.
>
> Aside: If you really do have >= 8 processors, skip the following
> paragraph as you likely know it already. Others on the list may find
> it interesting. And while I think I'm right, I'm not a CE, just a
> CS/Math. :-)
>
> It's not been a highly motivated feature, because in SMP systems that
> are 4-way and below, you really won't see much of a performance
> difference with user-controlled processor affinity. The only small
> benefit you'll get is avoiding some cache flushes. Linux already does
> a good job minimizing TLB flushes (and you'll get those even in UP
> systems -- it's a fact of life for "multitasking"). And on small SMP
> systems, the hardware will do cacheline snooping between the
> processors, minimizing a CPU jump cost. (As I understand it.) In other
> words, SMP hardware is *designed* for processor hopping.
>
> Now, what you have in Windows is a throw down from larger enterprise
> situations where all this really does matter, i.e., you shouldn't use
> it in Windows for quads and below, either. Like Linux, increasingly,
> Windows can run on really big systems. When your RAM isn't close
> enough to a processor group such that they can snoop or when RAM
> fetches are going to be longer, it does make sense to hint to the
> scheduler that certain applications should be held together in the
> same processor(s).
>
> If you still really, really want to, I can do some further research
> for you. It will be non-trivial until well into late-2.6 or 2.8
> timeframe.
>
> Again: As I Understand It.(tm) I've followed the kernel-traffic
> summaries, and I understand that all of this is covered very well in
> various flavors of the kernel, but that the mainline release is still
> much more conservative with respect to NUMA features.
>
> As far as how it works, iirc in one of the patches it was something
> simple like:
>
> If we assume the process pid in question is, say "543"; and assume you
> want to bind it to processor "13", you would do
>
> echo 13 > /proc/543/processor_affinity
>
> (Oddly, I have a PPro system who's MPS tables list the two CPU's as
> "0" and "13" and none else. And /proc/cpuinfo lists them like that. Go
> figure.)
>
> --
> chris kb7rnl =->
>

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Jan 28 14:02:01 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Jan 28 14:02:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Morning wakeup
In-Reply-To: <20040128181828.GB8960@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040128181828.GB8960@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <22513-03392@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, Keith Lofstrom keithl-at-kl-ic.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> When I start using the systems in the morning, and bring everything up
> out of screen save, about 30 seconds is spent in "slow redraw mode". It
> feels like everything is being rebuilt out of swap disk or something.
> This may be because nightly backups using rsync are really thrashing the
> machines, so indeed every user process may be getting swapped out.  It
> may be something else.  Anyone else see this?

This is indeed what has happened.  All the file access has caused the
kernel to expand its filesystem buffers and swap out "unused" applications
to make room for them.

My solution:

# swapoff -a

Supposedly the 2.6 kernel will handle this situation better.

Check this PLUG post and related posts for more info:

http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/2003-September/022109.html

  -- Steve

On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, Dan Haskell wrote:
> The way I read the article, it is intended as an examination of local
> contributiors to the Linux movement. That's why they focused on people
> like Paul, Cliff, and Oso rather than RMS.

And I understand that and accept it.  But the author hadn't yet fully
decided on the tack he was going to take for the article when we spoke and
I feel like he took one of the least interesting approaches.

We actually had a little talk about how the WW seems to always be 10 years
behind the times.  This article is a good example of one that could have
been written ten years ago without too much difference (except the depth
of saturation, but that's sort of what makes it no longer "news").  So
while the direction the story took is totally understandable and in line
with the history of the WW, I kind of thought we might see something more
ground-breaking on this one.

Hope springs eternal, I guess.

By the way, I didn't think the article should focus on Stallman, just that
the concept of Free Software combined with the easy, ubiquitous networking
of the modern age are the reason something like Linux can take hold and
drives the development of all the other projects mentioned in the article.
The article continues the common misconception that Linux is an operating
system and not just a kernel and nothing is done to alter the other great
misconception that an operating system includes a windowing environment,
session management, spoolers, a web browser, and all the other cruft
Microsoft says it is.

I love the fact that there are great projects here in Portland and I
totally respect everybody involved in those projects, but personality
pieces don't really cut it as public education in my book and the article
just seemed to gloss over a few things that might actually help people
understand things better.

I'm really sleepy, so the words aren't flowing properly at the moment..
but hopefully I'm getting the idea across.

J.

I am wondering if this is the problem.

On the fedora site:

        ls *ftp*

I grabbed the only ftp server (vsftp), but there is no in.ftpd

        rpm -qlip vsftpd-1.2.0-5.i386.rpm | grep bin
        /usr/sbin/vsftpd

So, my guess is your system is running in.ftpd, or via inetd and its not
a fedora package.

Ignore Jeme's silly whine about dependencies.  RPM handles these quite
well (apt/yum/up2date handles the install better).

you can test on the system with

        rpm -qRif /usr/sbin/in.ftpd

Which will tell you which files are required and who owns the package.

>From an old system I see:

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401281430500.1208@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 2004-01-28 at 14:31, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> > Since I use cyrus and amavisd, all mail gets filtered by a system user
> > (amavis's user in this case), I run sa_learn as that user.
> 
> A ha!  This is what I do, too (on the system intended here, anyway).
> 
> So you just run sa-learn as the amavis user.


We actually I do a bit more.  I only care about me (I get the most mail)
so I only extra-learn from me (amavis is learning all the time).  As
root I grab mail from the cyrus files, chown it to amavis, razor the
uncaught spam (I have hand verified it), and then copy the caught spam
(I check the folder first, well sometimes), I copy it over, then I learn
it as spam.  Then I learn my HAM, which is very very litte.

My only problem is SA not catching mails titled like:

                          Subject: 
Re: CXUT, shop where bread

I had to up my level over 6 and this triggers 5.5:

X-Spam-Status:  No, hits=5.5 tagged_above=-999.0 required=6.3
tests=BAYES_99, HTML_MESSAGE

So my Bayes is dead on, but nothing else is triggering.  I have been
meaning to write a regex for SA to handle this.


spam_learn:
#!/bin/bash
echo "Removing Spam"
rm -f /tmp/spam/*
echo "Copying spam_notcaught"
cp -vpra /var/spool/imap/user/zot/spam_notcaught/[0-9]*\. /tmp/spam/
echo "chowning it...."
chown amavis.amavis /tmp/spam/*
echo "razoring it...."
su - amavis -c "razor-report -f /tmp/spam/*"
echo "Copying spam_notcaught"
cp -vpra /var/spool/imap/user/zot/spam/[0-9]*\. /tmp/spam/
chown amavis.amavis /tmp/spam/*
echo "Learn'n it."
su - amavis -c "sa-learn --showdots --spam --dir /tmp/spam/"

echo "Copying HAM"
rm -f /tmp/ham/*
cp -vpra /var/spool/imap/user/zot/spam_not/[0-9]*\. /tmp/ham/
echo "chowning it...."
chown amavis.amavis /tmp/ham/*
echo "Learn'n it."
su - amavis -c "sa-learn --showdots --ham --dir /tmp/ham/"

From ian at znark.com  Wed Jan 28 18:59:01 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed Jan 28 18:59:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ftp-fedora?
In-Reply-To: <1075328571.13866.19.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1075328571.13866.19.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <401876CD.9000003@znark.com>

Bill Spears wrote:
> When I try to ftp, on my LAN, I get this error (same error from 3
> different systems):
> 
> [me at zeus me]$ ftp apollo
> Connected to apollo (10.0.1.19).
> in.ftpd: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.2: cannot open
> shared object file: No such file or directory
> 
> The offending system was just upgraded from RH8 to Fedora Core 1.
 >

Did you upgrade the server or the client?  You can diagnosis the 
dependency problem by finding: a) what package is the FTP server

rpm -qf /usr/sbin/in.ftpd

b) what version of libssl it requires

rpm -q --requires <ftpd server package> | grep ssl

c) what version of openssl is installed

rpm -q openssl

d) what version of libssl it provides.

rpm -q --provides openssl

e) if anything provides libssl.so.2

rpm -q --whatprovides libssl.so.2

My guess of what happened is that the server was running wu-ftpd or 
proftpd as FTP server.  Fedora Core 1 only has vsftpd.  The FC1 
installer force upgraded openssl.  The orhpaned ftpd was left without 
its ssl libraries.

The solution is to install the openssl06b package.  It provides the 
libssl.so.2 library for RH8 and older packages.  Another option is to 
use the included vsftpd server.  If you are using wu-ftpd, you should 
definitely consider it since vsftpd is more secure.  If you were using 
proftpd, you can find a FC1 package from freshrpms.net.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/



From ian at znark.com  Wed Jan 28 19:10:02 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed Jan 28 19:10:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ftp-fedora?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401281504320.1208@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <1075328571.13866.19.camel@apollo.spears.org> <1075330181.17695.63.camel@dell.linux.box> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401281504320.1208@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <40187939.5070008@znark.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> Also, have you considered using a package management system that
> automatically handles dependency resolution so you don't have to deal with
> stuff like this?
> 

RPM keeps track of dependencies for Fedora.  The installer likely 
screwed up the dependencies for the old package when doing the upgrade. 
    I would call that an installer bug that results from turning off 
dependency checking when installing core packages.  If the installer was 
smart it would have installed the compatibility package.

Fedora includes yum which does dependency resolution.  yum doesn't have 
a way to check for broken dependencies.  But it does have a way to find 
dependencies: "yum provides libssl.so.2" will find the openssl096b 
provides the wayward library.

Fedora (and Red Hat) can also use apt for rpm.  APT will definitely 
diagnosis the problem with "apt-get check".  I don't think it will 
automatically fix the problem.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

>         ftp-0.17-18.i386.rpm                   ncftp-3.1.6-2.i386.rpm
>         ftpcopy-0.6.2-3.i386.rpm               tftp-0.33-2.i386.rpm
>         gftp-2.0.14-5.i386.rpm                
>         tftp-server-0.33-2.i386.rpm

I  don't know how you did that "ls *ftp*".  I did the time consuming
"yum search ftp" and got same results.  So since I was using wu-ftpd,
which comes with RH8, I came to the same conclusion. I considered Rob's
idea of scp, and will eventually go there, but, for X's sake I just
wanted to move some files around my lan(as far as I know, I don't offer
any services to the outside world).

> I grabbed the only ftp server (vsftp), but there is no in.ftpd
> 
>         rpm -qlip vsftpd-1.2.0-5.i386.rpm | grep bin
>         /usr/sbin/vsftpd
> 
Not sure what "i option" adds here.
> So, my guess is your system is running in.ftpd, or via inetd and its not
> a fedora package.
Nope, as I explained, I was running wu-ftpd, inherited from RH8.  Since 
I want to go with Fedora, I elected to dump wu-ftpd and install vsftpd.

I "yum install vsftpd"d and it worked, sort of. It only allowed
anonymous login's which is not what I wanted.

After swimming around in a deep sea of "I almost understand that", I got
it working the way I want.  Since I'm grateful for anyone that takes the
time to do these package thingies, I'm loath to criticise, but I think
the package install is not quite right for Fedora.  I had to read the
tar documentation, "Install", in order to get it working.  It's
installed so that you have to copy an example "conf" file into /etc, and
vsftpd.xinetd file into /etc/xinetd.d and edit it.  Also
/etc/vsftpd.conf has to have at least one line changed to run under
xinetd. If I were doing this as a package for Fedora, which I presume is
going to use xinetd, I would make these part of the initial install.  I
don't know how to handle the change to non-anoymous only.  I guess you
just have to know to read the "conf" file.

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Wed Jan 28 21:32:01 2004
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Wed Jan 28 21:32:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Adding numbers
In-Reply-To: <1075353544.20468.14.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <1075353544.20468.14.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <200401282142.04995.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

On Thursday 29 January 2004 12:19 am, Sean Whitney wrote:
> I'm grepping through some log files for some numbers.
>
> What can I do to total the values and print that out....  I'm sure there
> is a simple solution, it's just escaping me right now...
>
>
> Sean

Brute force:

[mark at caprice mark]$ sum=0; for n in `grep missing messages*|awk '{print 
$7}'`; do let 'sum = sum + n'; done; echo $sum

Must have the last command, i.e. echo $sum, on the same line as the "done" 
statement.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Wed Jan 28 22:49:01 2004
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed Jan 28 22:49:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Adding numbers
In-Reply-To: <1075353544.20468.14.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <1075353544.20468.14.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <20040129064826.GB26297@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>

echo "(print (+ " `grep missing messages*|awk '{print $7}'` "))" > /tmp/numbers

Then evaluate that with your favorite lisp.

$ clisp /tmp/numbers

6      
# or whatever that sum is...

Emacs's *scratch* buffer is great for this also, drop in the numbers,
wrap them in a big (+ ... ) and hit C-j on the last paren.

-Rogan

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 29 02:55:03 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Jan 29 02:55:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Adding numbers
In-Reply-To: <20040129073443.D7DEA180D@grayscale.canids>
References: <1075353544.20468.14.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>
	<20040129064826.GB26297@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU>
	<20040129073443.D7DEA180D@grayscale.canids>
Message-ID: <86isivowit.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Felix" == Felix Lee <felix.1 at canids.net> writes:

>> What can I do to total the values and print that out....  I'm sure
>> there is a simple solution, it's just escaping me right now...
>> grep missing messages*|awk '{print $7}'

Felix> awk ' BEGIN { total = 0 } /missing/ { total += $7 } END { print
Felix> total } ' messages*

That'll work, but the BEGIN clause is superfluous.  Variables default
to zero anyway, so it can reduce to:

  $ awk '/missing/ { total += $7 } END { print total }' messages*

If it was me, I'd be too lazy (when doing ad hoc stuff anyway) to type
out all five letters in "total", so I'd probably stick to something
shorter like "a", e.g.:

  $ awk '/missing/ { a += $7 } END { print a }' messages*

--

    from Russell Senior <seniorr@aracnet.com> 
References: <1075353544.20468.14.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org> <20040129064826.GB26297@sapphire.CS.ORST.EDU> <20040129073443.D7DEA180D@grayscale.canids>  <86isivowit.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> 
Message-ID: <20040129114554.C81B360@grayscale.canids>

Russell Senior <seniorr at aracnet.com>:
> That'll work, but the BEGIN clause is superfluous.  Variables default
> to zero anyway, so it can reduce to:
>   $ awk '/missing/ { total += $7 } END { print total }' messages*

no, variables default to null.  if no lines match, then your
version prints a blank line instead of 0.  another way of getting
0 is to say
    END { print total + 0 }
but I think that's conceptually weirder than using BEGIN to set
the initial value to 0.  initialization is a simple idea, it
transfers to any language.
--

Message-ID: <20040129020841.GD27032@nellump.net>

What is the general consensus [1] regarding the use of a swap partition
on a system with "plenty" of RAM? My daily driver has 512 MB of RAM,
and I've never bothered to set up a swap partition for it. So far, I
don't seem to lack anything in the performance department, but then I

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Jan 29 09:09:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Jan 29 09:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap or Not?
In-Reply-To: <20040129020841.GD27032@nellump.net>
References: <20040129020841.GD27032@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <3436-30005@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, Paul Mullen paul-at-nellump.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> What is the general consensus [1] regarding the use of a swap partition
> on a system with "plenty" of RAM? My daily driver has 512 MB of RAM, and
> I've never bothered to set up a swap partition for it. So far, I don't
> seem to lack anything in the performance department, but then I have
> nothing to compare to. Am I missing something here?

I don't think there is a general consensus so much as a mess of differing
opinions.  Here's a survey of some of the most popular and my take on
them:

1) Make swap 2x RAM

This is a very old rule of thumb, dating back from the PDP-11 days of
UNIX.  This kind of made sense once upon a time when RAM was hideously
expensive and the servers had a massively multiuser workload.  It was
important that things that remained unused were moved out of the way for
things that needed the RAM during the present.

I don't think this is a good rule for workstations (more on this later).

2) Make swap 1x RAM

On some UNIX systems if they don't have at least 1x swap, the system
doesn't use all the physical memory.  (HP-UX is like this by default)

I don't think Linux ever had this problem.

3) Make swap some small fixed size (i.e. 100MB)

This gives the system some small amount of room to swap out things that
are truly unused, but not so much that you're waiting large amounts of
time for things to be swapped back in.

If I have problems with option (4) below, this is where I go next.

4) Don't make any swap

If you have "plenty" of RAM this is the highest performance option.
However, if you ever see kscand hogging the CPU and system performance get
choppy, you'll know that you no longer have "plenty" of RAM and you may
want to get more (or turn on swap).  This choice eliminates the problem of
the kernel swapping out programs to make room for more disk buffers.
(This happens a lot on workstations, particularly if they run nightly
backups.  All the file activity coupled with litte or no application
activity fools the kernel into thinking all those apps you'll need the
next morning are "unused".)

  -- Steve

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Jan 29 10:17:02 2004

On Wed, Jan 28, 2004 at 09:19:04PM -0800, Sean Whitney wrote:
> I'm grepping through some log files for some numbers.  
> 
> What can I do to total the values and print that out....  I'm sure there
> is a simple solution, it's just escaping me right now...
> 
> 
> Sean
> 
> grep missing messages*|awk '{print $7}'

perl -lane '$a += $F[6] if /missing/; END{print $a}' messages*

If you don't mind a running summary:

perl -lane 'print ($a += $F[6]) if /missing/;' messages*

If you'd rather run use two processes instead of one:

grep missing messages* | perl -lane 'print ($a += $F[6]);' messages*

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jan 29 10:18:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Jan 29 10:18:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Network Config question
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F25iW9MAfKlUsY00035897@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F25iW9MAfKlUsY00035897@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <40194E34.6000109@dimstar.net>

Vincent Yau wrote:

>
> Thanks for your reply.
> I happen to have a linux box and 3 network cards
> at my disposal.  And I can use a hub so I want to
> turn one of my linux box into a hub.
> It looks like I can use IPCop on top of my current
> RH installation.
>
> Can I use IPCop to make my linux box function like a hub?

Please respond via the list. Thanks for understanding.

You can use your linux box as a hub, but I wouldn't want to do this. It 
increases the likelyhood of computer 2 or 3 losing their connection to 
the 'net. With hubs being as inexpensive as they are, it's easier to get 
a hub and plug each computer into that instead of daisy chaining computers.

Also with this kind of setup, you will have a much more difficult 
configuration. In addition, I'm not sure the second and third nic in 
computer 1 would be able to get an address via DHCP.

Russ

It might be wireless, it might be a Ethernet jack that gets to the Internet 
through the hotel DSL line.  

Usually you can ssh to your office.

When I was in Sidney Montana recently (pop 1,200 and big for the area) the hotel
had a Win95 box in the lobby on DSL for customer Internet access.  For ssh to 
the world:

	http://www.google.com
	search "putty download" click on "I'm feeling lucky"
	click on link for putty.exe
	select option to run from server
	ssh away!

The same technique can work from airport Internet kiosks.

On Thu, 2004-01-29 at 15:31, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Many thanks for the same answer. This now brings up a pertinent question:
> is there some documentation I can read so I can convert my Slackware-9.1
> notebook from static IP address (which is what I use here) and DHCP? I don't
> mind manually swapping config files, but I've never set up dhcp so I have no
> experience on what needs to be changed and how best to organize it all.

When I was running a static-ip network without DHCP (now I'm running a
pleasant mixture with a DHCP server always there for ease of setup of
new computers) I just ran dhcpcd eth0 when I wanted to use DHCP.  Make
sure the DHCP client daemon is installed on your system.

Otherwise, you could edit /etc/rc.d/rc.inet1.conf, but for something
like this, I'd just run the command manually.

Rob

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Jan 29 15:43:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu Jan 29 15:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap or Not?
In-Reply-To: <20040129020841.GD27032@nellump.net>
References: <20040129020841.GD27032@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <1075419905.1541.138.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2004-01-28 at 18:08, Paul Mullen wrote:
> What is the general consensus [1] regarding the use of a swap partition
> on a system with "plenty" of RAM? My daily driver has 512 MB of RAM,
> and I've never bothered to set up a swap partition for it. So far, I
> don't seem to lack anything in the performance department, but then I
> have nothing to compare to. Am I missing something here?

"Plenty" is a very relative term,  I have 512 MB in my workstation, but
I don't consider it to be plenty.  My kids would much rather use my
system instead of their own (they each have their own dual boot systems,
but mine is faster), so I have at least 4 different X sessions open at
the same time, with all kinds of programs loaded up.

What I've seen happen when the system runs out of memory is that
processes will be killed by the kernel, no warning, just gone.

With that much RAM, what I've been doing is setting up 2 swap
partitions, each about half the physical RAM.  This gives you a little
flexibility when trying to find the best compromise with the swap size. 
I personally think that if you have to swap more than your physical RAM,
you really should increase the amount of physical RAM (just from a
performance point of view).

The systems I've seen that have "plenty" of RAM and a swap file usually
put about 1 MB in the swap, and leave it at that.  These systems will
also show more than that as free (unused) RAM, they will also have huge
reserves for buffers and caches.

The only scenario that a larger than RAM swap makes sense is if you are
short on RAM (indicated by processed being killed off) and performing is
more important than performance (in other words, is a slow but working
machine better than a fast but limited machine).

To recap, having a large swap file with lots of RAM won't really hurt
you, unless you are actually using it a lot.  The advantage is that
performance will degrade, but the processes will keep running,  instead
of the alternative, which is processes being killed off.

HTH,

Derek Loree

(talk about the wrong way to use a poorly written app).

The Portland Holiday Inn off of I-205 and Stark area has 4 wireless access 
points using a captive portal username/login scheme - you get the 
username/password on checkin, and once you authenticate thru the portal you 
can do just about anything you'd expect to.  I did not have a linux box when 
I was visiting, so I am unable to address the specific configuration 
questions you may have. 

If you plan on travelling, be aware of whether the hotel you are visiting 
has hardwired or wireless access, so you can be prepared with the 
appropriate NIC.

A> Every hotel I have been on for business that advertises that had a
A> 10/100 port on/near the desk.  Most charge for it as well, i.e. it

I've had one place that had a DNS intercept that returned their A
record even for non-existent hostnames.  This was a problem for me on
some ssh'ing I was doing, because my ssh client was doing a IPv6 DNS
lookup for my home box, and it believed the IPv4 address (theirs) that
came back.  Evil.

Other than that, usually no problem these days.  Your port 25 might be
blocked, but ssh tunnelling will get around that.

From sean at fork.com  Thu Jan 29 19:51:01 2004
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Thu Jan 29 19:51:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] 'Net access from hotels
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401291459310.4726@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401291459310.4726@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1075434606.20523.31.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

You really have to take it with a grain of salt and call the hotel.

In the last 6 months, most of the places that I have stayed have had
"High Speed Internet Access have been fine", but

one hotel had 10 proprietary wireless pcmcia cards, and if you weren't
one of the first 10 people you were screwed.

another hotel had HSI access it was webtv.....

A third one had it but the first time I stayed there it didn't work in
my room.  I stayed there again a few days later (the reservation had
been made previously and it was only one night) and it worked in a
different room.

It's a crap shoot, and the front desk isn't going to be any help.
But if you do get a port and you get a lease, I haven't had many
problems.  I would however install a firewall.  I've been using
firestarter and I like it's flexibility.


Sean

From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)

On Thu, 29 Jan 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:

>Usually you can ssh to your office.
>
>When I was in Sidney Montana recently (pop 1,200 and big for the area) the hotel
>had a Win95 box in the lobby on DSL for customer Internet access.  For ssh to 
>the world:
>
>	http://www.google.com
>	search "putty download" click on "I'm feeling lucky"
>	click on link for putty.exe
>	select option to run from server
>	ssh away!
>
>The same technique can work from airport Internet kiosks.


Real men <beating my chest in an ape-like fashion> have mindterm
on a box that allows 0/0 http & ssh access. Why go through all
the trouble of installing software when java is usually enabled?

Travel war stories/tips:

Linux Expo Toronto (2000), I was with a number of people who (then and
now) hold high positions in the free-software world were "escorted"
out of the onlinejobs.com (or some other "hot at the time" job search
company) office for trying to hack the kiosk in their lobby. I managed
to break out using mindterm just seconds before the security guy 
showed up...

Many of the charge-for-DSL/Wireless setups I've seen only block
port 80, a few do DNS as well. If you know the IP address of a
server you have SSH access to, such info may not be be releavant.

At LWCE NY, we had an interesting experience. The SSID was 
"surf here", but it was really flaky. We managed to see that
port 80 was redirected to a "signup here" page. We called the
support number listed to complain that we were getting a bad connection
and they told us to call the hotel front desk and have them reboot the
AP (bad sign!). The front desk told us that there was no such AP in the
hotel. Call the other number back, relay the news, and they dig in further.
Turns out that the AP is in a phone booth (or something like that) a
block away from where we were. We found that if we held our laptops at
a 45 degree angle, DHCP + SSH suited our needs ;-)

-Eric

On Wed, Jan 28, 2004 at 06:08:41PM -0800, Paul Mullen wrote:
> What is the general consensus [1] regarding the use of a swap partition
> on a system with "plenty" of RAM?

Because if something goes wrong and springs a bad but slow memory leak, the
swap might be what saves your ass (though if it's a sudden, severe
memory leak, Sysrq-s sysrq-u sysrq-b is likely your only hope).

> My daily driver has 512 MB of RAM, and I've never bothered to set up
> a swap partition for it. So far, I don't seem to lack anything in
> the performance department, but then I have nothing to compare
> to. Am I missing something here?

Probably not if you're not getting out-of-memory errors.

On Thu, Jan 29, 2004 at 03:45:05PM -0800, Derek Loree wrote:
> "Plenty" is a very relative term,  I have 512 MB in my workstation, but

> the same time, with all kinds of programs loaded up.

Yeah, I frequently have multiple users logged in and doing stuff while
I'm playing GTA Vice City in WineX or something.  My machine
runs as sort of a general-purpose shell system for my friends, as well
as my personal machine.

> What I've seen happen when the system runs out of memory is that
> processes will be killed by the kernel, no warning, just gone.

Survival tactic, and not a bad one, really:  If something is eating
all the RAM, eventually it'll gun the offending process.

> To recap, having a large swap file with lots of RAM won't really hurt
> you, unless you are actually using it a lot.

But even then, only if performance matters.  Linux 2.6 has some pretty
amazing scheduling:  I'm able to do everything my machine does and
my machine still plays Vice City in an emulated environment than it
does on any PS2 I've seen[1].

> The advantage is that performance will degrade, but the processes
> will keep running, instead of the alternative, which is processes
> being killed off.


[1] I almost mistyped PS/2, but I imagine my statement is still true
even then...

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Thu Jan 29 22:11:01 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Thu Jan 29 22:11:01 2004

In-Reply-To: <20040130055136.GH26257@ursine.ca>

Message-ID: <1075442966.22462.5.camel@timmy>

On Thu, 2004-01-29 at 21:51, Paul Johnson wrote:
>
> > What I've seen happen when the system runs out of memory is that
> > processes will be killed by the kernel, no warning, just gone.
> 
> Survival tactic, and not a bad one, really:  If something is eating
> all the RAM, eventually it'll gun the offending process.

My experience has shown that it doesn't kill just the offending process,
but everything.

I had gpilotd go filling up memory one day. Before I knew what was
happening, it had filled up all my physical memory and the system froze
solid swapping out. I waited for quite some time while it filled up the
swap, all the while trying to get to a console to see what was going on.
After about 10 minutes every process except init was killed: ssh was
down, X down, everything killed.

It wouldn't be so bad if it killed just the process using up all the
RAM, but losing every process on the system is not a happy situation.

Just thought I'd share.

Evan

machines that act like anything I would consider to be fast.)

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jan 30 02:14:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jan 30 02:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap or Not?
In-Reply-To: <1075442966.22462.5.camel@timmy>
References: <20040129020841.GD27032@nellump.net>
	 <1075419905.1541.138.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <20040130055136.GH26257@ursine.ca>  <1075442966.22462.5.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <1075457761.1541.324.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2004-01-29 at 22:09, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> On Thu, 2004-01-29 at 21:51, Paul Johnson wrote:
> >
> > > What I've seen happen when the system runs out of memory is that
> > > processes will be killed by the kernel, no warning, just gone.
> > 
> > Survival tactic, and not a bad one, really:  If something is eating
> > all the RAM, eventually it'll gun the offending process.
> 
> My experience has shown that it doesn't kill just the offending process,
> but everything.

That has not been my experience.  For example, in the course of
modifying a Live CD image, on a system with just enough ram to run the
live CD , I ran the Debian program "dselect" before activating a swap
file.  Needless to say, updating, selecting and then installing consumed
all of the RAM, and it needed more.  Gracefully enough, it died, leaving
all other processed still running.  After activating a swap partition,
the program was able to start and run successfully.

I've seen this type of behavior on several occasions, so maybe it has
something to do with what process the kernel decides to kill.  (Like
killing the X-server, instead of the 10 mozilla widows that are open.) 
Granted, these were not run-a-way processes, just the processes that put
the system over the edge.
> 
> I had gpilotd go filling up memory one day. Before I knew what was
> happening, it had filled up all my physical memory and the system froze
> solid swapping out. I waited for quite some time while it filled up the
> swap, all the while trying to get to a console to see what was going on.
> After about 10 minutes every process except init was killed: ssh was
> down, X down, everything killed.
> 
> It wouldn't be so bad if it killed just the process using up all the
> RAM, but losing every process on the system is not a happy situation.

I wonder if it is killing processes that you seem to no longer be
interested in running, instead of the process that is using most of the
CPU time.
> 
> Just thought I'd share.
> 
Thanks, every little bit helps us get closer to understanding the whole
thing.

Derek Loree

FWIW... my Linksys WAP is turning out to be a piece of crap.  I bought
it in June while in Mississippi for $100.

It's an access point, wireless-wired bridge, four or five port 10/100
switch, and a router.  I use it as a WAP and wireless-wired bridge. 
Lately, it goes for about two weeks and starts dropping about 20% of the
wireless packets.  A few weeks after that, it just cuts out wireless
connectivity completely.  Unplugging it and plugging it back in, then
letting it sit for a few hours, on, fixes the problem.

I can't read the little model number right now... it's one of those with
four completely different (software-wise) revisions, so I'd have to look
at the bottom of it for the revision, too.  As far as I've been able to
tell, this one is *not* running Linux.

... slow response in morning ...
> This may be because nightly backups using rsync are really thrashing the
> machines, so indeed every user process may be getting swapped out.

Steve Bonds and Russell Senior suggested: swapoff -a .  This works,
but upon reflection this seems a bit dangerous.  If indeed I have
exhausted physical memory for some reason, then apps will get killed 
approximately randomly, right?  Not something I want to build into a
backup script run every night.

I was wondering if it would be possible to do something resembling
what I do to wake things up anyway, that is, select the various gnome
desktop workspaces, which apparently signals the apps to redraw
themselves, which causes the kernel to swap them back in.  Say a
kill -SIG<some-nonlethal-signal-here> on all the keithl-owned
processes.  Or some arcane signal to gnome.  Probably too hard.

Well, I will probably be installing Fedora Core 2 with a 2.6 kernel in
late April, and that should fix most of this.  Patience, Grasshopper!

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Jan 30 10:44:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jan 30 10:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Controlling grub from Windows?
In-Reply-To: <20040130174203.GA4759@edge>
References: <20040130174203.GA4759@edge>
Message-ID: <1075488328.1547.332.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2004-01-30 at 09:42, Bill Barry wrote:
> Here is the short question. Is there a way
> to edit grub.conf from Windows?
> 
> Here is the longer background.
> I have a dual boot machine that is headless. 
> with no keyboard or monitor.
> When it is in Windows I access it with VNC,
> when it is in linux I use ssh and X11 forwarding.
> The boot loader is grub. The default boot OS in
> grub is linux and when I want to boot to Windows
> I insert a boot floppy which has a grub.conf
> in which Windows is default.
> I would like to do this without the floppy.
> >From linux, I can edit grub.conf and tell it
> to reboot to Windows. But once in Windows I can't
> access grub.conf to tell it to boot back to linux.
> [while writing that last sentence I thought of
> one possibility. format the boot partition as fat32
> that way I could edit grub.conf from both OSes
> Will that work?]
> Thanks for any suggestions,

I don't know about grub, but with lilo, you can use the -R switch to
specify the default for the next boot as a one time deal.  The idea
being that right before issuing the reboot command, you would issue a
lilo -R command that would tell it to boot to winblows (something like
"lilo -R default=Windblows") instead of linux.  Then when you reboot out
of winblows, the original lilo.conf will be there ready to boot you back
to linux.

GRUB may have something similiar, and that sure sounds easier than
having a special boot partition.  (What would you do with it anyway, you
have no head?)

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jan 30 10:58:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Fri Jan 30 10:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Morning wakeup
In-Reply-To: <20040130161339.GA7061@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040130161339.GA7061@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <868yjp1cy4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> Steve Bonds and Russell Senior suggested: swapoff -a .  This
Keith> works, but upon reflection this seems a bit dangerous.  If
Keith> indeed I have exhausted physical memory for some reason, then
Keith> apps will get killed approximately randomly, right?  Not
Keith> something I want to build into a backup script run every night.

Just put the swapoff/swapon at the end of your script.  That will swap
everything back in that was swapped out during the backup and reenable
swap again.  Nothing gets killed.  Plenty of swap during the backup if
needed (probably not).  If your quiescent machine needs swap you are
in trouble anyway.  I think it's probably pretty safe.

Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

> >         tftp-server-0.33-2.i386.rpm
> >         lftp-2.6.5-4.i386.rpm                  vsftpd-1.2.0-5.i386.rpm

4)  I noted a lack of anything called ftpd-server, which is now
important.

> > 
> I  don't know how you did that "ls *ftp*".
(in ncftp, you should use it over "ftp" for a command line client)


> > I grabbed the only ftp server (vsftp), but there is no in.ftpd
> > 
> >         rpm -qlip vsftpd-1.2.0-5.i386.rpm | grep bin
> >         /usr/sbin/vsftpd
> > 

5) I noticed that there is no such thing as a in.ftpd in the only
standard fedora packages, so that led me to the conclusion that the
in.ftpd was loaded by you from another system, or was left on.

Pretty easy.

> > So, my guess is your system is running in.ftpd, or via inetd and its not
> > a fedora package.

> Not sure what "i option" adds here.

man rpm ->
       -i, --info
              Display   package  information,  including  name,  version,  and
              description.  This uses the --queryformat if one was  specified.

> Nope, as I explained, I was running wu-ftpd, inherited from RH8.  Since 
> I want to go with Fedora, I elected to dump wu-ftpd and install vsftpd.
> 

So it should be clear, in.ftpd was *from* the wu-ftpd package.


> I "yum install vsftpd"d and it worked, sort of. It only allowed
> anonymous login's which is not what I wanted.

I applaud redhat or vsftpd for this.  vs stands for very secure.  Users
using ftp send their system passwords in the clear.  Not secure.

> 
> After swimming around in a deep sea of "I almost understand that",
> installed so that you have to copy an example "conf" file into /etc, and
> vsftpd.xinetd file into /etc/xinetd.d and edit it.  Also
> /etc/vsftpd.conf has to have at least one line changed to run under
> xinetd. If I were doing this as a package for Fedora, which I presume is
> going to use xinetd, I would make these part of the initial install.

well if you do a rpm -ql on vsftpd you will see:

/etc/rc.d/init.d/vsftpd


So it uses the standard rc scripts not xinetd.  The RH guis should be
able to see this.

Or you can run chkconfig add vsftpd.  I hope it is not installed by
default.

>   I
> don't know how to handle the change to non-anoymous only.  I guess you
> just have to know to read the "conf" file.

>From the vsftpd.conf man file:

     userlist_enable
              If enabled, vsftpd will load a list of usernames, from the file-
              name given by userlist_file.  If a user tries to log in using  a
              name in this file, they will be denied before they are asked for
              a password. This may be useful in preventing cleartext passwords
              being transmitted. See also userlist_deny.

/etc/vsftpd.user_list:
# vsftpd userlist
# If userlist_deny=NO, only allow users in this file
# If userlist_deny=YES (default), never allow users in this file, and
# do not even prompt for a password.
# Note that the default vsftpd pam config also checks /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers
# for users that are denied.

So read up on these issues


> 
> > >From an old system I see:

> It's interesting that the offender "libssl.so.2" didn't show up.
> > 

Well it was from a RH6.2 image.  I guess wu-ftpd added ssl.

So not to harp on a subject, but if you run sshd, you then run sftp like
you run ftp.

Passwords work great.

No security issues with clear text.

No changes to the system.

After a short period, figure out keys.  It can be tricky getting
everything set, since typos cause hell.

Then learn about ssh-agent.  

Never look back.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri Jan 30 12:30:05 2004
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri Jan 30 12:30:05 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Controlling grub from Windows?
In-Reply-To: <20040130174203.GA4759@edge>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0401301220330.25363-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Fri, 30 Jan 2004, Bill Barry wrote:

> Here is the short question. Is there a way
> to edit grub.conf from Windows?
>
Having booted multiple OS's on one computer with
grub, the short answer is maybe.

The longer answer is this. Grub looks for the
grub.conf file as it starts, which (IIRC) is usually
on one of the Linux partitions (whatever /boot is mapped to).
If you can see the partition that the grub.conf is on
from Windows, you can do it.

Since then & now I would prefer to have as little
to do with the internals of Windows as possible, I
have no idea if there is a way to mount either a ext2 or
ext3 partition from Windows -- & I tend to doubt it can
be done.

Geoff

>   Is there any way to set up pine so that messages addressed to specific
> users are routed to specific files in ~/mail/?
> 
>   There are business-related messages that I keep and it would be handy to
> not have to manually replace 'sent-mail' for each one that goes to a
> projec/client file.
>

This may not be much help but I'm almost positive it's possible. I seem 
to remember doing it a few years ago when I was using Pine pretty much 
exclusively. I don't really remember how do it though, possibly in the 
address book somewhere.

mail to yourself, and then set up procmail rules to filter it where you 
want it to go.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Jan 30 16:20:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri Jan 30 16:20:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] pine: setting up fcc by addressee?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401300945480.7194@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401300945480.7194@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0401301617310.9327@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 30 Jan 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Is there any way to set up pine so that messages addressed to specific
> users are routed to specific files in ~/mail/?
>
>   There are business-related messages that I keep and it would be handy
> to not have to manually replace 'sent-mail' for each one that goes to a
> projec/client file.

The FCC can be set per address in your address book.  It's trivial.
Create an address book entry for the address and put the mbox in which
you'd like outbound messages saved as the FCC.

Whenever you compose a message to that person, the default FCC is set to
the proper outbound folder.

Roles can mess this up a bit, though, as they take precedence at compose
time.  It's a bit of a tricky situation, but if you delete the fcc line
with a ^K and then scroll up to To: and then back down, it'll set the FCC
to the one associated with that To: line.  Sounds weird, but it works
great and takes no time.  Just delete whatever FCC is set, make sure the
To: is set properly, then the FCC gets updated.

Of course, you're not going to read this because ignorance is more
important to you than tolerance.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jan 30 22:06:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Jan 30 22:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] tiny-box gateway routers, linux-based?
Message-ID: <20040131060455.GA10900@gate.kl-ic.com>

At the personal telco meeting Wednesday, Jim Thompson of netgate.com
(mail order network goodies out of Spokane) was showing a little box
from Taiwan they were planning on peddling for about $100.  It is like
a linksys WAP/Firewall/Router, except geared more towards the Linux
hacker, with handy things like a serial port for debugging.  It is
so new, they don't have a name for it yet.  PTP raffled one, and it
ended up with Greg Buchan.  Or at least the promise of one, more
beta units are on the way.

There was some discussion that these would make great PTP nodes, but
PTP is based on NoCat which is written in Perl, which is a bit large
for most embedded systems.  However, where there is a will ...

Again, this product is in beta, so we don't even have a name yet,
much less implementation details.  But talking with Greg, and with
his background in security, he seems to be just about the best
possible fellow to get that box.  Expect good things.

Keith

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Fri, 30 Jan 2004, Bill Barry wrote:

> On Fri, Jan 30, 2004 at 07:08:01PM -0800, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > Any Sonicwall users out there?  Have you found a way to keep your SSH
> > connections from being dropped after a few minutes of inactivity?
> > 
> 
> Are you sure this is Sonicwall specific. I am not using 
> Sonicwall, but had to do two things
> to keep my ssh connections from timing out.
> in /etc/ssh/ssh_config set KeepAlive yes
> and 
> echo 300 >/proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_keepalive_time

It is specific to the Sonicwall because I only have the problem when the
Sonicwall is between me and the server.  The Sonicwall is tearing down the
connection when it doesn't see any traffic for several minutes (which is
actually a good thing from the firewall's point of view).

"KeepAlive yes" is the default for SSH, but setting the tcp_keepalive_time
lower is an interesting solution.  Currently I see that it's set to 2
hours (at least on Fedora 1).  Setting it lower will affect all TCP
connections, not just SSH, that use KeepAlive but that should be fine and
hardly noticable on my laptop.
Thanks,
~M

From m at pdxlug.org  Sat Jan 31 07:04:02 2004
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat Jan 31 07:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Notebook firewall
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401310615060.10172@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401310651260.5132-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>

On Sat, 31 Jan 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Fri, 30 Jan 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> > iptables?  ;-)
> 
>   Sure. I guess I was thinking there was more that should be done.

As root, type:

    netstat -l -t -u

and see what comes back.


If you're not running any services, then you really don't have anything to
worry about since there's nothing for the outside world to connect to.
X is probably listening so you can disable that by changing

    :0 local /usr/X11R6/bin/X

to...

    :0 local /usr/X11R6/bin/X -nolisten tcp

In RH it's in /etc/X11/xdm/Xservers


Or you could use one of the many scripts for easily configuring iptables.
I've been happy with Arno's IPtables Firewall:

http://rocky.molphys.leidenuniv.nl/

You just set a few parameters in iptables-firewall.conf and start the
script and all the iptables magic is done for you.
~M

From ian at znark.com  Sat Jan 31 17:00:02 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sat Jan 31 17:00:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Sonicwall and SSH
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401301907040.8507-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401301907040.8507-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>

Matt Alexander wrote:
> Any Sonicwall users out there?  Have you found a way to keep your SSH
> connections from being dropped after a few minutes of inactivity?
> 

I recently figured out how to keep our Sonicwall at work from timing out 
connections.  There is a default inactivity timeout but this didn't seem 
to affect the connections.  There is also a timeout on each of the 
filter rules.  If you increase the timeout on the incoming SSH rule, 
then they won't timeout.

  - Ian

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jan 31 17:43:03 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat Jan 31 17:43:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Another hard linux lesson learned: oops!
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0401311715540.11667@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  In my naivety, I believed that /usr/local contained only locally-installed
applications went into /usr/local; that distribution upgrades would not
overwrite that file system so it was "safe". I am no longer naive.

  For reasons I can not explain, my Red Hat 7.3 system has libc.so.6 in
/usr/local/lib, while the Slackware 9.1 systems have libc.so.6 in /usr/lib
and /lib/. So, in the process of moving applications from the Red Hat system
to the Slackware system, I tarred, moved and untarred /usr/local from the
former to the latter. Now the latter will not boot (or run sftp, scp or
ssh).

  Why? During the boot process, the Slackware-9.1 box runs /sbin/agetty and
discovers that "/usr/local/lib/libc.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.3' not found
(required by ...)". Sigh.

  This means, of course, that I cannot even boot into single user mode. What
I'm thinking I need to do run through the install floppies, keeping the
partition table intact, then reinstall the system. But, that would not
overwrite /usr/local, will it?

  Would I be better off by downloading a copy of Knoppix, burning it onto a
cdrom, and using that to gain access to the hard drives on the hobbled
system? I suspect that if I can remove the inproper libc files I have a
chance of booting properly.

Comments?

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>



From pem at nellump.net  Sat Jan 31 18:47:02 2004
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Sat Jan 31 18:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] debian - mounting mac scsi hard drive ?
In-Reply-To: <013120041621.11505.5227@comcast.net>
References: <013120041621.11505.5227@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20040201024628.GA29810@nellump.net>

On Sat, Jan 31, 2004 at 04:21:24PM +0000, gilmanhunt at comcast.net wrote:
> 
> I'm on the right path, right? I bought a scsi card down at Freegeek, and a cable, and I think the mount command will look like 
> 
> #mount -t hfs /dev/sda0 /macdrive

You'll need a driver for the Mac filesystem. There are two, depending
on which flavor of HFS (Apple's "Hierarchical File System") the dead
PowerMac was using: HFS and HFS+. HFS+ is an extension of HFS (who
knew?), and supports much larger disks, along with lots of *nix-ish file
attributes. Kernel modules are available for both, and are included in
standard PPC trees.

I'd bet that the PowerMac was using HFS+. Other than backward
compatibility with older machines, there's no real reason to be using
HFS. If you mount an HFS+ partition with the HFS driver, you'll see a
handful of files, one of which is a readme-like text file telling you
why you can't see anything more.

It's unlikely the first partition on the drive will be the one you
want to mount. Apple's brand of Open Firmware likes to use up several
parititions. Listing the partition table with 'mac-fdisk -l /dev/bluh'
is an easy way to help guess which partition is the likely suspect.
Naturally, if it's a typical one-partition Mac drive, it'll be the last
on the disk (and the largest).

Good luck... :-)


Paul

>   This means, of course, that I cannot even boot into single user mode. What

Does your install medium have a rescue mode?  You could make a rescue CD 
or floppy.  They are smaller than Knoppix.  I always have a LNX-BBC 
mini-CD available for rescue situations.

Also, you might want to try starting a shell directly instead of going 
through the single-mode init process.  Try setting the "init=/bin/bash" 
kernel parameter.

  - Ian

> through the single-mode init process.  Try setting the "init=/bin/bash" 
> kernel parameter.
> 
>   - Ian
> 
> -- 
> ian at znark.com
> http://www.znark.com/
> 
The installation media is its own environment.  Use the rescue mode and
follow the chroot instructions.  Then delete or move the libc.so.6
files.  Then reboot.  You will be whole again.

Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM

On Sat, 31 Jan 2004, Ian Burrell wrote:

> Matt Alexander wrote:
> > Any Sonicwall users out there?  Have you found a way to keep your SSH
> > connections from being dropped after a few minutes of inactivity?
> > 
> 
> I recently figured out how to keep our Sonicwall at work from timing out 
> connections.  There is a default inactivity timeout but this didn't seem 
> to affect the connections.  There is also a timeout on each of the 
> filter rules.  If you increase the timeout on the incoming SSH rule, 
> then they won't timeout.

True, but my problem was with outgoing ssh connections.  I've resolved the
problem by adjusting tcp_keepalive_time on my Linux box, but it'd be nice
if I could have the Sonicwall not close ssh connections in the first
place.
~M

From sandy at herring.org  Sat Jan 31 22:08:02 2004
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Sat Jan 31 22:08:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] stupid vi question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401312154530.10811-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>
References: <401C36BA.9000807@brianquade.net> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0401312154530.10811-100000@hosting.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <20040201060752.GA3832@kippered.herring.org>

On Sat, 31 Jan 2004, Matt Alexander wrote: 
> On Sat, 31 Jan 2004, Brian Quade wrote:
> 
> > I am no vi expert or anything but I use it because it is convenient.  
> > (Actually I use vim.)  But if I accidentally hit the wrong key (the # 
> > key I think), then whatever word the cursor is on turns brown in every 
> > document I ever open with vi from that point onward.  I tried looking in 
> > .viminfo and I did remove all of the search history lines in there but 
> > it didn't work.  Does anyone know how I can turn this feature off 
> > forever or get rid of it or something so that I don't get brown text all 
> > over the screen?
> 
> I don't know off-hand how to permanentaly disable it, but you could always
> just search for something else that doesn't exist:
> 
> /lkjsflkjsdf

In your .vimrc,

    set nohlsearch      ' (aka nohls)

That's the default behavior, so I suspect your .vimrc has

    set hlsearch        ' (aka hls)

As Matt pointed out, you can do a failed search to get rid of the
highlighting on an adhoc basis. You can also,

    :noh

hth,
Sandy
